channel.title: Quartz
channel.description: Quartz is a digitally native news outlet for the new global economy.

item.title: A busy day for democracy.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: In addition to Brazil, many voters around the world cast their ballots Sunday. Exit polls in Ukraine suggested that over 75% of voters chose staunchly pro-Western parties (paywall) in parliamentary elections, though elections were not held in Crimea or in areas with high numbers of pro-Russian separatists. Uruguay's presidential election went to a run-off, and while votes are still being tallied in Tunisia's crowded election, the secular party is already claiming victory.

item.title: Scary clowns are no laughing matter.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: With Halloween just around the corner and nightmarish "horror clowns" on the rise, World Clown Association president-elect Randy Christensen (aka "Oxford P. Nuts") is calling for a return to "good, clean, wholesome, family-friendly, cheerful comedy."

item.title: Hong Kong's protesters call off their vote.
item.dc:creator: lilkuo
item.content:encoded: Leaders of Hong Kong's Umbrella Movement abruptly canceled a poll that asked the public about how to proceed with pro-democracy protests, citing "different opinions" within the movement, raising questions about demonstrators' unity and ultimate endgame. Meanwhile, an anti-Occupy rally turned violent on Saturday, earning condemnation from Hong Kong's chief executive, who called the assaults on journalists and students "a savage act."

item.title: Haters have been hating for a long time.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Philosopher Søren Kierkegaard advised how to deal with them nearly 200 years ago.

item.title: Hungary protests an internet tax.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Activists hurled computer parts at the economy ministry after the government proposed a levy of 140 forints ($0.60) per gigabyte of data traffic. The government said it would cap charges at 700 forints, a little over an hour's work at minimum wage.

item.title: Germany is losing what little confidence it has left.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Ifo Business Climate Index, a closely watched measure of German business confidence, fell to 103.2 in Oct., down from 104.7 last month, and a 22-month low. This is likely a reaction to the revised GDP figures issued two weeks ago.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Germany now expects its economy to grow by 1.2% this year, compared to an earlier prediction of 1.8%. And 2015's predicted growth rate—1.3%—isn't any better.

item.title: Comets smell absolutely disgusting.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The EU's Rosetta probe—which took 10 years to travel 250 million miles to reach comet 67P/C-G—discovered that is emitting formaldehyde, hydrogen sulphide, hydrogen cyanide, sulphur dioxide and carbon disulphide. In other words, the comet smells of rotten eggs and horse pee.

item.title: Prosecutors seek Sewol ferry captain's execution.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: South Korea hasn't exercised the death penalty for 17 years, but some want the captain of the ferry that sank in April, claiming nearly 300 lives, to receive the country's harshest punishment. Three crew members may also face life in prison.

item.title: IBM throws analytics software at the Ebola virus.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Big Blue is doing what it does best: Taking its expertise in big data and using it to solve serious problems. The computing company is donating various bits of technology to Nigeria's and Sierra Leone's governments that will enable citizens to use text messages to report outbreaks and ask questions.

item.title: The news just got worse for Russia, Iran, and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Another big Wall Street voice is forecasting long-term lower crude oil prices—as low as $75 per barrel in 2015. Joining Citi as a bear, Goldman Sachs says US shale oil will overpower anything OPEC can do to contain production.

item.title: ISIL has got its hands on anti-aircraft rockets.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: And it may use them on commercial airlines or the jets being used by US-led coalition forces (paywall) according to German intelligence. Some of the missiles—captured from Syrian stocks—date back to the 1970s, while others are said to be modern.

item.title: What Brazil desperately needs is better infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Twitter gets no love.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The microblogging service's third quarter financial results were roughly in line with expectations, as revenue more than doubled to $361 million. But its closely watched engagement metric—timeline views per user—slid 7%, and active user growth ticked down slightly, sending shares down more than 9%.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Baffles me when a company beats revenue estimates, matches growth estimates, & still drops ~10% in after hours $TWTR pic.twitter.com/gnkdgT1gUr

— Kurt Wagner (@KurtWagner8) October 27, 2014

item.title: The FBI may have found the NSA's "second leaker."
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Investigators searched the home of a contractor they suspect of leaking a terrorist watch list to Glenn Greenwald, a journalist who worked with Edward Snowden. The list contained the names of 1.2 million people, half of whom had "no recognized terrorist affiliation."

item.title: China merges its two biggest train makers.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: CNR and CSR will combine to more effectively compete for international rail contracts, sources told Bloomberg. The merger, ordered by China's state council, will create a $26 billion company that has recently won contracts to build subway cars for Boston and bullet trains for Macedonia.

item.title: Japanese shoppers rediscover their wallets.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Retail sales growth accelerated for the third straight month in September, which may make it easier for prime minister Shinzo Abe to push through another sales tax increase. Sales grew 2.3% in September from a year earlier, higher than a predicted 0.6% increase.

item.title: Apple and Alibaba flirt over e-payments.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Alibaba chairman Jack Ma said at a Wall Street Journal conference that he would be “very interested” in a partnership with the newly launched Apple Pay service; “We’re going to talk about getting married later this week,” Apple CEO Tim Cook replied. But both companies are subject to intense scrutiny from Beijing, which has tried to protect the market share of its massive state-owned banks.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Apple's R&D spending during its latest fiscal year (paywall) topped $6 billion, or 3.3% of its revenues, notes the Financial Times—a figure that the company hasn't dedicated to research since the 2007 launch of the iPhone, and a one-third increase over last year.

item.title: Japan’s richest man is now a big player in India’s online economy.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Softbank CEO Masayoshi Son has invested $627 million in India’s Snapdeal, an Alibaba-like marketplace, and is leading a $210 million investment in Ola, an Uber-like taxi service. Son was also an early investor in Alibaba, and reaped massive profits from its IPO.

item.title: Table tennis stars can throw tantrums, too.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A Chinese tournament winner was stripped of $45,000 in prize money after he trashed the arena.

item.title: You should gamble on an empty stomach.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Research subjects had a better grasp of the odds when they were hungry.

item.title: Sweden zeroes out.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: For the first time in its 350-year history, Sweden's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate to 0%. The country has been fighting a losing battle with deflation for a while, but a faction at the bank that feared rising debt levels until fairly recently resisted extra monetary stimulus.

item.title: How baby boomers changed their minds over legal weed.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Pfizer beat the street.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The US's largest drug maker beat expectations on its third-quarter numbers. Executives credited the results to a 9% bump in sales in emerging markets.

item.title: Russia fans the flames in Ukraine, again.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov says his country will "recognize the results" of the elections scheduled to take place this Sunday (Nov. 2) in the rebel-controlled east, despite protests from Kiev and the West. Lavrov said the vote will "legitimize the authorities there."

item.title: 5,000+ medical workers need to travel to Africa—now.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That's the message of Jim Yong Kim, president of the World Bank. At a conference in Ethiopia, he pleaded: "I hope health care professionals will understand that when they took their oath to become a health care worker it was precisely for moments like this."

item.title: Digging a tunnel under a bank vault actually works.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Police in northern India are trying to locate perps who dug a tunnel 125 feet long and just 2.5 ft. wide to a bank from an empty house. They got away with cash, jewelry, and other valuables worth a few hundred thousand dollars.

item.title: Lloyds is cutting 10% of its workforce.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Rumors of the cuts started floating around late last week, but now it's official. As well as cutting 9,000 jobs, the British bank will reduce the number of branches by 7%, as it invests more in online banking. It also saw a hefty year-on-year jump in third-quarter profit, though a drop in the nine-month total.

item.title: Would you buy a used video game from this company?
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Walmart will offer second-hand game titles in 1,700 of its 4,800 US stores, even as the games console market seems to be tanking. Gamestop, which currently dominates the used-game market, doesn't seem to be worried.

item.title: Facebook meets expectations, but scares investors.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Revenue and earnings were roughly in line, and monthly active users rose 14%. But the social media giant warned of an impending spending binge ("We plan on 2015 being a significant investment year"), and its shares plummeted by about 9% in after-hours trading.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_288467" align="aligncenter" width="640"] [/caption] https://twitter.com/jandawson/status/527195128210153472

FB mobile ad revenues were just shy of $2 billion in Q3, from zero in Q1 2012. Pretty astounding growth. pic.twitter.com/QU0eOJftjI

— Jan Dawson (@jandawson) October 28, 2014

item.title: We identified the problem—now we're correcting it.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: A commercial rocket exploded at takeoff in Virginia.
item.dc:creator: tfernholz
item.content:encoded: An Antares rocket built by Orbital Sciences suffered a "catastrophic failure" shortly after launching at 6:22 p.m. local time on the east coast of the United States, resulting in an enormous explosion. NASA, which hired the private space firm to bring supplies and research materials to the International Space Station, said no injuries were reported.

item.title: Being a pop star is hazardous to your health.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: Marvel maps out a diverse future, but risks a superhero glut.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Disney-owned moviemaker unveiled a slate of nine movies it has planned through 2019, including standalone films featuring female ("Captain Marvel") and African-American ("The Black Panther") superhero protagonists. Including films on the way from rival DC Entertainment, that makes 29 superhero movies scheduled for the next six years. (This post incorrectly said the movie featuring a female lead was "Marvel Girl.")

item.title: The Iraqi peshmerga starts its first Syrian mission.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: 150 Kurdish fighters received permission to travel through Turkey to join the fight against Islamic State militants in the Syrian border town of Kobani. Turkey reiterated it will not send ground troops to support the Syrian Kurds, nor will it allow Kurds from the Kurdistan Workers' Party, or PKK, to fight.

item.title: The US national anthem ends with a question mark.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It expresses “a sense of fear and anxiety” to reflect its wartime origins.

item.title: Zambia's president dies in London.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Michael Sata, 77, was receiving treatment for an undisclosed illness. Zambian vice president Guy Scott will be the acting leader until elections are held in 90 days. Scott is the first white leader of an African country since South Africa's apartheid era.

item.title: A pilot strike costs Air France-KLM €330 million.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Two weeks of industrial action last month contributed to a more than 50% annual fall in the airline's third-quarter operating profit, which was €247 million ($315 million). Europe's second-largest network carrier said it would focus on "dynamic management" throughout 2015 to make up for lost earnings, but denied it has plans to slash jobs.

item.title: Nintendo gets a high score.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The video game company recorded third-quarter net income of 24.2 billion yen ($224 million), well above expectations of 5.7 billion yen and up from a loss of 8 billion yen a year earlier. Increased demand for Wii U games and a weaker yen boosted the results; Nintendo left its full-year sales forecast unchanged at 590 billion yen.

item.title: Sanofi fires its CEO.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The French drug maker’s directors ousted Christopher Viehbacher due to dissatisfaction with his “management style and relationship with the company’s board.” Rumors of Viehbacher’s impending exit—which he discounted just yesterday—have been circulating since he moved to the US in June, taking Sanofi away from its French roots.

item.title: Russian health authorities don’t like selfies.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: They have accused the narcissistic photography craze of being "the main reason" for the spread of head lice.

item.title: Reinforcements start trickling into Kobani.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: About 50 armed rebels from the Free Syrian Army entered the border town from Turkey to help Kurdish fighters in their battle against an onslaught of Islamic State militants in Syria. A group of 150 Iraqi Kurdish peshmerga fighters is also headed to Kobani to join the fight, which has been raging since mid-September.

item.title: Fiat lets Ferrari drive off the lot.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Ferrari will become its own company by the end of next year, with Fiat listing 10% of the shares in the super-car maker and then giving the rest to shareholders. Luca Cordero di Montezemolo, who lead Ferrari for 23 years, stepped down earlier this month.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In related news, Chrysler—which Fiat took control of this year—issued two recalls Wednesday totaling 566,000 trucks and SUVs.

item.title: Chinese real estate is hot—at least by this measure.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Data gathered by the China Sexology Association says 44% of men and 40% of women have sex less than once a week. But a breakdown by profession found that those in real estate are the most likely to report copious amounts of coitus.

item.title: Officials point to Kremlin in hacking of the White House.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Nothing was broken in the breach, said anonymous White House officials, who told the Washington Post that the hackers were probably working for Russian intelligence. Computers storing classified information weren't compromised, they said. This wouldn't be the first time Russia has penetrated America's systems: It hacked into US military networks back in 2008.

item.title: German exports to Russia plummet.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In August, goods worth 2.3 billion euros were exported from Deutschland to the Russian Federation. That's down 26.3% year-over-year. Thank sanctions and Russia's ban on Western food for that. This isn't helping things in Germany, where economic growth is already sputtering.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Ostpolitik kaputt pic.twitter.com/XiP8ZJoLyb

— Jason Karaian (@jkaraian) October 29, 2014

item.title: An insult heightens US tensions with Israel.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Atlantic quoted an unnamed senior White House official calling Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu "chickenshit," for failing to compromise with Palestinians or the Sunni Arab states. "Certainly that's not the administration's view," a US official quickly asserted. Netanyahu told Israel's parliament that he is "not prepared to make concessions that will endanger our state."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: If nothing else, the ensuing brouhaha seems to support the premise of the original article in the Atlantic, by Jeffrey Goldberg and headlined: "The Crisis in U.S.-Israel Relations Is Officially Here." But US officials are saying that there is no such crisis.

item.title: QE ends; the world does not.
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
item.content:encoded: As expected, the US central bank concluded its most recent bond-purchasing program, or "quantitative easing." (The jury is still out on whether that helped the recovery.) The Fed also made Wall Street queasy by signaling that it might hike rates sooner than expected, but the damage was minor.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Fed ends QE. No sign of end times. But rates pop a bit. pic.twitter.com/dg6YDh47UX

— Matt Phillips (@MatthewPhillips) October 29, 2014

item.title: The Fed is finally taking the training wheels off the US economy
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
item.content:encoded: XXX

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Fed is finally taking the training wheels off the US economy

item.title: IBM and Twitter shake hands.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Twitter will give IBM its data. And in return, IBM will use its supercomputers to sell solutions that enable companies to "make better decisions." Details are few and far between, but Twitter says it's seeing 15 billion pieces of "social activity" every day on its network.

item.title: Russia tests NATO with aerial maneuvers.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Some two dozen Russian planes have tested NATO airspace over the past 24 hours, including two bombers that flew along the coasts of Norway, the United Kingdom, and Portugal early on Thursday morning. NATO said its jets scrambled to intercept and monitor the "unusual" Russian flights, which also took place off the coasts of Lithuania and Turkey.

item.title: This is why Hong Kong needs its young people.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz

item.title: Samsung surprises no one with a terrible quarter.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The electronics giant fulfilled its own dire predictions as its smartphone profits cratered, falling to 1.75 trillion won ($1.66 billion) from 6.70 trillion won a year ago due to fierce competition from Apple's iPhone and cheaper Chinese competitors. Samsung said it "cautiously expects" an increase in the current quarter's profits, but its TV and microchip units will have to do the heavy lifting.

item.title: Bad loans spiked at China's biggest lender.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: ICBC, the world's largest bank by assets, reported the biggest increase in bad loans since 2006 as China's economy cooled off and its property market struggled in particular. Third-quarter nonperforming loans rose 9% from the previous quarter to 115.5 billion yuan ($18.9 billion), accounting for 1.06% of all loans.

item.title: Zambia gets a white head of state.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Vice president Guy Scott was named acting president after Michael Sata died in London on Tuesday, becoming the first white leader of a sub-Saharan African country since the fall of apartheid. But Scott cannot run for president as his parents were not born in Zambia.

item.title: Drinking milk to get strong bones?
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: New research shows it may actually have the reverse effect.

item.title: The Giants win the World Series, and the world gets snarky.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The San Francisco Giants defeated the Kansas City Royals 3-2 in Game 7 for their third championship in five years. That prompted an outpouring of skepticism about a "world" title awarded by a league solely populated by US (and one Canadian) baseball teams.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
So which country won the World Series this year?

— FrankHendstein (@LibyaLiberty) October 30, 2014

America beat America in the World Series? Awesome.

— Alastair Gale (@AlastairGale) October 30, 2014

item.title: Tunisia votes in a secular party.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Nidaa Tounes party won 85 seats in the country’s new parliament, short of an outright majority; Islamist party Ennahda won 69 seats, and called for the formation of an inclusive government. The peaceful election was Tunisia’s second since the Arab Spring.

item.title: Xiaomi surges into third place.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Chinese company became the world’s third-biggest smartphone maker as sales increased by 211% to 17.3 million thanks to its iPhone-like Mi4 handset, according to research firm IDC. Second-place Apple had its best third quarter ever due to iPhone 6 and 6 Plus sales, shipping 39.3 million phones in all, and Samsung retained the top spot even though its shipments declined.

item.title: Xiaomi surges into third place among smartphone makers.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: Chasing birds can get you arrested.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A TV pitchman was busted for harassing an owl in a paraglider.

item.title: gross-domestic-investment-2009-13-average_chartbuilder1
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Federal-Reserve-QE-Training-Wheels
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
item.content:encoded: Cyclists peddle past the United States Federal Reserve Board building (rear) in Washington October 28, 2014. The U.S. Federal Reserve this week will likely reinforce its stated willingness to wait a long while before hiking interest rates after a volatile month in financial markets that saw some measure of inflation expectations drop worryingly low. REUTERS/Gary Cameron (UNITED STATES - Tags: BUSINESS POLITICS)

item.title: Hong-Kong-s-elderly-dependency-ratio-per-1-000-population-Number_chartbuilder
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz

item.title: Third-quarter-smartphone-sales-Volume-Annual-Growth_chartbuilder
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: A cellist is performing duets with her own brain.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Katinka Kleijn translates her brain waves into sound. While hooked up to an electroencephalography (EEG) headset, she plays the cello while reacting to words like "grief" and "excitement" that subtly change her brain activity.

item.title: Hong Kong is still a very easy place to do business
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Hong Kong’s Occupy Central, which vowed to bring the city’s financial center to a standstill, hasn’t quite done its job: The World Bank says that despite the pro-democracy protests, Hong Kong is still the world’s third-best locale to do business.

item.title: Tim Cook: "I'm proud to be gay."
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: "While I have never denied my sexuality, I haven’t publicly acknowledged it either, until now. So let me be clear: I’m proud to be gay, and I consider being gay among the greatest gifts God has given me," the Apple CEO writes in Businessweek.

item.title: America's economy grew more than expected in Q3.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The country's GDP grew by 3.5% in the third quarter, higher than the 3% predicted by analysts surveyed by Bloomberg. The quarterly growth caps the country's strongest 6-month streak in over a decade; the economy grew 4.6% in Q2. Fewer oil imports have helped lower the trade deficit, while job gains and cheaper gas are boosting confidence among American consumers.

item.title: Protestors set Burkina Faso's parliament building on fire.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The outrage stems from the government's attempt to allow the president in power for 27 years, Blaise Compaoré, to serve again. "October 30 is Burkina Faso's Black Spring, like the Arab Spring," said one activist. MPs responded to the blaze by abandoning their plans to extend Compaoré's reign.

item.title: The New York Times is doing better than it expected.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Grey Lady said its third-quarter loss still managed to beat Wall Street and the company's expectations as digital revenues offset declines on the print side. Digital advertising revenue grew 16.5%; the company expected 16%. Subscribers to the NYT's digital-only offering rose by 44,000 to 875,000, its best quarterly increase in almost two years. Still, the company is slashing jobs company-wide to contain costs.

item.title: The US ranks shamefully high on child poverty.
item.dc:creator: qzroya

item.title: The US economy keeps on truckin'.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: us-real-gdp-annualized-change-us-real-gdp-annualized-change_chartbuilder
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Shadow banking has grown to 120% of the world's GDP.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The murky industry, which includes hedge funds, real estate investment trusts and off-balance sheet investment vehicles, is worth $75 trillion, according to the Financial Stability Board. It grew $5 trillion in the span of one year, thanks to lenders looking to avoid regulations and investors seeking yield amid historically low interest rates. Argentina's shadow banking sector grew the most—50% year-over-year—followed by China's, which grew 30%.

item.title: Lufthansa admits it's struggling to keep up—again.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It's the airline's second profit warning in less than six months. CEO Carsten Spohr said its previous forecast for 2015—of operating revenues hitting $2.52 billion—is unattainable, thanks to Europe's economic slowdown and lower airfares driven by regional competitors like Ryanair and mideast carriers like Emirates. Ebola, political crises and worker strikes haven't helped, Spohr said.

item.title: Vice Media spreads its wings to Canada.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Brooklyn, NY-based media company (founded in Montreal) focused on the young and irreverent is spreading its provocative content to Canadian TV, mobile and digital devices in 2015. As part of its $100 million joint venture with Rogers Communications, Vice will have its own channel on country's no. 1 cable operator, which has two million subscribers.

item.title: Citigroup is facing new probes into its currency business.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: And it's going to be expensive. The bank took a new, $600 million legal charge against third-quarter earnings, in addition to $951 million in legal expenses it already disclosed, because of "rapidly evolving regulatory inquiries." Those now include a criminal probe in the US, and inquiries in the U.K. and Switzerland.

item.title: Russia signs a gas deal with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Russia will supply Ukraine with 4 billion cubic meters of gas until March next year, at a cost of $4.6 billion, some of which is for previous gas deliveries. Ukraine must pay the sum up front but the EU, which also signed the agreement, will provide "unprecedented levels" of aid to help cover the cost.

item.title: Starbucks results are lukewarm.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A 1% rise in traffic and a 5% rise in same-store sales in the Americas failed to excite investors, who were hoping for a rise of 6.2%. Chief executive Howard Schultz said the popularity of online shopping meant was leading to fewer customers in stores.

item.title: North Korea quarantines all arriving foreigners over Ebola fears.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: All non-North Koreans entering Pyongyang will be required to spend three weeks under observation. North Korea has had no reported cases of Ebola.

item.title: A new military leader is in control of Burkina Faso.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Lt. Col. Isaac Zida emerged from a power struggle to take charge of an interim government after president Blaise Compaoré was forcibly removed after 27 years in power. Thousands of protesters gathered to denounce the coup, and the UN warned of potential sanctions.

item.title: You may have a throat virus that lowers your brainpower.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Chlorovirus ATCV-1 is found in 40% of Americans.

item.title: Beware fake priests in graveyards.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Filipino police warn of fraudulent clerics seeking payment for prayers on All Saints’ Day.

item.title: The Bank of Japan gives world markets a boost.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Both the Nikkei in Japan and the S&P 500 in the US closed on record highs after the Japanese central bank said it would expand its bond purchases to 80 trillion yen a year ($726 billion), from 60-70 trillion currently, in a surprise attempt to kickstart the sluggish economy. The bank's board said the move was necessary to reverse "a deflationary mindset" (paywall).

item.title: Sony losses aren't as bad as expected.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The struggling Japanese technology company reported an operating loss of 85.6 billion yen ($780 million) in its fiscal second quarter, about half the expected loss. Sales of its PlayStation 4 console helped the company—it sold 3.3 million in the quarter, outpacing Xbox sales.

item.title: Hungary backs down on its internet tax.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Prime minister Viktor Orban said mass protests and industry opposition convinced him to drop a proposal to levy a tax based on bandwidth consumption. “We aren’t governing against the people but for them,” he said.

item.title: BNP Paribas and RBS are back in the black.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: BNP posted a third-quarter profit of €1.5 billion ($1.9 billion), after a loss in the second quarter due to a US fine for violating sanctions. RBS swung to a third-quarter pre-tax profit of £1.27 billion ($2 billion), from a loss of £634 million (paywall) the same period last year.

item.title: Halloween costumes are banned on the Beijing subway.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Authorities say they could cause “panic” or “stampedes” (paywall).

item.title: The Tea Party is over.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Republicans are once again all about Wall Street.

item.title: The case for immigration in Japan.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Americans are clenching their wallets.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Consumer spending in September surprisingly fell 0.2%—the first month-to-month drop in eight months. And this is despite gas prices falling below $3 a gallon in most of the 50 states. Didn't consumer confidence just hit a seven year high?

item.title: Russia's central bank raises its benchmark interest rate to 9.5%.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The jump—from the previous 8.0% rate—was steeper than what economists were expecting. Despite the move, and the $15 billion in spending the government has been engaged in to prop up the ruble, Russia has seen its currency drop 8% in value in October alone.

item.title: Britain goes easy on its banks.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Lenders knew they'd have to start keeping a greater percentage of their capital in the vault, but the 4.05% minimum leverage ratio that the Bank of England will be requiring as of 2019 is well below the 7.5% ratio some were expecting. Barclays and Lloyds shares rose on the news.

item.title: Microsoft reportedly fires its global ad sales team.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Facebook experiment results in higher voter turnout.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In the fall of 2012, the social networking giant manipulated the feeds of 1.9 million users, promoting news stories over other—personal—shared items. When "occasional" Facebook users were surveyed about voting habits, the users who had their feeds changed were 3% more likely to vote than the control group.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A similar study on happiness was done on 700,000 users in Jan. 2012 (pdf).

item.title: Abenomics just made the Nikkei notch a seven-year high.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Richard Branson vows to press on, cautiously, into space.
item.dc:creator: tfernholz
item.content:encoded: "Space is hard—but worth it. We will persevere and move forward together," wrote the Virgin head in a statement after SpaceShipTwo, the flagship of his space-tourism project, exploded on a test flight on Friday, killing one of the pilots. But, he added at a news conference, "we are not going to push on blindly."

item.title: What's your poison?
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Drinks giant Diageo is poised to trade ownership of Bushmills whiskey to Jose Cuervo in exchange for control of their joint venture, the fast-growing Don Julio tequila brand, the WSJ reports (paywall). Diageo failed to buy the whole of family-owned Jose Cuervo two years ago.

item.title: The UK approaches the "point of no return."
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Angela Merkel is running out of patience with her British counterpart, David Cameron, over his plan to potentially cap the number of migrants into the UK. Der Speigel reports that Germany believes the move to raise the drawbridge would "cross a red line," making a UK exit from the EU a genuine possibility.

item.title: The expiration date for fossil fuels is 2100.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change said the majority of the world's electricity must be low carbon by 2050, and fossil fuel-free by the end of the century. It estimates a cost of only 0.06% of global GDP every year to keep temperatures from rising more than 2 °C. Will world leaders meeting in Paris next year listen?

item.title: A suicide bomber strikes at the Pakistan-India border.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A blast killed more than 50 people and injured 100 on the Pakistani side of the Ragah border crossing, which draws hundreds of visitors daily to watch elaborate flag-lowering ceremonies on both sides. The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility, as did another militant group.

item.title: Ukraine's separatists elect a leader.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Rebels who refused to participate in national elections held their own poll and elected separatist leader Alexander Zakharchenko as their president. Russia said it will recognize the vote; Europe and the US say the election violates a cease-fire deal.

item.title: A new electrified spoon could give your food some zing.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The utensil zaps your taste buds with electrodes, and could be used to augment flavors for people who cannot eat sugary and salty foods.

item.title: If you want a middle-class raise, it helps to live near a fracking site.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: Argentina suspends Procter & Gamble.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It accused the world’s biggest consumer products company of inflating import prices to evade taxes (paywall). Argentine officials also notified their regulatory counterparts in the United States about the allegations; P&G has yet to comment.

item.title: Macy’s store layout could use some work.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Thirty percent of visitors at its flagship location in New York City's Herald Square are visibly lost (paywall). So the retailer is spending four years and $400 million on a renovation.

item.title: Publicis finds a consolation prize.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The world's third-largest advertising company, which tried unsuccessfully to merge with Omnicom earlier this year, agreed to pay $3.7 billion in cash for digital ad firm Sapient in an attempt to boost its US presence.

item.title: Ryanair defies Europe's economic doldrums.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Irish budget airline said it expects fiscal year profits of $935 million to $960 million (paywall), up from the $774 million-$811 million range it predicted earlier. Better customer service and flights to bigger airports also contributed to a 4% rise in its first-half passenger numbers.

item.title: British banker charged with double murder in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Rurik George Caton Jutting, 29, has been charged with killing two women, one of whom was found in a suitcase on the balcony of Jutting's apartment. If convicted, he faces life in prison. Hong Kong isn't known for violence, with just 14 homicides recorded between January and July of 2014.

item.title: World Trade Center has reopened.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Just 60% of the 1,776-foot tall $3.9 billion building has been leased thus far, with publishing giant Condé Nast taking five of the 104 stories. Condé Nast says 170 of its employees are moving in now, with another 3,000 people due to set up their desks in early 2015.

item.title: The hole in the ozone layer is now the size of the US.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: But scientists from NASA and NOAA say that despite its size, people shouldn't panic because the hole—over Antarctica—has stayed practically the same as it was in 2013. It's also "smaller than what we saw in the late-1990s and early 2000s," according to NASA's Paul Newman.

item.title: Thieves steal an infamous concentration-camp sign.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Vandals took the sign at the Dachau concentration camp that reads "Arbeit macht frei" (Work sets you free). It symbolizes the suffering of millions incarcerated and killed by the Nazis during World War II. In 2009, a sign bearing the same slogan was stolen from Auschwitz.

item.title: China creates drone-killing lasers.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: State media claim the once it has locked-in a drone, the system takes only five seconds to shoot it out of the sky. During tests, the system successfully detected and destroyed 30 drones. The laser only work on drones traveling less than 50 meters/second, at an altitude of less than 500 meters.

item.title: You need to make £7.85 an hour to live in the UK.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Britain's Living Wage Foundation has increased the hourly wage it thinks one should be making in order to live in the country by £0.20. For London, its recommendation went from £8.80 an hour to £9.15 ($14.64). Britain's minimum wage remains £6.50 ($10.40) an hour, compared with$7.25 in the US.

item.title: Americans are putting off buying their first home.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: One in three home purchases made this year have been by first-time buyers, and that's a 27-year low—the norm is usually around 40%. The chief economist at the National Association of Realtors blames increasing home prices—soon likely to peak (paywall)—and "stringent credit standards."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Percent of first-time home buyers drops to 27-year low http://t.co/oOqxRZL75Q pic.twitter.com/5tYGzMXm2H

— MarketWatch Economy (@MKTWeconomics) November 3, 2014

item.title: Emirates kills its FIFA sponsorship.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The airline's move comes amid a torrent of corruption allegations swirling around soccer's top body, including controversy about the selection of Qatar as the site for the 2022 World Cup. Emirates may be replaced as a sponsor by none other than Qatar Airlines. Sony, which is reviewing its sponsorship and has called for a corruption investigation, may be replaced by its major rival Samsung.

item.title: Iran has jailed a woman who attended a men's volleyball game.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Ghoncheh Ghavami, an Iranian-British woman, has been sentenced to a year in jail after being found guilty of disseminating anti-government propaganda at a men's volleyball game in the summer. Ghavami was defying a ban on women attending male-only matches. Over 710,000 people have signed a petition demanding she be released immediately.

item.title: The dollar is hitting 7-year highs against the yen.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Japan's unexpected stimulus announcement last Friday pushed the yen to ¥113.81 against the dollar. If it breaks ¥114.02, then the US currency will be at levels not seen since Dec. 2007. In related currency news, the euro is getting clobbered to levels not seen since Aug. 2012.

item.title: The US fines Korean car makers for polluting.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Kia and Hyundai understated the CO2 emissions of some of their cars by about 4.75 million tonnes—equivalent to a year’s emissions from a million passenger cars. Their $100 million fine—plus the forfeiture of $200 million in greenhouse gas emissions credits—is the biggest penalty in the history of the US Clean Air Act.

item.title: A major setback for the US tax fraud crackdown.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A Florida jury found a former top UBS banker not guilty on charges that he conspired to help wealthy Americans hide $20 billion in offshore accounts. US authorities have spent six years trying to prosecute Raoul Weil, the highest-ranking Swiss banker to stand trial in the United States.

item.title: Russia removed a Steve Jobs memorial after Tim Cook came out.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A statue in the shape of an iPhone honoring the late Apple co-founder, erected by a Russian group of companies called ZEFS last year, was removed last week after current Apple CEO announced that he was gay. ""In Russia, gay propaganda and other sexual perversions among minors are prohibited by law," ZEFS said in a statement, noting that the memorial had been "in an area of direct access for young students and scholars."

item.title: Taylor Swift snubs Spotify.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The millennial pop star's move to remove her entire catalog from the streaming music services comes on the heels of huge sales of her latest album, 1989, making her 2014's only platinum-selling artist. As a result she is quickly becoming the most influential artist of her generation, at least in terms of her impact on the industry.

item.title: The United States is slipping as a good place to do business.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: The US probes JPMorgan.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The justice department opened a criminal investigation into the bank's  foreign-exchange trading activities. JPMorgan, the largest US bank by assets, said settlement talks are underway, and increased its loss estimates for legal proceedings from $4.6 billion to $5.9 billion.

item.title: China has a monthly cremation quota.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: Apple mulls a euro bond.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Deutsche Bank and Goldman Sachs are reportedly arranging what could be the company's first non-dollar bond sale (paywall). A euro issuance could be cheaper for Apple and may also help the tech giant avoid repatriation taxes on some of the money it has stashed in foreign subsidiaries.

item.title: Xiaomi is going fundraising.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded:
The world's third-largest smartphone manufacturer is reportedly planning to raise a new round of investment that would value the company at between $40 billion and $50 billion, according to Bloomberg. The company's previous round, in August 2013, valued Xiaomi at only $10 billion.

(We incorrectly reported earlier that the company was raising up to $50 billion.)

item.title: Sprint is a headache for Softbank.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Problems at the US wireless carrier have led Softbank to cut its fiscal 2015 operating profit forecast to 900 billion yen ($7.9 billion), from 1 trillion yen earlier. Softbank bought Sprint for $22 billion last year (paywall) but the carrier has been losing customers fast, and talks to tie up with T-Mobile US fell apart recently.

item.title: Banco Santander rides the Spanish recovery.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Spanish bank’s third-quarter net profit rose 52% on the year to €1.6 billion ($2 billion), while provisions for delinquent and defaulted loans fell 8% in the period to €2.78 billion. In Spain, profits more than doubled (paywall) in the first nine months of the year.

item.title: A cute penguin robot is roaming Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It goes undercover to research adult penguins.

item.title: Alibaba dazzles in first post-IPO earnings report.
item.dc:creator: gguilfordqz
item.content:encoded: The Chinese e-commerce giant blew past expectations, announcing $2.7 billion in revenue for the quarter ended September—a 53.7% increase on the same period the previous year. Between June and September, Alibaba added 28 million active customers, bringing its total to 307 million‚ roughly the population of the entire United States.

item.title: China's anti-corruption policies put a dent in Macau's casinos.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The territory—the only place in China where one can legally gamble—recorded casino revenues of approximately $3.5 billion in October. That's down 23.2% year-over-year, the biggest fall on record. A crackdown on Chinese government corruption is deterring some of the high rollers who are responsible for 60% of the city's gaming revenues.

item.title: Thailand arrests a Pirate Bay co-founder.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Hans Fredrik Lennart Neij, a.k.a. TiAMO, was convicted in Sweden in 2009 for copyright infringement for running the file-sharing website. As soon as he posted bail, he left the country, and has been living in Laos since 2012. Crossing into Thailand, he got flagged and was arrested in Nong Khai.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In related news, another Pirate Bay co-founder—there are three in total—was sentenced last week to three and a half years of hard time in Denmark for breaking into sensitive computer systems in 2012 and stealing personal information.

item.title: Spain doesn't want Catalonia to even pretend to vote.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Spanish Constitutional Court has banned Catalonians from holding a symbolic vote for their independence on Nov. 9. This comes after the court's Sept. 29 ban on an official independence referendum. It's not the first time Catalonia has attempted to do this, and likely won't be the last.

item.title: India's Supreme Court wants women make-up artists.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Strong union protections have made it illegal for women to do Bollywood movie make-up since 1955 (though hair, bizarrely, was allowed). The country's supreme court has ruled the ban unconstitutional. "Remove this immediately," the judges wrote. "We are in 2014, not in 1935. Such things cannot continue even for a day."

item.title: America votes today.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Republicans are expected to win eight seats—and become the majority—in the Senate, while likely capturing nine seats in the House. Key policy issues in the balance include climate change, the legalization of marijuana, and abortion.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
It's Election Day! Our final forecast: Republicans have a 3 in 4 chance of winning the Senate: http://t.co/Sfg43bN518 pic.twitter.com/siVi5lx5AZ

— FiveThirtyEight (@FiveThirtyEight) November 4, 2014

It's Election Day! Our final forecast: Republicans have a 3 in 4 chance of winning the Senate: http://t.co/Sfg43bN518 pic.twitter.com/siVi5lx5AZ

— FiveThirtyEight (@FiveThirtyEight) November 4, 2014

item.title: SoundCloud scores its first major label deal.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Warner Music will put an untold number of its tracks on the online music streaming service, and get paid whenever said tracks get streamed. A premium version of SoundCloud launches in 2015 that will let artists and DJs promote their work, so expect to see other labels make similar commitments.

item.title: Facebook spills the beans on more of its users.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Governments asked the social network for data on its users 34,946 times in the first half of 2014, a 24% increase on the second half of 2013. Facebook is adamant that it'd rather not be handing over this data, but local laws require it to.

item.title: Amazon makes Prime more tempting.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The giant online retailer is giving members of the $99-a-year Prime program unlimited photo backups—US only, for now. And Prime subscribers who shop on UK retailer AllSaints will get the same free two-day shipping as when they shop on Amazon. Both moves are aimed at getting more Prime subscribers.

item.title: A Japanese computer speaks better English than Japanese kids.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: NTT Labs has developed software, called "To-Robo", that scores higher (paywall) on the English section of the entrance exam to Tokyo University than your typical Japanese teenager. It's achieved a 95 (out of 200) this year, higher than the 52 it managed just one year ago, while humans averaged 93.1.

item.title: The GOP takes the US Senate.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Republicans won Democrat-held Senate seats in seven states (paywall), with the outcomes of several races yet to be declared, and expanded their majority in the House of Representatives. The GOP framed the race as a referendum on president Obama, who now faces the difficult prospect of a fully Republican-controlled Congress for his last two years in office.

item.title: Asia's richest man gets into leasing planes.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Li Ka-shing's Cheung Kong holdings will spend $1.9 billion on 35 planes and will form a joint venture with Japanese company MC Aviation Partners, which will buy a further 15. Asia's rising middle class represents a growth area for airlines.

item.title: Europe leads the downturn in global cement sales.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Third-quarter sales at Paris-based Lafarge, the world's second-largest cement maker, fell 2% to €3.6 billion ($4.6 billion), on an 8% fall in Western Europe. Sales growth was highest in the Middle East and Africa at 9%, followed by a 6% rise in Asia (paywall); chief executive Bruno Lafont said a strong euro was partly to blame.

item.title: A weak yen gives Toyota a bump.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Japanese auto maker raised its full-year operating profit forecast by 9.1% to 2.5 trillion yen ($21.9 billion) despite trimming its auto sales target slightly.

item.title: Cable news is changing how Americans vote.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: An early version of eBay.com was about Ebola.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The virus was one of founder Pierre Omidyar’s obsessions.

item.title: Germany is finally falling in love with the hamburger.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The sandwich, whose name is derived from the city of Hamburg, comes full circle.

item.title: Washington, DC, and Oregon legalized recreational marijuana.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US capital's successful referendum allows residents over 21 to grow, possess, and "transfer" cannabis but not to buy or sell it—although a Republican-controlled Congress could still try to block legalization. Oregon's law is more in line with more liberal recreational marijuana laws in Washington and Colorado.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In related news, Eaze—known as the Uber for pot—raised $1.5 million.

item.title: The euro zone can shake its malaise.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Retail sales were much weaker than expected, falling 1.3% month-on-month, and Markit's final composite purchasing managers' index was essentially flat at 52.1 in October, from 52.0 in September.

item.title: The euro zone can't shake its malaise.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: September retail sales were much weaker than expected, falling 1.3% month-on-month, and Markit's final composite purchasing managers' index was essentially flat at 52.1 in October, from 52.0 in September.

item.title: African leaders try to talk sense to Burkina Faso.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The presidents of Ghana, Nigeria, and Senegal will meet with the country's military leaders to urge a transfer of power to a civilian government. The African Union said Burkina Faso's army will face sanctions if it doesn't step aside within two weeks.

item.title: Siemens splits again.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The German conglomerate will reportedly spin off its €14 billion ($18 billion) healthcare unit into a separate company. Earlier this year, Siemens divested itself of appliances (paywall), hospital IT, microbiology, and security.

item.title: China scrubs its air before world leaders converge in Beijing
item.dc:creator: isenqz

item.title: US job growth is picking up.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Private payroll firm ADP says 230,000 jobs were created in October, up from 225,000 in the previous month. This beat an estimate of 220,000 by economists surveyed by Bloomberg, a good sign for the official jobs tally that will be released on Friday.

item.title: Sugary drinks will be more expensive in Berkeley.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The California city is the first in the US to levy a tax on soda—a cent for every ounce—after two-thirds of residents voted in favor of the move, which the drinks industry fought. A similar measure was on the ballot in San Francisco, but it didn't pass.

item.title: The Brits are going back to Iraq.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Eight years after assisting in the takedown of Saddam Hussein, the UK military is retuning to Iraq to help local forces trying to stop the advance of Islamic State militants. "We are going to be stepping up our training effort," UK Defense Secretary Michael Fallon told the BBC. "I can't give you precise numbers."

item.title: A Japanese company offers lunch delivery with a view.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: For prices starting at ¥30,000 ($263), a company called Platinum Lunch will send a professional female model or actresses to the office to deliver an afternoon meal from a Tokyo restaurant. Customers are not simply paying for the eye-candy: The delivery women will also explain the components of the meal and set the table.

item.title: The World Health Organization picks a new Ebola boss.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Dr. Matshidiso Rebecca Moeti will replace Luis Gomes Sambo, who has been the WHO's Africa director since 2005. The move follows complaints about the international body's response to the Ebola crisis, which has killed 5,000 people. Moeti said her priorities will be to "improve the support for health systems in Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In related news, Obama just asked for $6.2 billion to fight Ebola.

item.title: A vaccine-resistant strain of polio is out there.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Back in 2010, 445 people in the Congo were infected with polio, and almost half died. Initially the outbreak was blamed on lapses in vaccination, but now French scientists say it was partly caused by a new strain of the disease that has evolved to resist current vaccines.

item.title: Amazon gets closer to instant deliveries.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The internet retailer is testing the use of the taxi app Flywheel (paywall) to deliver packages in San Francisco and Los Angeles in just an hour, for an extra $5 fee. Amazon is also bringing same-day shipping to Toronto and Vancouver.

item.title: Elon Musk and Tesla beat the Street.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Investors were expecting (paywall) to see a loss of 1 cent per share on revenues of $889 million, with 7,800 of the company's luxury electric vehicles delivered. Actual results: $932 million in revenue, 7,785 deliveries, and 2 cents per share profit. On the down side, the company cut its 2014 shipment forecast from 35,000 Teslas to 33,000.

item.title: Xiaomi's booming profit is revealed.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Chinese smartphone maker earned 3.46 billion yuan ($566 million) in 2013, up 84% from the year before, according to a document leaked to the Wall Street Journal (paywall). The company is known for its inexpensive devices, but it sells more smartphones in China than anyone.

item.title: Feeding the homeless is illegal in Fort Lauderdale.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Two pastors and a 90-year-old volunteer face 60 days of jail time in the Florida city.

item.title: iPhones get their first real malware.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: WireLurker is being disseminated through a third-party Chinese app store and has been downloaded more than 350,000 times, according to security firm Palo Alto Networks. The malware, which appears to be a work in progress, first infects Mac computers before being spread to iOS devices like the iPhone and iPad.

item.title: The US targets Putin's inner circle.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Prosecutors are investigating whether Gennady Timchenko, who has close connections to state oil company Rosneft, used the US financial system to transfer funds for allegedly corrupt deals (paywall). The investigation is an escalation of pressure on Russian president Vladimir Putin, after the US applied sanctions to Timchenko and others in his circle earlier this year.

item.title: Jay Z buys into bubbly.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The rapper and music mogul purchased Armand de Brignac from Sovereign Brands for an undisclosed sum. The champagne is popular at nightclubs and is known for its oversized metallic bottles.

item.title: China is accused of smuggling ivory on its presidential plane.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The nonprofit Environmental Investigation Agency issued a report claiming that Chinese diplomats bought up huge quantities of illegal ivory during president Xi Jinping’s state visit to Tanzania last year.

item.title: Our outlook on free will is dictated by our bladder.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: If we need to pee we’re less likely to believe we control our own fates.

item.title: Siemens stagnates.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The German engineering conglomerate reported flat fourth-quarter revenue of €20.62 billion ($25.8 billion), and said sales were unlikely to improve next year (paywall).

item.title: Why are there so few women at the World Economic Forum?
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Global warming is causing a shortage of beach sand.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: That’s caused a “sand rush” among miners in the Midwest.

item.title: You should job-hop through your 20s.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: You’ll be happier and will also earn more in your 30s and 40s.

item.title: Europe's central banks in wait-and-see mode.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: As expected, both the European Central Bank and Bank of England kept interest rates at historic lows. Now analysts will parse the banks' announcements for clues on when the UK will raise rates as its economy strengthens, and whether the ECB will unleash more aggressive stimulus measures to keep the monetary union from falling into the abyss.

item.title: The ECB leaves interest rates alone.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The European Central Bank kept interest rates on hold at its meeting today in Frankfurt, as predicted by 55 economists surveyed by Bloomberg. ECB president Mario Draghi said the ECB is willing to inject another one trillion euros into the euro zone to boost the continent's economy.

item.title: Showtime will cut the cord in 2015.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Just like HBO, Showtime announced it will offer its content as a standalone streaming service at some point in 2015, according to CBS CEO Les Moonves. No word on pricing, nor whether it will continue to give Netflix users access to Showtime programs like Dexter and Californication.

item.title: Microsoft Office for the iPad is now free.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: As a way to lure more mobile users, the world's largest software company is no longer requiring an Office 365 subscription to create and edit documents on the iPad. On the iPhone, Microsoft now has dedicated Word, Excel and PowerPoint apps to fend off touch-friendly work apps like Haiku Deck, Quip, Smartsheet, and Evernote.

item.title: Attorney–client confidentiality no longer exists in the UK.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: British spies are allowed to "target the communications of lawyers", court documents show. The case in question—filed in 2012—involves Libyan politician Abdel Hakim Belhaj and Sami al-Saadi suing the former head of Britain's counterintelligence MI6 division (paywall). Belhaj was sent back to Libya in 2004 after being detained in Malaysia—he was then tortured.

item.title: Palestinian farmers can now move through Israel.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Seven years ago, Hamas took control of the Gaza Strip, and Israeli authorities placed strict controls on what goes in and out. Since 2007, Palestinian farmer have been banned from traveling to the West Bank from the strip via Israeli territory. That's no longer the case. 10 tons of cucumbers have made it through. Fish is next.

item.title: US commercial property prices are back at pre-crisis levels.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: American commercial property prices have climbed above the peak reached during the height of the credit bubble, according to data from Moody’s and Real Capital Analytics (paywall). Prices are 0.2% higher than the late 2007 peak, thanks to fierce competition between lenders and historically low interest rates that have driven investors into asset classes boasting higher returns.

item.title: Amazon unveils a talking computer.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The company's 10-inch tall tube called "Echo" is Amazon's answer to Apple's Siri and Google Now. Say "Alexa," then ask a question, and the Echo—which costs $199 or $99 for Prime members and ships in a few weeks on an invite-only basis—responds with information, music, news, weather, and other personal assistant-type tasks.

item.title: Obama reportedly wrote a secret letter to Iran's leader.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Last month, the US president wrote supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei both to stress the benefit of jointly fighting the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria and to move the needle on a nuclear deal, the Wall Street Journal reports. Obama wrote that partnering against ISIL would depend on one condition: Iran's compliance with Western nuclear demands by Nov. 24.

item.title: One reason bears think it's time to sell gold
item.dc:creator: qzroya

item.title: The end of the road for Silk Road 2.0.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Following in its predecessor's footsteps, online hidden marketplace Silk Road 2 was taken down by international law enforcement agencies including the FBI, the Department of Homeland Security and Europol. The FBI arrested its alleged operator, 26-year-old Blake Benthall, in San Francisco and charged him with multiple offenses including conspiring to commit narcotics trafficking. He's facing life in prison.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Congrats to Silk Road 2.0 on being acquired by the FBI!

— Post-Halloween (@ProfJeffJarvis) November 6, 2014

item.title: The US strikes Khorasan for the second time.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The American military said it struck the Khorasan group—which has been linked to al-Qaeda—in northwestern Syria near the Turkish border. Its five targets included several vehicles and buildings in the Syrian city of Sarmada, which US officials said were being used for training and to produce explosives. The US's first strike on the group was in late September.

item.title: A look at the iPhone 6 rocking the global economy.
item.dc:creator: qzroya

item.title: Is Beijing bending on Hong Kong?
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Chinese officials will pay more heed to the "two systems" formula for Hong Kong, sources told the South China Morning Post. The possibility of "appropriate adjustments" to China's Hong Kong policy is a vague but potentially significant development for pro-democracy campaigners, who are struggling with their own internal divisions.

item.title: Mexico cancels a massive Chinese rail deal.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: President Enrique Peña Nieto unexpectedly pulled a $3.7 billion high-speed rail contract that was awarded to a China Railway Construction led-consortium. Mexico's transportation secretary said the reversal was remove any "doubts about the bidding process." Opposition leaders had questioned the consortium's ties to family members of Nieto's ruling party.

item.title: Canary Wharf rejects a Qatari takeover bid.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Songbird Estates, the majority owner of the London financial district, turned down a £2.2 billion ($3.5 billion) offer from the Qatar Investment Authority and US-based Brookfield Property Partners. Two weeks ago, QIA agreed to buy HSBC's Canary Wharf headquarters for about £1.1 billion (paywall).

item.title: Putin defends a Nazi-era pact.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Russia's president said there was nothing wrong with the Soviet Union's treaty with Nazi Germany, which secretly divided control of Poland and other eastern Europe countries between Hitler and Stalin. "Serious research has shown that such methods were part of foreign policy at that time," he said, stoking more fears of Russian aggression in Europe.

item.title: Takata knew it had air bag problems in 2004.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The air-bag maker at the center of Honda's US recall found defects a decade ago (paywall) after conducting secret tests, but Takata executives buried the results, according to the New York Times. The defects have forced more than 17 million car recalls by 10 manufacturers, including a new batch by Honda on Thursday.

item.title: China and Japan agree to disagree on disputed islands.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The two countries acknowledged that "different positions exist" on ownership of several disputed islands in the East China Sea, which has inflamed Sino-Japanese relations. The countries also said they will work to re-establish diplomatic ties and set up mechanisms to manage any future crises.

item.title: US app downloads spike when school lets out.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: Marijuana legalization is largely a guy thing.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Fifty-nine percent of US men are pro-legalization, but only 44% of women feel the same.

item.title: Another big bank settlement on the way.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: A multi-billion-dollar penalty for banks alleged to have manipulated foreign-exchange rates could be announced next week by British and US authorities, according to reports by Reuters, the Wall Street Journal, and others.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Bank of America just cut $400 million from its previously reported profit to cover the cost of the probe, adding to the tens of billions that big banks already set aside for legal defense last quarter.

item.title: Ukraine says Russian tanks are crossing its border.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: 32 tanks, 30 trucks, and lots of trouble. Despite the Sep. 5 ceasefire agreement between Ukraine and pro-Russian separatists, officials in Kyiv say the massing of troops in eastern Ukraine could spark a return to full-scale conflict. Russia is the only country to "respect" the recent elections in the breakaway Donetsk and Luhansk regions, which Kyiv and its allies consider illegal.

item.title: A Chinese bible factory published its 125 millionth copy.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: And this is despite China being an atheist country with officially only 30 million Christians (paywall). The factory—which started printing the religious text in 1987—has produced over 65 million bibles in China's various languages and another 60 million in 90 other languages for export. The Nanjing-based plant the largest bible publisher around.

item.title: Britain will pay its bill to Brussels, eventually.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: After much political posturing, the €2.1 billion ($2.6 billion) in back payments that Britain owes to the EU will be paid after all. But instead of doing it by the original Dec. 1 deadline, Britain now has until Sep. 2015.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The UK and a few other EU members owe more money to the bloc's common budget after revisions to past figures showed their economies performed better than originally estimated.

item.title: What drives Vladimir Putin? Love.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In a speech to the Russian Geographical Society, Russia's leader said: "The meaning of our whole life and existence is love. It is love to the family, to the children, to the motherland. This phenomenon is complicated, it lies at heart of any of our behaviors."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In somewhat related news, a Russian lawmaker has proposed that Russian women be able to mail-order Putin's sperm in exchange for special treatment for bearing his offspring.

item.title: The porn industry is seeking Google's help.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: If you search for "Taylor Swift," Google will show you legal ways to consume her music. The pornography industry, which has been "turned upside down" by piracy, deserves similar consideration, the genre's studios and actors are arguing in their appeal to the internet search giant.

item.title: Loretta Lynch will likely be the next US attorney general.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Unnamed officials tell CNN she has the experience—she's currently the US attorney in Brooklyn, New York, a post she also held during the Clinton administration. An official announcement isn't coming today, however, and probably not in the next few days, either, since president Barack Obama will be away in Asia.

item.title: The US Supreme Court will have another go at Obamacare.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Two years ago, a single vote decided the fate of universal healthcare in the United States. Now comes a Republican-backed challenge to the tax credits that have helped 4 million citizens in 36 states afford insurance. The high court has agreed to hear the case; a ruling is expected by June.

item.title: The German train drivers' strike is ending a little early.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It was supposed to last four days, the longest in German history, but with the 25th anniversary of the collapse of the Berlin Wall coming up this week, the union decided to keep the trains running. The drivers want a 5% pay raise and a 37-hour work week.

item.title: Twitter's roller-coaster ride is fun to watch, unless you're an investor.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: America is sending 1,500 additional troops to Iraq.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: According to the New York Times' Peter Baker, the White House says the soldiers will be there in "a non-combat role to train, advise and assist Iraqi Security Forces." Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel says the troops will be deployed at the request of the Iraqi government.

item.title: Uber wants more money.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: The app-enabled car service is in talks to raise another $1 billion (pdf) in fresh equity, the Financial Times reported. Less than six months ago, Uber raised $1.2 billion at a steep-looking valuation of $17 billion.

item.title: Banks near $1 billion deal over currency manipulation.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The US Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the British Financial Conduct Authority, after an 18-month probe, may reach a settlement as early as next week with seven large banks over their foreign-exchange dealings (paywall). The banks include HSBC, JPMorgan Chase, RBS, and Citigroup. It seems all banks do these days is set aside money for fines from regulators.

item.title: No imminent decision over net neutrality.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The Federal Communications Commissions's new rules over allowing US internet providers to charge for faster access now won't arrive until next year (paywall). The FCC's current thinking leans towards allowing so-called “fast lanes” and an expanded role for itself in regulation of the internet—which is sure to please the many net neutrality activists that crashed the FCC's site back in July.

item.title: Murmurs, winks, and nods at APEC.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: US president Barack Obama and other Asia-Pacific leaders at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit are breaking for lunch in Beijing right about now. China president Xi Jinping is trying to push forward an Asian free-trade agreement, but the US is pushing its own alternative pact, which excludes Beijing. Look out for who's meeting on the sidelines.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A long-awaited meeting between Xi Jinping and Japan's prime minister Shinzo Abe took place on the sidelines, but the awkwardness of their meeting—the first since have been in office—was apparent. Given the animosity between the two countries, neither could afford to look too eager, which led to quite a dour photo op.

item.title: North Korea releases two Americans.
item.dc:creator: zachseward
item.content:encoded: One of the detainees, Kenneth Bae, had been held for two years, accused of plotting a "religious coup d'état" against Pyongyang. The other, Matthew Todd Miller, entered the country under mysterious circumstances earlier this year. James Clapper, the US intelligence director, is accompanying the men back from North Korea.

item.title: Catalonia voted for independence—sort of.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: More than 80% of over 2 million voters opted for independence from Spain in an informal poll, organizers said. Catalan leader Artur Mas said the result now paves the way for an official referendum on independence for the 7.5 million person region, but Spanish justice minister Rafael Catala described the exercise as "useless."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Catalans vote in symbolic referendum on independence in defiance of Madrid http://t.co/wkdwOt8irE

— The Guardian (@guardian) November 9, 2014

#Catalonia: it is referendum day in Catalonia, thousands are going to the polling boots to vote for their future #9N pic.twitter.com/4DiuiFCd9V

— Thomas van Linge (@arabthomness) November 9, 2014

item.title: Mexican protestors attack a presidential palace.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Demonstrators torched the door of president Enrique Pena Nieto’s ceremonial palace in Mexico City after news that the bodies of 43 missing students may have been incinerated. The students’ disappearance is being blamed on police collusion with gangsters, and is putting pressure on Nieto to act on his pledge to clean up organized crime.

item.title: Another Chinese tech company plans its US IPO.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Location-based flirting and hook-up app Momo filed for a $300 million Nasdaq listing in a deal that might value the company at $2 billion. Momo has 60 million active users in China, and has talked of launching an English-language version soon.

item.title: Australians and Brits are having less sex.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: One factor: smartphone-enabled work has entered the bedroom.

item.title: An Indian airplane hit a stray buffalo on the runway.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: There were no injuries reported, other than the unfortunate buffalo.

item.title: Xiaomi's Hugo Barra explains how China's biggest smartphone maker could be India's too
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded:
Xiaomi has broken out of the pack to become China’s biggest smartphone manufacturer, surpassing Samsung and Apple and drawing ahead of domestic rivals like Lenovo. But the company, which is reportedly raising new funds that will give it a $50 billion valuation, isn’t stopping there. Its methodical expansion into southeast Asia and especially India belies a grand ambition to apply its low-margin, high-spec model across the developing world and beyond.

Xiaomi’s India unit—called just Mi, which the company is using as an easier-to-pronounce brand outside of China—is run by Hugo Barra, the former Google executive in charge of Android who raised many industry eyebrows when he defected to Xiaomi last year. The Brazilian-born Barra has been Xiaomi’s point person for  complaints that it has copied Apple’s designs and doesn’t adequately protect customer data. He spoke with Quartz about his admiration for Apple, Xiaomi’s plans to become an e-commerce giant, and why India is the company’s biggest focus outside of mainland China.

Could you tell us your plans for Xiaomi in India?

We are essentially building a company from scratch here. It’s not Xiaomi, it’s not Xiaomi India, it’s Mi India. That is the brand.

But it is a 100% subsidiary of Xiaomi.
