Of course. But I do think of it as building another company and that is an important distinction. It’s not like we are just building a sales office. That is why it was important to spend time finding the right people to run the business here.

Already we have a significant operation here. It involves getting our products from the plants to here and to Flipkart’s warehouses. That in itself is getting fairly complicated. In October, we had [an] entire plane full of products flying down from Hong Kong.

This means we need people here who are paying attention to delivery. We have a customer support operation that is well trained. And we have to focus on building an after-sales network. People from more and more remote areas in India are buying Mi phones now and right now people are having to travel long distances to get to a service centre. Now may be we have a 100 service centres but that is of course nearly not enough to cover the whole country.

Then of course there is the big piece, which is building our own e-commerce business here.

You are going to build your own platform here?

We are China’s third largest e-commerce company. We sell our own products from our own website.

Selling Xiaomi products alone makes you China’s third largest e-commerce company?

Soon the second. We are going to pass JD soon.

So how come you can’t seem to get enough Xiaomi phones to Indian customers who clearly can’t seem to get enough of them?

We are here not to sell phones and dominate. We are here for the long run, and we want to brand ourselves into the fabric of this country. We need to start small, we need to listen, iterate. We probably could sell 10 lakh (1 million) phones at one go—I’m not sure, but we probably could. But just imagine the burden that comes with supporting that many phones all at once. What if there is a problem?

 So we take our time, we ramp up carefully; we take feedback very, very seriously. The whole operation has to scale, we can’t just have a sales spike.

The third part is getting the whole R&D machinery to build and layer all the India-specific services into the Mi experience. There is a lot that we want to do and for that we have to build an R&D team here.

Are you going to one day make Xiaomi products in India?

We will, for sure, write software here. We certainly are also considering the possibility of manufacturing through partners. We don’t make products ourselves. We use Foxconn and others to do the manufacturing for us. We are here for the long run and it might make a lot of sense to be able to make [devices] here.

When you came to India, how many phones were you expecting to sell and how many have you actually ended up selling?

When we came here, we were planning to sell a few thousand phones and we were concerned if that target might be met. In the first two weeks alone, we sold 20,000 phones. The first sale was a bit turbulent because we had some technical issues with Flipkart facing enormous traffic. By the end of October, we will have sold 100,000 phones.

In a market with every possible kind of phone available, both by international and local brands, why do you think there is still this kind of demand for Mi phones?

 I think it’s a combination of factors. First of all we make really good products. The reviews have been amazing. I pay very close attention to reviews and see what we need to do differently and what we are doing well. For Red Mi, the return rate has been less than 1%.

What about Mi3 phones?

It’s a little bit higher because of the SIM tray issue. Because of a logistics goof-up, we couldn’t ship the micro SIM card tray with the phones. Huge mistake. Even so, the return rates were very low, particularly considering the fact that Flipkart has a thirty-day, no-questions-asked return policy.

You don’t have the same returns policy in China?

No, we don’t. There it’s seven days and there are some conditions. We go by the market standards there.

And the third factor of course is the price. We are selling incredibly high-spec devices at very aggressive prices.

Is it true that when the lifecycle of a Xiaomi product begins, you sell it at cost and make money as the cost of components come down?

We sometimes sell it at cost, sometimes a bit above cost and sometimes a bit below cost. We don’t make that many products. If you look at our portfolio, it’s very small. And we really build products that we think can sell for a long time.

To give you an idea, Red Mi and Red Mi S, which are basically the same device—as in the fixed costs are the same for us—have been selling for more than a year. And it’s ramping up. Mi2S is just coming to end of life, two years later.

This is more than what most manufacturers manage to get out…

Much, much more. Very few products, such as the (Samsung) Galaxy S3, manage to survive that long. The Galaxy S3 is still selling. Very few products have that kind of longevity.

What has happened to the Mi3? Have you stopped selling it?

We are shifting the production capacity for Mi3. In India, Mi4 will replace Mi3. Mi3 is a great example of a product where the cost of the materials and components came down fast enough that we were able to bring the prices down. So rather than making very large margins, we are able to keep prices aggressive.

Why did you decide to move to Bangalore?

Because we are here to build Mi India. We are not here to open a sales office or a branch office. India is currently the company’s biggest focus after our domestic market.

What new things are you planning to do in India?

We want to build an Internet platform that is delivered through these devices. We plan to partner with a whole lot of companies and build layers of services into the operating system. Take for instance the process of topping up your phone account or checking the balance. It’s incredibly cumbersome with a majority of the operators. Why isn’t it just integrated into the operating system? Why can’t you just go to the dialer on a phone and just use a tab there to recharge? You shouldn’t need a whole app or a web platform for this. We are going to do a whole lot of these, many of which involves working with startups.

It’s a major undertaking. It’s a task with the same level of complexity as building an operating system.

Truecaller, for instance, is a great example of a company that is not an Indian company but has done really well in India. They have built a whole dialer app. The dialer is a special kind of app. Nobody will let them replace the native dialer with their product. We are going to partner with them and integrate their dialer directly into our dialer. The result would be a native dialer that is much smarter and much more interesting that what is commonly found.

Why do you need your own e-commerce business to sell your products?

Because it becomes an integrated experience. You can log on to our website with the same username and password that you use to set up the Mi account on your phone. You feel like you are home the whole time. If you have a problem, you are talking to our people. You can track your order on our website. We like to have control over the complete experience for a customer.

Flipkart is our partner for life. We will work with them a very long time. Flipkart is one of the world’s foremost e-commerce companies. I put them right up there with Amazon and I put them ahead of most other e-commerce companies anywhere in the world.

Since you moved here, what has been your assessment of India’s tech ecosystem?

I think India is right in the middle of a tech renaissance, where it is definitely transitioning from being an IT outsourcing, business process automation, back-end type of work to a source of innovation.

Where our office is in Bangalore, we are right next to InMobi and a bunch of other exciting companies. It feels like Silicon Valley. Bangalore feels like Silicon Valley in many ways already. India today has the same number of Internet users as China had, say, in 2007-08.

You see that as sort of an inflection point?

Yes, except that India is going to go through that inflection point at a much faster rate. If you compare what the internet and startup scene was in China seven or eight years ago, it doesn’t even begin to compare with how thriving it is in India right now.

In many ways I feel privileged and honoured to be here at this point in time. Because I know that five years down the line, I’ll be able to say, I was there, in 2014!

The amazing thing about India is that India has scale, both as a consumer market and as a source of talent. You have amazing engineering schools. We also have an influx of people coming back. One of my friends from Google is coming back. Flipkart is in fact hiring most of them. It is on a mission to hire from around the world all the Indian engineers who wants to come back and they are very successful at it.

One of the things I’m trying to do here is to build bridges with the local startup scene with a couple of things in mind. One of the things is to find companies that are building stuff that we can integrate into our system. We also believe that being part of the ecosystem, being a local, means we should try and help develop it. So we firmly intend to make small, seed investments in companies, alongside, of course, bigger investments. That is a small contribution, but that is also a good way to build friends. We love to have as many friends as we can.

How did the controversy over Mi phones sending data back to Chinese servers affect your business? What are you doing about it?

We take personal data very seriously. They were reports in the media that were both exaggerated and inaccurate in many ways. We have addressed most of the concerns that were raised. I myself wrote a couple of very detailed posts explaining the accurate position.

You will also see more communication from us in coming months about what exactly happens with our servers, and what kind of data is collected or stored and what isn’t.

But as a consequence, are you for instance considering moving some of the servers to India?

So we are in the process of moving most of our servers dealing with our international users to Singapore, which is, from a network perspective, an ideal hub, because Singapore has good connections both to the US as well as to Asia. We use AWS (Amazon Web Service) and they have their data centre in Singapore. We will eventually move most of our backend to Singapore with one goal in mind—performance optimization.

The consequence of that is that it brings some level of confidence in some people.

Does Apple still make the best smartphones in the world, or are competitors like Xiaomi and One Plus One closing the gap?

Well, I’m a huge Apple fan. I’m very biased. I don’t think there is a company in the world today or there will be a company in the world today that operates at such a distance from its rivals. I think Apple is extraordinary.

What are your thoughts on One Plus One?

I really like what they are doing. I really love the One Plus One phone. I love some of the backs [rear phone panels] that they have introduced. I think it’s a beautiful device. The software is not quite my preference, it’s not something I would choose, but I think it’s an extraordinary device.

What other devices are you bringing to India?

RedMi Note is next. We have already brought the power bank. Then we will see. There is the Mi4. And the TV is something we want to do. We have an amazing TV. It’s 4k, 49 inches. It retails for under Rs40,000. I’m not saying this will be the price in India, I’m just converting the price.

item.title: A suicide bombing hits a Nigerian school.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: At least 47 students were killed when a suicide bomber attacked students during a school assembly in the northeastern Nigerian town of Potiskum. Suspicion landed on the Islamist group Boko Haram, whose name means “Western education is forbidden.”

item.title: Soyuz returns to Earth.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Russian spacecraft landed in Kazakhstan after a five-and-a-half-month mission to the International Space Station in part to breed fruit flies. The astronauts on board became famous on social media during their trip for tweeting beautiful imagery of Earth.

item.title: An end to "too big to fail"?
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The world’s 30 biggest and most important banks may be forced to double their capital buffers under a new proposal by the G20's Financial Stability Board. G20 leaders are expected to endorse the proposal later this week, but a public consultation on the rules will run until February, giving lobbyists time to chip away at the measures.

item.title: Western sanctions and cheap oil pummel Russian growth prospects.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Russia's central bank cut the country's GDP growth forecast for 2015 to zero, based on the assumption that sanctions will remain in place and oil will stay at $95 a barrel. The ruble has lost 28% against the dollar so far this year, the second-worst performing currency of 170 monitored by Bloomberg; only Ukraine’s hryvnia has performed worse.

item.title: A mother of six is the new beer mile record holder.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Chris Kimbrough ran four laps and drank four beers in 6 minutes 28.6 seconds.

item.title: Cyborg cockroaches could save your life someday.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Scientists have wired them up with microphones and tweaked them to find human voices in disaster zones.

item.title: World leaders press the flesh in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: An extremely awkward handshake between Chinese president Xi Jinping and Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe marked the first meeting between the two leaders since they took office. Separately, China and South Korea agreed on a free-trade pact, China and Russia expanded their natural gas pact, and the US and China battled for Asia-Pacific influence by pushing their competing multilateral trade deals.

item.title: This is the growth rate of the company that wants to kill work email.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Iran's drone-clone is up in the air.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: US forces in Afghanistan lost a Lockheed Martin RQ-170 Sentinel drone back in Dec. 2011. Earlier this year, in May, Iran unveiled a copy, and promised that it would become operational during the second half of 2014: it just did.

item.title: The Dutch are remembering MH17 victims today.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The international outrage over the July shooting down of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 may have faded, but the Netherlands is holding a national memorial to remember the 283 passengers and 15 crew members killed. Over 1,600 relatives of the dead are attending.

item.title: Vietnam is turning into Asia's smartphone hub.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Rising labor costs in China are pushing tech firms—like Microsoft, LG, Panasonic, and more recently Samsung—to relocate. Vietnam has already exported $19.2 billion worth of mobile phones and phone accessories this year, up 8% year-over-year; that figure will likely be boosted by Samsung's second smartphone plant.

item.title: Canary Islands nudists needn't fear exposure to Ebola.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The arrival of a fishing boat with 19 illegal migrants from Sierra Leone and Guinea on set off an Ebola scare on Maspalomas beach. But health officials have determined none of the migrants was infected by the virus.

item.title: Uber wants another billion.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The $1.2 billion that the car-service (and logistics-busting) company raised earlier this year isn't enough. Bloomberg reports Uber is seeking another $1 billion to accelerate its international expansion. But money won't help overcome the hurdles it faced in countries like Germany and Belgium.

item.title: GoPro is planning to sell an additional $800 million in shares.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Filings on Monday show the company is seeking additional funds for corporate purposes, including possible acquisitions. Investors don't like the news: GoPro's stock fell 5% in pre-market trading.

item.title: London's "Gherkin" has been sold for £726 million.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The iconic 180-meter (590 feet) skyscraper—designed by Norman Foster and long the butt of jokes for its cucumber-like shape—now belongs to Brazilian billionaire Joseph Safra. That Safra recently bought the banana producer Chiquita will no doubt provide fresh fodder for British comics.

item.title: Obama is arguing that the internet should be a public utility.
item.dc:creator: tfernholz
item.content:encoded: The White House has endorsed a plan to treat the internet as a public good—like power, water or telephone services. Obama's call for strong net neutrality will be embraced by internet-freedom advocates and some tech firms, but major service providers bitterly oppose restrictions on their business practices.

item.title: China is being accused of hacking the US Postal System.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The attack occurred in September, according to officials speaking to the Washington Post. The FBI is investigating the breach: it's estimated information pertaining to 800,000 employees was stolen. A US postal system spokesperson says the attacker appeared "not to be interested in identity theft or credit card fraud."

item.title: The US and China will start issuing 10-year visas.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The initial impact may be a bit lopsided, since the number of Chinese visitors to the US has been much stronger than the other way around. The White House said the move could add $85 billion to the US economy and create 440,000 jobs.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_293774" align="alignleft" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: For every $1 you donate to fight Ebola, Google will donate $2.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The matched-donation campaign will stop at $7.5 million, but Google and CEO Larry Page's family foundation will give another $25 million to nonprofits associated with the cause. Two months ago, Bill Gates committed $50 million to fighting the disease. And last month Mark Zuckerberg made a promise for $25 million.

item.title: A hellish stench is keeping Moscow's citizens indoors.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The smell of rotten eggs in parts of the city is said to be the result of a cloud of hydrogen sulphide. Officials from the Emergencies Ministry are blaming a nearby sulfur dioxide processing facility.

item.title: Uganda is planning a new anti-gay law.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A previous law that made homosexuality illegal and punishable with jail time was overturned in August, after international outrage and the suspension of some foreign aid. This time, instead of specifically calling out homosexuality, the law will refer to "unnatural acts."

item.title: Elon Musk pre-announces a new space race.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The SpaceX CEO confirmed reports (paywall) that his company is developing “micro-satellites operating in large formations,” that could provide internet access from the sky. More details are due in a few months.

item.title: A divorce settlement worth nearly $1 billion.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Harold Hamm, CEO of energy giant Continental Resources, must pay his ex-wife $322.7 million by the end of the year and at least $7 million a month after that, in a divorce settlement worth $995.4 million. Mr Hamm is estimated to be worth $14 billion.

item.title: Putin's flirtatious APEC move.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Russian president draped his jacket over the shoulders of Chinese president Xi Jinping's wife—a questionably chivalrous maneuver that was quickly scrubbed by Chinese censors. Beijing also limited access to pollution data showing sub-par air quality in the capital.

item.title: Alibaba smashes its Singles Day record.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The online retailer had sold $8.6 billion of goods by 10pm local time, well over last year’s total. Over 40% of purchases were done on mobile devices. The Nov. 11 shopping holiday, invented by Alibaba, can make or break Chinese online retailers. Quartz's Lily Kuo reported from inside Alibaba's Singles Day war room.

item.title: Two Rothko paintings sell for $76.5 million.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: They belonged to the late Rachel “Bunny” Mellon, heir to the Listerine fortune and wife of philanthropist Paul Mellon. Paintings from the estate collectively fetched $158.7 million at auction (paywall).

item.title: The pope used to work as a nightclub bouncer.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: His other odd jobs included running tests in a chemical lab.

item.title: Koreans are flying to Nevada for quickie divorces.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It’s easier than enduring court-ordered counseling and a three-month waiting period at home.

item.title: Obama argues that the internet should be a public utility.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The White House endorsed a plan to treat the internet like electric power, water and telephone services. The US president’s stance was hailed by internet-freedom advocates and some tech firms; Republican Sen. Ted Cruz called it “Obamacare for the internet.”

item.title: The Sewol ferry captain is sentenced to 36 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Lee Joon-seok was found guilty of gross negligence after his ferry capsized, killing more than 300 school students in April and causing outrage across South Korea. The ferry's chief engineer was found guilty of muder and sentenced to 30 years in prison; 13 other crew members were convicted of criminal abandonment.

item.title: Vodafone raises its full-year outlook.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The world’s second-biggest mobile operator expects full-year core earnings of up to £11.9 billion ($18.9 billion), due to improving demand in Europe and a smaller decline in revenues. Shares in the company rose 4%, leading the FTSE 100 to a 6-week high.

item.title: Google lands its own airport.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The search giant rented out 1,000 acres of Moffett Federal Airfield—which includes several large hangars, two runways, and a golf course—in a deal that will pay NASA $1.16 billion over 60 years.

item.title: How Alibaba's Singles Day exploded over the years.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Republicans disappoint their big-business backers.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Taxing online sales in the US is a contentious issue, and you'd think Republicans would side with brick-and-mortar retailers who want their online competitors to pay sales taxes too. But having just taken complete control of Congress, the party is apparently not in a rush to make it happen (paywall).

item.title: Want a cheap iPhone? Go to Moscow.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Thanks to the collapse of the Russian ruble, an entry-level iPhone 6 starts at just $700, cheaper than in any other European country. Russians usually cross the Finnish border to get cheaper goods, but now iPhones might start being smuggled out of Russia to the rest of the continent.

item.title: Ford is making aluminum pickup trucks.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The F-150—the top-selling US vehicle for the past 37 years—should start reaching car dealerships in the US next month. The switch from steel to aluminum will make the vehicle more fuel-efficient, but it's a big gamble: One in three Fords is an F-150, and the truck accounts for up to 90% of the automaker's profits.

item.title: Pakistan-India tensions don't look as bad as they once did.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Sweden wants Google to pay for news.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A member of the Swedish parliament thinks that because of the way Google indexes the news—and displays snippets of stories—the search company should contribute to news outlets' funding. Last year, Google announced a 60 million euro ($75 million) digital publishing innovation fund for French publishers, and Spain recently adopted a "Google tax."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Last week Germany's biggest publisher, Axel Springer, caved to Google on a similar issue. Springer had insisted the search giant stop publishing snippets from its articles on Google News, so for two weeks, Google stopped. The publisher changed its mind after traffic fell through the floor.

item.title: There's a virus that makes you (a little bit) stupid.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: And it was found by complete accident. Researchers noticed that 44% of the people in an unrelated study on throat microbes had a previously unknown virus. Those same people scored seven to nine points lower on a set of IQ tests. Mice injected with the virus became confused too.

item.title: Russia is going to build eight nuclear reactors for Iran.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The agreement was sealed on Tuesday in Moscow. Four of the reactors will be built on an existing site owned by Russia's state nuclear company, Rosatom. It's a provocative move given that Russia is also one of the countries trying to negotiate a nuclear deal with Iran by Nov. 24.

item.title: Yahoo spends some of its Alibaba cash.
item.dc:creator: johnqz
item.content:encoded: The company paid $640 million in cash for video ad firm BrightRoll. The deal is CEO Marissa Mayer's second-biggest acquisition, and its first since reaping a multibillion-dollar windfall from the Alibaba IPO.

item.title: Japan delays a contentious sales tax hike.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz

item.title: Touchdown, space rock.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Europe’s Rosetta satellite will deploy the Philae probe it’s been holding in its belly for 10 years and billions of miles. Confirmation of the probe's arrival on the comet affectionally known as 67P will come at around 4pm GMT (11 am ET); there's a live stream from European Space Agency mission control.

item.title: The next Pumpkin Spice latte?
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Starbucks has been working on a drink for the past three years that it calls the Chestnut Praline Latte. It’ll be the first new holiday drink the company has launched in five years when it goes on sale today. Early reviews say it’s “extremely sweet—overwhelmingly so.”

item.title: OPEC wants to cut oil production, but it can't.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: chinese-arrivals-in-the-us-in-thousands-chinese-arrivals-in-the-us_chartbuilder
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: The world's top two polluters sign a greenhouse gas pact.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US set a new 2025 emissions-reductions target and China agreed to halt emissions growth by 2030, under a deal signed by Barack Obama and Xi Jinping in Beijing after nine months of secret negotiations. The countries also agreed to a plan to avoid military clashes, and a pact to cut technology tariffs.

item.title: Mali records its second Ebola death.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A nurse who treated a victim of the disease from Guinea has died and the Bamako clinic she worked in has been sealed off. Mali reported its first  Ebola death, a two-year-old girl, late last month. Separately, the number of Ebola cases in the US has returned to zero.

item.title: Alibaba records $9.3 billion of sales in a day.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The final numbers are in, and China’s biggest e-commerce company recorded a monumental increase from the $5.8 billion on last year’s Singles Day. Nearly all the 30,000 merchants on the internet retailer’s platform offered discounts, which explains the 278.5 million packages now in transit through China.

item.title: Five banks are fined over alleged currency manipulation.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: British, Swiss, and US authorities ordered UBS, Citigroup, HSBC, Royal Bank of Scotland, and JPMorgan Chase to pay a total of $3.3 billion to settle an investigation into alleged manipulation of the $5.3 trillion-a-day currency market.

item.title: India’s sterilization death toll climbed.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Thirteen women have now died and 60 are hospitalized after a mass sterilization in the state of Chhattisgarh. A single surgeon performed 83 procedures in six hours at a government-sponsored camp—which is unfortunately nothing new for India’s blood-soaked sterilization program.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_295364" align="aligncenter" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Burberry reports plush profits.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The British luxury brand posted adjusted pre-tax earnings of £152 million ($242 million) in its fiscal first half, up 6% from the same period a year earlier, though it said spending in Russia and China was still weak.

item.title: Google is teaching robots karate.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: What could go wrong?

item.title: Humankind gets its first view from a comet.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: And you can watch the live stream here. The Rosetta orbiter—which has traveled billions of miles over the span of ten years, has successfully landed a probe called Philae on a piece of space rock affectionally known as 67P.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
BREAKING: European Space Agency says it has succeeded in landing a spacecraft on a comet for 1st time.

— The Associated Press (@AP) November 12, 2014

item.title: NATO confirms that the Russians are rolling into Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: "We have seen columns of Russian equipment, primarily Russian tanks, Russian artillery, Russian air defense systems, and Russian combat troops entering into Ukraine," said US general Philip Breedlove, NATO's supreme allied commander in Europe, confirming reports by several other groups.

item.title: Wages just grew faster than inflation in the UK.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It's the first time that has happened in five years, according to the Office for National Statistics. Average wages excluding bonuses grew by 1.3% in September, versus the 1.2% inflation rate. And the Bank of England warns that inflation may fall below 1% during the next six months, putting even more money in the people's pockets.

item.title: Afghanistan's opium production hits a record high.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: An estimated 224,000 hectares are now being used to grow the poppies needed to make the drug, according to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime. That's up 7% compared to last year. Actual opium production is up 17%. Afghanistan produces more than 80% of the world's opium, and cultivation has increased each year since 2010.

item.title: America may ban its "cruel treatment" of prisoners—in some places.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: President Barack Obama is expected to tell officials at the United Nations that the US will no longer subject its prisoners to "cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment”—which falls short of what's technically termed "torture" and is already banned—in some, but not all, foreign lands, according to the New York Times (paywall).

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Obama administration's more restrictive interpretation of where "cruel treatment" is allowed under an international treaty on torture is likely to ban it wherever the US has governmental authority, including the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. But it appears to exclude the “black site” prisons where terrorism suspects were detained during the Bush years, and the military detention camps in Afghanistan and Iraq during wars there.

item.title: Tencent disappoints with its third-quarter numbers.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg were expecting to see 6.1 billion yuan of net income from the other Chinese internet giant (the company behind the popular WeChat messaging service, with 468 million monthly active users); but it delivered only 5.66 billion yuan ($923 million). Revenues rose 28%, but that was the slowest growth seen since 2007.

item.title: The bloody toll of India's sterilization program.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Yet another Chinese hacking reported.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Just two days after the Washington Post reported that Chinese operatives hacked into the United States Postal Service to steal information on 800,000 employees, the paper reports that China hacked the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. This may have made for some awkward conversation during president Barack Obama's visit to China this week.

item.title: Alibaba can tell your spending habits by your bra size.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Goldman Sachs names its new partners.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The investment bank bestowed one of the most sought-after titles in finance on 78 executives, including PR boss and former US treasury aide Jake Siewert (paywall). That brings the total to 467, down from 477 in 2012, as the bank tries to limit the number of partners—who receive a $900,000 base salary—in proportion to its rank and file; the promotion round is the bank's second-smallest in its history (paywall).

item.title: Fifa cleared Qatar (and itself) of corruption.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The global football body’s internal ethics commission dismissed allegations that Qatar paid bribes to host the 2022 World Cup championships. Fifa instead pointed the finger at the English football association with a claim that it had damaged “the image of Fifa and the bidding process” for the 2018 World Cup, which was awarded to Russia.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
But former New York district attorney Michael Garcia, who conducted the investigation, said that Fifa's summary of his findings is "incomplete and erroneous":
Today’s decision by the chairman of the adjudicatory chamber contains numerous materially incomplete and erroneous representations of the facts and conclusions detailed in the investigatory chamber’s report. I intend to appeal this decision to the Fifa Appeal Committee.
Publishing Garcia's report in full is "not legally possible," Fifa says.

item.title: DreamWorks Animation is in talks with Hasbro.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The studio behind the Shrek film franchise is in merger discussions with toymaker Hasbro, according to a report by Deadline. Hasbro has tried to get into the movie business before, with unfortunate results.

item.title: New York singles out Barclays for special treatment.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The state's financial regulator pulled out of a settlement that included the US and UK governments and five other banks so it could pursue a more severe punishment for the British bank, according to Bloomberg. Barclays was noticeably absent (paywall) from yesterday's multibillion-dollar currency-rigging announcement.

item.title: Ebola deaths surpass 5,000.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The rate of new infections is decreasing in Guinea and Liberia, but it still remains high in Sierra Leone, where hundreds of health workers went on strike to demand $100 a week in hazard pay. An estimated 14,000 are infected with the disease.

item.title: A possible comet probe glitch.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The European Space Agency’s Philae craft touched down yesterday, but scientists won't find out until today whether it is properly attached to comet 67P. It may have bounced after its harpoons failed to anchor it to the comet’s surface.

item.title: Taking notes can be detrimental to your memory.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Your brain knows it doesn’t have to remember the things you’ve written down.

item.title: Intel is backing a 13-year-old startup entrepreneur.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: He invented a Braile printer made out of Legos.

item.title: Three Ebola trials get the go-ahead in West Africa.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Medicins Sans Frontieres will test the use of two antiviral drugs and blood from recovered Ebola patients in Guinea and another unconfirmed location, with the aim of increasing patients’ survival rate during the critical first 14 days of infection. More than 14,000 people are estimated to be infected by Ebola and over 5,000 have died.

item.title: Warren Buffett is taking Duracell off P&G's hands.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Berkshire Hathaway will fork over $4.7 billion to buy the battery company from Procter & Gamble, as the household products maker aims to shed slower-growing brands. P&G agreed to inject $1.8 billion in cash into Duracell before the deal's close. Bucking a global shift away from disposable batteries, Buffet said he has "always been impressed by Duracell."

item.title: Warner Music partners with Tencent to distribute music in China.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The company behind the popular chat application WeChat—which boasts 468 million mobile active users—will distribute Warner Music Group’s vast catalog and manage new releases to "all legitimate audio sources" in mainland China. Record labels hope such deals will boost the mere 1% of global sales that came from China in 2013 (paywall), amid rampant piracy.

item.title: Facebook just shortened its terms of service by 70%.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The social networking giant wants people to actually read them instead of just clicking "Agree," following a slew of complaints and lawsuits from users about privacy concerns. "Our goal is to make the information about Facebook as clear as possible," said Facebook's chief privacy officer (paywall).

item.title: Wal-Mart beats the street, but probably not for long.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In Wal-Mart's quarterly earnings, same-store sales rose at US stores for the first time in roughly two years thanks in part to low fuel prices, back-to-school shopping, and a consumer-happy Halloween. The company is banking big on Black Friday (paywall), but continues to struggle with squaring its supercenter-heavy business with the rise of e-commerce.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: "It used to be called Black Friday, then it became Thursday, now it's a week long," said Wal-Mart US chief merchant Duncan Mac Naughton. "Maybe we should just call it November."

item.title: US job hires just hit a six-year high.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: 5.03 million Americans got a new job in Sep., a number that hasn't been seen since Dec. 2007. On the flip side, the number of people who quit their job—2.8 million—hit a five-year high. Last week's jobless claims did increase by 12,000, higher than what economists were expecting, but still near 14-year lows.

item.title: Wal-Mart sells a lot of (not that fresh) food.
item.dc:creator: qzroya

item.title: Amazon and Hachette put down their swords.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The online retail giant struck a confidential multi-year agreement with the publisher that incentivizes it to lower book prices, ending a pricing war that spurred Amazon to freeze pre-orders on Hachette titles. Amazon is trying to persuade the “Big Five” publishers to price all ebooks at $9.99 and fork over a bigger share of sales.

item.title: NATO jets intercept a Russian plane in the Baltics.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Two Dutch F16 jets escorted the Russian transport plane away from Lithuanian and Estonian airspace because it hadn’t reported a flight plan; Russia’s defense ministry pointed out that the plane remained in international airspace. Lithuania is currently hosting a NATO military exercise.

item.title: Halliburton is in merger talks with Baker Hughes.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Discussions between the world’s number two and three oilfield services companies are moving fast, sources told the Wall Street Journal (paywall). The combined company would be a $67 billion juggernaut.

item.title: Standard & Poors says Twitter’s debt is junk.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The ratings firm says the micro-blogging service may not generate positive cash flow until 2016, and rated its bonds a BB-, three grades below investment level. Twitter’s share price fell almost 6% on the news.

item.title: The US is spying on mobile phones from Cessnas.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The federal government is using scanning devices called "dirtboxes" that are installed on small aircraft capable of covering most of the US population, according to the Wall Street Journal (paywall). The devices capture the unique ID numbers of thousands of mobile phones in an indiscriminate dragnet, even when they are switched off.

item.title: NASA created an environmentally-friendly drone.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: If it crashes, the fungus it's made out of continues the circle of life.

item.title: Burkina Faso agrees on a civilian-led government.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A prime minister will be appointed and allowed to form a government ahead of national elections in November 2015, according to an agreement between military, political, and civilian groups. Lt. Col. Isaac Zida seized control on Nov. 1 after longtime president Blaise Compaore was ousted.

item.title: US lighting strikes are going to increase by 50% this century.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A warming climate creates more water vapor, which in turn fuels more explosive thunderstorms, according to a new study.

item.title: Alibaba would like another $8 billion, please.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Chinese e-commerce company, flying high after raising $25 billion in its IPO and setting a new daily sales record on Nov. 11, is planning to sell nearly $8 billion worth of "Yankee" bonds in the United States. With interest rates so low, why not?

item.title: Russia antagonizes Australia
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Russian president Vladimir Putin sent a fleet of warships near the coast of Australia to "provide security" as he prepares to attend the G20 summit in Brisbane this weekend. Australian prime minister Tony Abbott accused Putin of "bullying" behavior as he tries to "recreate the lost glories of Tsarism [and] the Soviet Union." (paywall)

item.title: The Pentagon tries to fix its nukes.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Defense secretary Chuck Hagel says billions of dollars are needed to make emergency alterations to the US nuclear weapons infrastructure. A study discovered blast doors that won't close and reliance on one out-of-date wrench to maintain 450 ballistic missiles.

item.title: The EU accuses Starbucks and the Netherlands of dodgy dealings.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The European Union's antitrust regulator said Starbucks received unlawful aid that allowed it to pay lower taxes. Similar arrangements involving Luxembourg, Ireland, Apple, Amazon, and Fiat, among other companies, are also under investigation.

item.title: The Onion is up for sale.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: No joke: The satirical news site has hired investment bank GCA Savvian to explore possible options, according to Bloomberg. Parent company Onion Inc. also runs the entertainment site A.V. Club, and has been owned by fund manager David Schafer since 2003.

item.title: China's media regulator bans flirting, ghosts, and murder.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Online videos are also banned from showing bewildering array of other content, including one-night stands, extramarital affairs, rape, prostitution, suicide, and "excessive horror," the Hollywood Reporter reports. "Game of Thrones" and Korean soap operas may not have much to show beyond their opening credits.

item.title: Microsoft is now worth more than Exxon Mobil.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz

item.title: Greece—yes, Greece—outperformed the euro zone.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: New figures show that Greece's economy grew by 0.7% in the third quarter, unexpectedly the strongest performance in the euro zone. Euro zone GDP as a whole expanded by 0.2% versus the previous quarter, more or less in line with expectations. Germany eked out 0.1% growth in the quarter, narrowly avoiding recession.

item.title: Obama to announce climate change donation at G20 summit.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That's according to an unnamed senior administration official who spoke to The New York Times (paywall). The $3 billion contribution Obama is expected to unveil will go toward a fund for poor countries, which are expected to be the most affected by climate change.

item.title: US retails sales climbed 0.3% in October—beating expectations.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It's welcome news given September's 0.3% contraction. Part of the reason for October's growth spurt is likely cheap gas, which is putting more money into Americans' pockets. That trend has stuck around this month, which bodes well for retailers in the run-up to the all-important holiday shopping season.

item.title: Japan's new bullet train can hit 500 km/h.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That's equal to 310 mph, or 120 mph faster than the peak speeds of the maglev trains currently in use. Some 2,400 people selected by lottery have been given a chance to demo the new train, which come 2027 should shave one hour off the journey between Tokyo and Nagoya.

item.title: America is throwing $425 million at its supercomputer problem.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The world's fastest supercomputer, Tianhe-2, is located in China and capable of performing at 55 petaflops. The US, looking to return to the top of the rankings, is going to build two supercomputers—Summit and Sierra—capable of hitting 150 petaflops and 100 petaflops, respectively. That's seven times faster than America's current best.

item.title: The US Navy deploys its first laser weapon.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The USS Ponce now has a "laser gun" capable of destroying a drone or a small boat. The ship, which essentially functions as a floating helicopter pad, is currently patrolling oil shipping routes  in the Persian Gulf, where Iran has experimented with the use of drones and "swarming" small boats.

item.title: Farmers in India are using stuffed tigers to scare off elephants.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: And while it looks like they're certainly scaring the monkeys away, some of the elephants don't seem to pay the stuffed animals any mind. The life-size, 1,100 rupee ($17) plush-toy tigers are being used in the Krishnagiri district. One farmer said they've helped him save 1,000 coconuts this season.

item.title: More trouble at Petrobas.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The Brazilian oil giant delayed filing its third-quarter earnings as federal police arrested 18 people (paywall) in a widening corruption probe. Newly re-elected Brazilian president Dilma Rousseff, who chaired Petrobras from 2003 to 2010, promised a wide-ranging investigation that would "change forever the relationship between Brazilian society, the Brazilian state and private companies."

item.title: Obama's email list doesn't come cheap.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The nonprofit, Organizing for Action, is paying more than $1.2 million a year to rent the president's political email list (paywall), which is believed to be the largest ever created. OFA, established by Obama re-election alumni, raised more than $26 million in 2013 and also manages the @barackobama Twitter.

item.title: Hipsters, explained by mathematics.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: A French mathematician has developed a model that helps explain why bearded, cold brew-drinking types dress alike, even though they're all trying to be contrarian. It's because neurons in the brain experience a delay in perceiving what is mainstream, leading to inadvertent synchronization.

item.title: The G20 tries to tackles global growth while chastising Putin.
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
item.content:encoded: Leaders at the summit—whose countries represent 85% of the global economy—will try to to boost GDP by at least 2.1% by 2018. But efforts to enact the Brisbane Action Plan (pdf) were overshadowed by criticism of Russian president Vladimir Putin. Canadian prime minister Stephen Harper said to Putin: "I guess I'll shake your hand, but I have only one thing to say to you: You need to get out of Ukraine."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: World leaders also spent some time cuddling koalas.

item.title: ISIL beheads another hostage.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The group posted a video showing the decapitation of American aid worker Peter Kassig. The man carrying out the killing spoke with a British accent, just days after the UK pledged to take action to combat ISIL jihadists.

item.title: The fastest growing economy in the euro zone? Greece
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz

item.title: An oil services merger discussion turns ugly.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Negotiations between Halliburton and Baker Hughes broke down, as Halliburton warned its smaller rival that it plans to mount a proxy fight to take control at a shareholder meeting in April. Talks between the second-largest and third-largest oil services providers reportedly stalled due to disagreements over price and securing clearance from US anti-trust regulators.

item.title: Japan enters a recession.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The economy posted its second consecutive decline, with GDP unexpectedly shrinking by 1.6% in the third quarter compared with the same period a year ago. Prime minister Shinzo Abe is likely to postpone a planned sales tax increase; his economic adviser said the GDP drop was "shocking" and called for additional economic stimulus measures.

item.title: Christmas is under threat in Japan.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A nationwide butter shortage is threatening the production of cakes and cookies.

item.title: Facebook goes B2B.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The company is experimenting with "Facebook at Work," which would allow colleagues to communicate and collaborate, sources told the Financial Times (paywall). The service would compete with Google Docs and LinkedIn as well as newer companies like Slack.

item.title: The tilde is under threat from emoji.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The 3,000-year-old character (~) should consider rebranding itself "Invisible Man With Twirled Mustache."

item.title: The Hong Kong-Shanghai “through-train” leaves the station.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A link between Shanghai and Hong Kong stock exchanges will give Hong Kong investors direct access to mainland shares for the first time, and vice versa, in a big step for China’s efforts to liberalize its economy. Cross-border share deals will however be subject to numerous restrictions (paywall), and may be hindered by a notorious lack of transparency among Shanghai-listed companies.

item.title: Burkina Faso appoints a new president.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Former foreign minister Michel Kafando became the country's interim president and will be responsible for selecting a prime minister this week. The military seized power from the country's longtime president last month but is in the process of transitioning to civilian rule sometime next year.

item.title: Hong Kong has a man shortage for the middle-aged, and a woman shortage for the young
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: "Corpses" wake up in the morgue from time to time.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: But happily for the coroners, the cases are quite rare.

item.title: Australia and China sign a free-trade pact.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Australian prime minister Tony Abbott and Chinese president Xi Jinping concluded a landmark deal in Canberra, ending more than 10 years of contentious negotiations. New Zealand concluded a similar free trade deal with China in 2008 and has since seen trade double.

item.title: Apple scores a major China payments deal.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Customers can now connect UnionPay, a state-backed payments giant, to their app store accounts, making in-app purchases easier. The agreement could pave the way for the roll-out of Apple Pay in China.

item.title: An upset in Romania's presidential election.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In a surprise victory, the ethnic German Klaus Iohannis took 54.5% of the vote. Many were expecting prime minister Victor Ponta to win, but Romanian expats throughout Europe queued at their local embassies to elect Iohannis, who has promised to eliminate corruption.

item.title: A doctor dies from Ebola in Nebraska.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Martin Salia was being treated at an Omaha hospital after he arrived in the United States on Saturday from Sierra Leone, where he was treating Ebola patients. Salia is the second person to die on US soil from the disease, while the death toll in West Africa stands at over 5,000.

item.title: HSBC is accused of facilitating tax fraud.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Authorities in Brussels say over 1,000 wealthy Belgians used the bank to move billions of dollars to tax havens in Panama and the Virgin Islands. Prosecutors say HSBC "knowingly eased and promoted fiscal fraud," which wouldn't be a first: The bank was slapped with a $1.92-billion fine in 2012 for helping Mexican drug cartels launder money.

item.title: Advanced classes in US schools are disproportionately white and Asian.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Actavis is buying Allergan for $66 billion.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Allergan—known as the Botox manufacturer—will soon become a part of Actavis, and help it pay a lower corporate tax rate (paywall) in the process. The $66-billion cash-and-stock deal still needs to be approved by regulators. And you never know—Valeant might still come in with a higher offer (paywall).

item.title: Halliburton is buying Baker Hughes in a fracking mega-merger.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The $35 billion deal between the world's second- and third-largest oil services firms broke a tense standoff but must now overcome regulatory hurdles, or Halliburton will face a $3.5 billion break-up fee. The combined company will dominate the US hydraulic fracturing sector, which is driving the US oil and gas boom.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This deal, combined with Actavis' $66 billion intent to buy Allergan, marks over $100 billion worth of deals this Monday.

item.title: NATO intercepts another Russian jet.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In what is becoming an increasingly common pattern, NATO jets scrambled after spotting a Russian Su-27 fighter plane flying over international waters near Latvia. A report released last week detailed 40 close calls involving Russian planes in the last eight months, including a near-miss with a Swedish passenger plane.

item.title: Scientists are resurrecting a woolly mammoth.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The plan is to clone a 40,000-year-old frozen specimen named "Buttercup." Its surrogate mother would almost surely die, and it would be destined for an unhappy life in a lab.

item.title: Hong Kong police are dismantling a pro-democracy protest site.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Bailiffs began removing barricades around the Citic Tower in Admiralty, which is at the center of the main pro-democracy protest site that has stood for more than seven weeks. Protest leaders, who voluntarily left the area before the clean-up operation began, said they would not allow the city's three main protest sites to be fully dismantled.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Student leader Joshua Wong nonchalantly texting as barriers removed around him #OccupyHK pic.twitter.com/geCje2pZoE

— Tom Grundy (@tomgrundy) November 18, 2014

item.title: Missouri declares an emergency in Ferguson.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Governor Jay Nixon called in the National Guard ahead of a grand jury decision on the fatal shooting of a black teenager by a white police officer. Major protests are expected if the police officer is not charged with a crime.

item.title: Why Jeff Bezos should (but probably won’t) split Amazon in two.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: Hasbro cancels merger talks with DreamWorks Animation.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The toymaker’s board ended negotiations after less than a week, sources told Reuters. Hasbro never made an official bid for the studio, but its pull-out caused a 14% drop in DreamWorks shares—the largest single-day fall since the company went public in 2004.

item.title: Four Israelis are killed in a Jerusalem synagogue attack.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Two Palestinians armed with guns, knives, and axes stormed

item.title: Palestinian attackers kill five Israelis in Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Two men armed with pistols, knives, and axes entered a synagogue, killing four worshipers, including three rabbis born in the US and one man born in Britain. A fifth victim, a Druze policemen, died from his injuries on Tuesday night after bursting into the synagogue to stop the attack. One of the deadliest attacks in recent years comes amid rising tensions and killings in a dispute over access to a holy site in Jerusalem's Old City.

item.title: EasyJet's annual profit takes off.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Europe's second largest low-cost airline reported a pretax profit of £581 million ($910 million) for the year ending September, up 21.5% from a year earlier. Europe's largest budget carrier Ryanair also raised its full-year profit forecast by 20% this month.

item.title: A solar power company bets on the wind.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Missouri-based solar panel parts maker SunEdison and its partially-owned subsidiary Terraform Power agreed to pay $2.4 billion for privately-held First Wind, creating the world's largest renewable energy company (paywall). SunEdison vowed to continue growth despite the expiration of US clean energy tax credits.

item.title: Uber gets über-creepy.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: An executive suggests digging up dirt on unfriendly journalists, including having a look at their personal lives, families, and Uber travel logs.

item.title: India has 18% of the world's population but 40% of the world's slaves.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Japan's prime minister calls for new elections.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Shinzo Abe said he would dissolve the lower house of parliament on Nov. 21 and delay a planned sales tax increase until 2017, after the country unexpectedly dipped into recession.

item.title: Nokia starts making Android tablets.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Not Nokia's Lumia division, which Microsoft bought earlier this year (and then ditched the Nokia name), but the part of Nokia that's still in Finland making infrastructure equipment. The 7.9-inch "N1" tablet—thinner and lighter than Apple's third generation iPad mini—will be made by Foxconn, launch in early 2015 in China and Europe, and be powered by an Intel processor. Price? $250.

item.title: Italy arrests 40 mafiosi.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: They all have links to the 'Ndrangheta crime syndicate, a group that has an elite class known as "Santa". Along with the arrests, police also recorded parts of the "Santa" initiation ceremony, something that's never been done. One study claims the 'Ndrangheta group was responsible for 3.5% of Italy's 2013 GDP.

item.title: Hong Kong protesters storm the legislature.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Hours after being evicted from a section of their main protest site, pro-democracy demonstrators broke into the legislative council building and clashed with police, who deployed pepper spray and batons to repel them. Police are planning to dismantle the hard-line Mong Kok protest site as early as Thursday.

item.title: The US senate narrowly votes down a pipeline bill.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A bill that would have forced approval of the Keystone XL pipeline, which would pump Canadian tar sand oil to the Gulf of Mexico, was narrowly defeated after senate Republicans and 14 Democrats failed to muster the 60 votes they needed for approval. The vote was a major setback for Democratic senator Mary Landrieu of Louisiana, who favors the pipeline and is facing a tight run-off election.

item.title: Uber sort of apologizes for its creepy threats against journalists.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: CEO Travis Kalanick tweeted out a long stream of quasi-apology text after a top executive suggested digging up dirt on unfriendly journalists. But Quartz’s Gideon Lichfield notes that Kalanick’s attempt at damage control was really “an instruction to other Uber staff” and “a warning about what happens when they step out of line.”

item.title: Janice Dickenson accuses Bill Cosby of sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The iconic model joined a number of women who have accused the famous comedian of drugging and sexually assaulting them, saying that Cosby gave her "a glass of wine and a pill" in 1982 when they met to discuss a role. "The next morning I woke up, and I wasn't wearing my pajamas, and I remember before I passed out that I had been sexually assaulted by this man," she said.

item.title: Philae found organic molecules on its comet.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The discovery could lend strength to the theory that comets provided the raw materials for life on Earth—and perhaps other planets as well.

item.title: The US recalls Takata airbags.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Millions of vehicles containing devices from the world’s second-largest airbag maker will be taken off the road, affecting 10 major car brands. The flawed airbags can explode under certain conditions, and have killed at least five people (paywall).

item.title: Obama's immigration reforms likely include the parents of citizens.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Undocumented mothers and fathers of US citizens will be allowed to avoid deportation under the president's planned changes to immigration rules, according to reports. An announcement is due as soon as Thursday.

item.title: Airline fuel costs are going down, but customer surcharges never do.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: The music business is an oligarchy.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Digital music has democratized opportunities, but 1% of artists earn 77% of the revenue.

item.title: A winter storm blasts the United States.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: All 50 states including Hawaii experienced temperatures below freezing, and more than 60 inches (1.5m) of snow buried the city of Buffalo, killing four people. New York governor Andrew Cuomo declared a state of emergency, and the weather is likely to worsen today.

item.title: Burma shoots down Aung San Suu Kyi's presidential hopes.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The speaker of parliament said the country's restrictive rules for presidential eligibility won't be changed until after the 2015 elections. The Nobel Peace Prize winner received support from US president Barack Obama during his visit last week, but former military leaders have been slow to relinquish power.

item.title: A New York City man ruined his $100-a-month rent deal.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: He tried to get a neighboring building knocked down.

item.title: To feed India's gold habit, Bangladeshis are stashing it on passenger flights.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Three senior Biman airline employees are accused of orchestrating the smuggling of the precious metal into India, where an insatiable appetite for gold is making it the world's largest consumer, and import duties are rising. Officials say they've seized over 1,400 pounds of gold over 15 months. Two others were also arrested in the scheme.

item.title: Target's new CEO delivers.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The US big-box retailer reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings, and CEO Brian Cornell said the holiday shopping season should be even better. (Last year’s was marred by a massive data breach.)

item.title: Xbox One owners in the UK can now order pizza without missing a frag.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Pause "Destiny," snap it to the side of your screen, and procure yourself a pepperoni with extra cheese. No more having to stretch your arm over to your phone or tablet, which are probably right next to you anyway. The new Domino's pizza app is either a sign of how far we've come or how far we've fallen.

item.title: Netflix puts its Bill Cosby special on the back burner.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Fresh rape accusations—and the American comedian's refusal to respond to them and others—have prompted the video streaming service to delay Bill Cosby 77, which was taped on his birthday and due to air Nov. 28. A total of 15 women have now accused Cosby of sexual violence.

item.title: Iceland will jail some of the bankers behind its economic collapse.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Sigurjon Arnason—once the CEO of Landsbanki—was sentenced with one year in jail (nine months suspended) for manipulating markets. His bank and two others collectively racked up $75 billion in debt, then collapsed, plunging the country into a financial crises lasting half a decade. Two others from the bank received shorter sentences.

item.title: Beats may be coming to iOS.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Financial Times (paywall) says that in early 2015 the device maker will push the Beats streaming service, which Apple acquired in August, to every iPhone and iPad, in an aggressive challenge to Spotify. Beats isn’t free, but the price may be cut in half to $5 per month.

item.title: A man with a rifle in his car is arrested outside the White House.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Renae Kapheim, 41, was cuffed after he told uniformed Secret Service agents that someone had told him to drive from Iowa to the residence. Last month the director of the service resigned over multiple presidential security breaches.

item.title: Silicon Valley’s herd culture may be turning on Uber.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Napster, which “broke all the rules and got shut down,” is a cautionary tale.

item.title: Takata prepares to testify.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: An executive from the Japanese airbag maker will join colleagues from Honda and Chrysler in Washington on Thursday to explain its recall process. Earlier this week US regulators demanded a nationwide recall, and the family of a woman killed by a faulty airbag filed suit against Takata and Honda.

item.title: China's falling execution rate remains higher than the rest of the world's together.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Yahoo nabs a Firefox partnership from Google.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Firefox browser, which generates 100 billion searches per year, will use Yahoo as its default search engine from December, replacing Google. Until recently, Firefox’s deal with Google accounted for most of the browser firm’s revenue.

item.title: Russia’s first McDonald’s reopens.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Pushkin Square branch in Moscow had been closed since August, after the government appeared to target the chain in retaliation for Western sanctions. Around half of Russia’s 400 McDonald’s restaurants remain closed due to either “financial” or “hygiene” audits.

item.title: Drink wine if you can’t make the gym.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A glass of red does just as much good for the heart as a vigorous workout.

item.title: Obama waives deportations.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Up to five million undocumented immigrants will be allowed to stay (paywall) in the United States, including the parents of US citizens and people who came to the country as young children, under the US president’s executive order. In a speech from the White House at 8pm local time (1am GMT Friday), Obama is also expected to grant more work visas to foreign graduates who could fill high-tech jobs.

item.title: Alibaba raises another $8 billion.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Chinese e-commerce giant will sell the year’s most sought-after bond issue to renew existing loans and pay for general corporate expenses. The company also raised $25 billion in September in the largest IPO ever.

item.title: A worrying global manufacturing slowdown.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Purchasing managers’ indexes were grim across the board: activity in the euro zone dropped to a 16-month low, missing even the most pessimistic analysts’ forecasts; China’s index touched a 6-month low, dropping to the level that suggests manufacturing stagnation; and Japan also lost some steam.

item.title: China inks its biggest-ever foreign investment deal.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Nigeria signed a $12 billion contract for China Railway Construction to build over 1,400 kilometres (870 miles) of rail along its coast. Earlier this month Mexican authorities awarded and then canceled the Chinese company's contract to build a high-speed rail line because of questions about the bidding process.

item.title: A gun battle erupts at Florida State University.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Three people were wounded after shots were fired at a college library in the early morning hours, and a gunman was shot dead by police after he fired at officers.

item.title: The recorded music revolution will be streamed.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Mike Nichols—director of "The Graduate"—has died.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Husband to ABC news anchor Diane Sawyer, Nichols died suddenly on Wednesday at the age of 83. Born in 1931, the famed director emigrated from Nazi Germany with his family as a child. He studied medicine, but then delved into comedy and film. He's also known for Charlie Wilson's War and The Birdcage.

item.title: Sweden still wants to try Julian Assange for rape.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: "There is no reason to set aside the detention solely because Julian Assange is in an embassy and the detention order cannot be enforced at present for that reason," said a Swedish appeals court. The founder of Wikileaks has been under investigation since Aug. 2010 for alleged sexual assault against two women.

item.title: Thirty nations donate $9.3 billion to the Green Climate Fund.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The fund, based in South Korea, was hoping for $10 billion. America threw $3 billion into the pot, Japan put up $1.5 billion; Germany, France, and the UK are each giving $1 billion; and Sweden committed $500 million. The money is meant to help countries develop cleaner sources of energy and prepare themselves for climate change.

item.title: Goldman Sachs fires two after confidential Fed documents show up in its office.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: One of the firm's bankers—hired in July from the Federal Reserve—allegedly brought the documents. Another employee, who the firm says should have known what was going on but didn't report the situation to his superiors, was also fired. And the Federal Reserve employee who reportedly supplied the documents is also out of a job (paywall).

item.title: Rhinos are being killed in South Africa at a record rate.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: More than 1,000 have died at the hands of poachers this year alone. South Africa is home to the world's largest rhinoceros population, but activists say deaths will soon outnumber births if nothing is changed. The animal's horn—incorrectly thought to have medicinal properties—is highly sought after in countries including Vietnam.

item.title: Silvio Berlusconi wants to make movies free for seniors.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Italy's boisterous former prime minister says that if his party returns to power, some of the perks he'll offer the country's elderly population include "free cinema in the afternoons and train journeys during the week." Berlusconi can't run for office himself, though. He's been banned after being convicted of tax fraud.

item.title: Another attempt to seal the Iran nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Monday's deadline is quickly approaching, and despite Britain's foreign secretary and even Obama's former advisor on Iran expecting that a deal won't be made by then, US secretary of state John Kerry is going to give it one more go. The key question is how large Iran wants to make its uranium enrichment program.

item.title: Jim Webb is the US' first official 2016 presidential candidate.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The 68-year-old Democrat, who represented Virginia in the Senate and served as secretary of the navy under Ronald Reagan, has announced that he's forming an exploratory committee to examine his chances.

item.title: Tear gas has been fired into Nigeria's parliament.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Reports say police were trying to stop House of Representatives speaker Aminu Tambuwal from entering the building. Last month, Tambuwal announced his resignation from the ruling PDP party, and his intent to join the opposition. Today's parliamentary session was supposed to be the first meeting since Tambuwal's defection.

item.title: Who's clogging up the tubes?
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Kenya's government finds 12,000 "ghosts" on its payroll.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: After the country started using biometric identification on its civil servants in September, the false names were quickly discovered. An estimated $1 million a month was being lost because of the discrepancy. The names have since been removed, and an investigation has been opened.

item.title: Blackstone bets on Japanese real estate.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The world's largest private equity investor in real estate bought GE Japan's property unit, which manages over 1,000 apartments in 200 properties, for more than 190 billion yen ($1.6 billion). Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe's promise to end deflation, coupled with a weakening yen, has increased the attractiveness of Japanese properties to international investors, apparently despite a surprise recession this week.

item.title: The Federal Reserve begins an internal review.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The reserve bank will examine how it assesses the US’s most systemically important banks, following criticisms it is too deferential towards institutions it supervises, including Goldman Sachs.

item.title: UK reporters take the police to court.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The National Union of Journalists filed a lawsuit against London’s Metropolitan Police and the British Home Office after it obtained evidence that police spent years spying on reporters, the AP reports. Records held by police allegedly included details of one journalist’s partner and even family members’ medical histories.

item.title: Another gun-toter outside the White House.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A 23-year-old woman carrying an unregistered handgun was arrested outside the US president Barack Obama’s residence, just 15 minutes after he finished his immigration reform speech. She is the second person to be arrested for carrying arms near the White House this week.

item.title: The world’s oldest basketball court is in France.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It has iron pillars running through the middle.

item.title: Don’t rake those leaves off your garden.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Leaving them au naturel is far better for wildlife.

item.title: Activist investor Dan Loeb gets his Sotheby's scalp.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: The auction house announced that chief executive William Ruprecht will step down, just six months after Loeb joined the company's board. Loeb, of hedge fund Third Point Management, argued Ruprecht's management lacked "innovation and creativity," and the market seems to agree—Sotheby's stock increased nearly 8% in after hours trading after the announcement.

item.title: Most unauthorized immigrants to the US have been there since before we had Facebook.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: China cuts its rates for the first time in over two years.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Slowing domestic growth and a struggling property market led the People's Bank of China to reduce deposit and lending rates by 25 basis points and 40 basis points, respectively. The cuts are expected to boost economic activity in China and crude oil prices and mining shares jumped.

item.title: Japan’s prime minister dissolves parliament two years early.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Shinzo Abe paved the way for mid-December elections, seeking to bolster popular backing to push ahead with his economic reforms. The act may have been unnecessary; a Kyodo news agency poll found 63% of people don’t understand the need for a snap election.

item.title: The UK shifts right.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: UKIP, a political party that wants the UK to curb immigration and leave the European Union, won its second seat in parliament. The new MP is the old MP—the vote was triggered when Mark Reckless, the incumbent in a seat in Kent, defected to UKIP from prime minister David Cameron’s Conservative party.

item.title: Rolls-Royce wins a $5 billion contract from Delta.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The British industrial group will make engines for 50 new Airbus planes. It was welcome news for Rolls-Royce, which recently announced 2,600 job cuts following a series of profit warnings.
