item.title: President Obama was on a restaurant review TV show in 2001.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Here’s a video of the then-state senator’s cameo on “Check, Please!”

item.title: A former US diplomat may have been leaking secrets to Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Robin Raphel, assistant secretary of state for South Asian affairs during the Clinton administration, had her home raided last month (paywall) by the FBI. They discovered confidential documents. The raid was ordered after a conversation between Raphel and a Pakastani diplomat was intercepted. She has not been charged with a crime.

item.title: China cut its lending rate for the first time in over two years.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It hasn't been 7.5% since the late 90s (paywall), but its a move the Chinese Central Bank had to make in order to boost its sluggish economy. Most countries would so anything for 7.3% GDP increase, but 2013's growth was the slowest in half a decade.

item.title: Sotheby's CEO is leaving.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: William Ruprecht, who brought Sotheby's auctions to China, the Middle East, and the internet during his 14-year tenure as chief executive, is going to step aside. The details haven't been ironed out, with a successor not yet named and a timeline for the transition not disclosed.

item.title: People who drink to excess usually are not alcoholics.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A US government study involving nearly 140,000 Americans (paywall) has come to the conclusion that nine out of 10 heavy drinkers (defined as those who have four to five drinks in one sitting) aren't addicted to the sauce. Apparently, they just like getting drunk.

item.title: Now in motion on the ocean: the world's biggest ship.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Pieter Schelte left South Korea earlier this week and is expected to dock next month at the Rotterdam Port in the Netherlands so construction can be completed. The ship is 1,253 feet long—the height of New York's Empire State Building—and will cost an estimated $3 billion once it's finished.

item.title: Amazon is getting into the travel business.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A new service—appropriately called "Amazon Travel"—will let customers book stays at hotels and resorts in a handful of US cities, according to Skift. The three hoteliers Skift interviewed said Amazon will give them access to its customer database, and that their properties were selected for the service based on their TripAdvisor ratings.

item.title: Republicans sue Obama over Obamacare.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: They've aired their grievances with the president's signature healthcare measure for months—to which he replied, "So sue me!"—and that's exactly what just happened. The suit calls into question the $175 billion given to insurance companies and the delays in the deadline for when large companies need to offer insurance.

item.title: A teenage capitalist faces school suspension.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Tommie Rose, 15, bought junk food in bulk and resold it to his peers. He was so profitable—making nearly $22,000 before he was shut down—that he even hired two employees to help. "We admire this pupil's entrepreneurship," said the school's head teacher, whose biggest concern was that the business was trafficking in unhealthy food.

item.title: Could the EU break up Google?
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The Financial Times reports that a draft motion from the European Parliament (paywall) calls for Google to unbundle its search operation from other businesses to satisfy antitrust concerns. This reflects a hardening of the EU's stance in its long-running tussle with Google over the power it wields on the web.

item.title: The FCC gets a wireless windfall.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: An auction of wireless spectrum licenses by the Federal Communications Commission has collected $34 billion in bids (paywall), making it the most lucrative auction of its kind ever. Analysts had forecast less than half that amount. Bidders include US giants like AT&T and Verizon and broadcaster Dish, which wants to start a mobile phone service.

item.title: Even Boris can't escape US taxes.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The mayor of London, Boris Johnson, denounced the “incredible doctrine of global taxation” after the IRS demanded he pay a capital-gains tax on the sale of his London home (paywall). Johnson was born in the US and never relinquished US citizenship, despite its obligation to pay taxes on global assets.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Johnson has refused to hand over the money—ironic, as the US embassy in London has long refused to pay off its £7 million ($11 million) congestion-charge bill.

item.title: UN pushes back Ebola targets.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The United Nations had previously set a goal of safely burying 70% of the dead and treating 70% of the sick caused the Ebola outbreak in West Africa by Dec. 1, but now the UN and WHO only hope the disease can be contained by the middle of 2015. “The international response is outpaced by this Ebola spread,” Ban Ki-moon said, warning of its potential to devastate Mali next.

item.title: As France's economy gets weaker, the Christmas lights come earlier...
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz

item.title: Portugal's former prime minister is arrested.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Jose Socrates has been arrested by police as part of an investigation into money-laundering and bribery. Three others have also been detained. Socrates led the government from 2005 to 2011, when he was ousted by the public following the country's bailout during the financial crisis. The current government is also caught up in a separate corruption scandal.

item.title: Foreigners on both sides in Syria.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Many key members of ISIL are known to be foreigners, such as the Britons who have been executing hostages. Ex-soldiers are also traveling to the region to fight against the jihadists on behalf of the Kurds as mercenaries. The Guardian reports that two British former infantrymen are in Syria, having been recruited by an American via Facebook for a group called Lions of Rojava, which urges people to come “send terrorists to hell and save humanity.”

item.title: Iran: Deal or no deal?
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Probably no deal—negotiators say it's looking unlikely that the US, UK, China, France, Russia, and Germany can reach an agreement with Iran over its nuclear program by a Monday deadline. US secretary of state John Kerry has met his Iranian counterpart, Mohammad Javad Zarif, four times in three days but says there are still "serious gaps" between the two sides.

item.title: A new chapter in the Arab Spring.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Tunisians are voting for their first elected president since the 2011 revolution that kickstarted a wave of revolts across the region. Almost 30 candidates are running. In October, the secular Nidaa Tounes party won the most seats in parliament, beating the main Islamists, and its leader is one of the frontrunners.

item.title: The world’s most sophisticated malware is on the loose.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Cyber security company Symantec said the spying software called Regin was almost certainly created by a nation state, with the United States and Israel the most likely culprits. The sophisticated “back door-type Trojan” has been primarily used against government and business targets in Russia and Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Disney theme parks are no-fly zones.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The company took advantage of post-9/11 anti-terror bills to rid its skies of pesky aerial banner ads.

item.title: How to make a stress-free Thanksgiving pie crust:
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Go ahead and make twice as much dough.

item.title: US regulators take the wind out of commercial drones.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Federal Aviation Administration is expected to rule that operators must hold a license and fly during daylight, below 400ft (122 meters), and within sight of the person at the controls, according to the Wall Street Journal. Those rules would ban many commercial drone applications, including pipeline inspections, crop monitoring, and package deliveries.

item.title: Languages leave traces on your brain.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Our neural matter can bear the imprint of languages we never learned.

item.title: Samsung may sack its mobile boss.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The South Korean electronics firm may hand over control of its struggling smartphone unitto the executive who runs its home-appliance and TV business, replacing co-CEO and mobile head J.K. Shin, who oversaw the dramatic ascent and equally steep decline of Samsung’s smartphone profits, the Wall Street Journal reports (paywall).

item.title: Putin says he'll stay in power for another 10 years
item.dc:creator: jasonqz

item.title: Yik Yak is the latest messaging app to hit the jackpot.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The location-based anonymous messaging app secured a $62 million investment round led by Sequoia, valuing the start-up in the low hundreds of millions of dollars. Yik Yak, especially popular on US university campuses, has been controversial as a medium for bullying and violent threats; one university called it “a platform for hate speech.”

item.title: The average Gmail user gets five emails a day.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Which is why Google employees didn’t understand the service’s simpler redesign.

item.title: Another Chinese rate cut may be in the works.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Reuters is reporting China's central bank could slash interest rates again, citing "sources involved in policy-making." The bank unexpectedly cut rates for the first time in two years last week, which some see as a sign of panic at a slowing economy.

item.title: Talks over Iran's nuclear program have been extended.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A deal was supposed to be reached today, but that didn't happen, as Obama's former advisor to Iran predicted. According to the British foreign secretary, Iran and Western powers will now have an additional seven months to hammer out the details.

item.title: Tesla is talking to its direct competitor to develop a new battery.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: CEO Elon Musk says he is in negotiations with BMW to possibly collaborate on battery technology and light-weight carbon-fiber body parts. This is while Tesla seeks a piece of the market held by BMW’s successful entry-level Series 3.

item.title: An American trade deal with India is expected in a few days.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Thanks to all the face-to-face time prime minister Narendra Modi and US president Barack Obama have been having recently—with even more expected in January—the two world leaders are said to be close to reaching a deal on both food stocks and several aspects of a proposed WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement.

item.title: Apple will donate some of its Black Friday and Cyber Monday income.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: An exact percentage hasn't been revealed yet, but the money in question will go to the Global Fund to fight AIDS. The company will create a special section in its online App Store for the sale of 25 applications: all the profits generated there will be donated.

item.title: NASA wants to make some money on the side by mining astroids.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It costs upwards of a quarter million dollars to fetch the minerals and metals that make up an astroid, but two companies say they're willing to make space mining a profitable venture. One in particular—Deep Space Industries—have spacecraft known as "FireFlies" to do reconnaissance work, "Dragonflys" to snatch astroids, and "Harvesters" to do the actual mining itself.

item.title: Chuck Hagel resigns.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Hagel—Barack Obama’s defense secretary since Feb. 2013—served with “class and integrity,” according to the US president, but now it’s time for “a different kind of focus,” said an unnamed White House official. That’s probably the polite way of saying the White House wants someone more forceful as tensions rise in the Middle East and eastern Europe. Some say he was doomed from the start.

item.title: Europe will vote on whether or not to break up Google on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Even if they decide to go through with it, the European Commission has no authority to force Google to comply. Joaquin Almunia, the former EU competition commissioner, spent four years investigating Google at the request of Microsoft.

item.title: A 1,300-year-old book of spells has yielded "cures" and curiosities.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Researchers have translated a 20-page Egyptian codex, written in Coptic, that offers advice on—among other things—how to make someone love you, how to exorcise a demon, and how to cure diseases. It also contains evidence of extinct religions.

item.title: Cheap oil and Western sanctions are costing Russia $140 billion a year.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The country's finance minister says the annual hit from sanctions is $40 billion a year, and the collapse of oil prices is contributing another $100 billion. Russia and Venezuela are planning to talk tomorrow—before OPEC's Thursday meeting—to discuss reducing their oil output.

item.title: Saudi Arabia points the finger at ISIL.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The killing of seven Shia Muslims on Nov. 3 may be the first time the Islamic State has been involved in an attack in the country. The interior ministry said the attackers—of whom it arrested four suspects—got their orders from abroad.

item.title: Hong Kong police clashed with protesters.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Bailiffs cleared barricades from a major intersection in the city’s Mong Kok neighborhood, triggering scuffles between pro-democracy activists and police. At least a dozen people were arrested (paywall), including a pro-democracy lawmaker, and more clearances are scheduled in the area tomorrow.

item.title: Bank of China moves into Australia.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The bank said it would double the number of loans it makes to Australian homeowners, including a growing number of Chinese buyers, in the next two years, as it seeks overseas investments to counter China’s slowing real estate market.

item.title: The US is exacerbating a shortage of Ebola gear.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: US health officials are stockpiling $2.7 million worth protective suits, which are becoming so scarce that West African countries battling an outbreak of the virus are struggling to secure their own, according to the Wall Street Journal (paywall).

item.title: Lego had modern parenting advice 40 years ago.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Some boys like dollhouses and some girls prefer spaceships.

item.title: Powerful women are more prone to depression than powerful men.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Gender discrimination doesn’t stop when you reach the top.

item.title: It's not just Ferguson: US cops who kill are rarely indicted.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Twitter's CFO has a "DM fail."
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Anthony Noto publicly tweeted details of an apparent plan to buy an unnamed company, in the mistaken belief he was sending someone a private direct message (DM). The gaffe adds weight to the criticism that Twitter is confusing to use.

item.title: Tencent signs a deal to stream HBO in China.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The tech giant that owns WeChat will distribute the Time Warner unit’s content (paywall) on its various online platforms, though shows will be subject to a strict government ban on explicit sex and violence. Earlier this year, Tencent’s rival Alibaba teamed up with Lions Gate, and Xiaomi is investing $1 billion in creating its own content.

item.title: More calorie-counting for American diners.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US Food and Drug Administration is expected to increase the number of businesses that must display the number of calories (paywall) in each food serving, including vending machines and movie theaters. Alcoholic drinks at restaurants will also require calorie counts.

item.title: A rescue operation for hundreds of Europe-bound migrants.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Five ships have been launched to potentially evacuate a freighter thought to be carrying between 500 and 700 people, which became stranded 30 miles (48 km) from the Greek island of Crete. The nationalities, port of departure, and destination of those on board are currently unknown.

item.title: Americans drink more craft beer than Budweiser.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Nearly half of young people have never even tried a Bud.

item.title: France won't deliver a warship to Russia.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: After previously equivocal statements about when, or whether, it would deliver the first of two advanced "Mistral" warships to Russia, French president François Hollande finally announced that the handover would be postponed "until further notice." The €1.1 billion ($1.4 billion) deal was signed in 2011, but Russia's role in the unrest in Ukraine "does not allow" France to deliver the assault ships, Hollande said.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Le président @fhollande considère que la situation en Ukraine ne permet toujours pas la livraison du premier #Mistral pic.twitter.com/lTaawd9jSg

— Élysée (@Elysee) November 25, 2014

item.title: You too can own a Nobel Peace Prize—for around $3.5 million.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: James Watson's medal for co-discovering the structure of DNA is going up for auction on Dec. 4 in New York at Christie's. Watson, now 86, will donate some of his winnings to charities that support scientific research—useful, considering how America is cutting back on basic research.

item.title: The OECD has some bad news for Europe and Japan.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In its latest forecast, the organization says euro-zone inflation in the next two years will be lower than what the European Commission recently predicted, and way below the European Central Bank's 2% target. For Japan, the OECD halved its forecast for 2014 GDP growth and cut the 2015 outlook too.

item.title: America's economy surprises everyone.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Investors were expecting the Commerce Department to revise third-quarter GDP growth downwards, but instead the new figure came in higher, at 3.9%. Consumer spending was also revised, to a 2.2% bump instead of 1.8%.

item.title: Banco Santander gets a new boss.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Javier Marín is out after less than two years as CEO of Europe's largest lender. Jose Antonio Álvarez, who has been the bank's finance chief for the last decade, will take his place (paywall) on Jan. 1. It's the first big move by Ana Botín, who took over from her father as executive chairman in September.

item.title: Ferguson prepares for another tense night.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The governor of Missouri sent in 1,500 more National Guard troops after riots on Monday night resulted in officers arresting more than 80 people. Darren Wilson, whom a grand jury decided on Monday not to indict for shooting Michael Brown, said he has a "clean conscience" because he followed his training. A federal investigation is ongoing.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The New York Times reports (paywall) that the grand jury "faced a mass of evidence, much of it conflicting":
The grand jurors in the Wilson case met in a St. Louis County courthouse on 25 separate days. They heard 70 hours of testimony from roughly 60 witnesses. And they confronted a jumble of forensics reports, police radio logs, medical documents and tapes of F. B. I interviews with bystanders. ... Prosecutors did not seem to shy from pointing out discrepancies between multiple interviews of a single witness, or even at some points exploring the past criminal history of some witnesses, including Mr. Johnson, Mr. Brown’s friend. Several witnesses were asked if they felt pressure to conform to a certain story line, or if they felt fear if their recollections differed from the popular narrative.

BREAKING: "No justice, no peace!" #Chicago protesters head north on MLK Dr. #Ferguson @WBEZ pic.twitter.com/NzeU5l7uEI

— RadicalMedia_ (@UnToldCarlisle) November 25, 2014

Protesters march up Seventh Avenue in New York City, following the grand jury decision in Ferguson. pic.twitter.com/ZOtGC3TU3A

— NYT National News (@NYTNational) November 25, 2014

item.title: Sony is giving up on the smartphone race.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Instead of chasing market share and striving to become the world's third largest mobile phone maker—its previously intended goal—the Japanese company is now planning (paywall) to "make the business profitable even if we face declines in sales by 20% or 30%."

item.title: Apple briefly hits $700 billion.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It's the first US company ever to reach that valuation, and has doubled its market cap since Tim Cook formally became CEO three years ago. However, Apple is worth less than 4% of the S&P 500, compared to 5% for IBM and 6% for Microsoft at their peaks. Apple soon fell back below $700 billion.

item.title: Hewlett-Packard's numbers slip before the split.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Earnings fell 2.7% to $2.01 billion, in line with expectations, as revenues fell in almost every business segment. "Turnarounds aren't linear," said CEO Meg Whitman, who is breaking the company into half.

item.title: The US is politically polarized over Ferguson, as it is over everything.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: This Twitter map shows how people with different political and racial backgrounds ignore each other.

item.title: Nigeria caves to the power of oil prices.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: After spending billions of dollars in the past year to defend its currency, the naira, the country devalued it and raised interest rates. Falling oil prices have battered Africa’s largest economy, which analysts say needs oil at $126 to balance its budget; Brent crude on Tuesday fell to $78.33.

item.title: Uber is closing in on a $35-$40 billion valuation.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The car-booking service is near to securing a new funding round worth over $1 billion, sources told Bloomberg News, in a deal that would double Uber's June valuation of $17 billion.

item.title: Netflix sues a former exec for corruption.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The video streaming company accused former IT operations chief Mike Kail of secretly pocketing kick-backs worth $450,000 to $560,000, Re/code reports. Kail left Netflix in August to become Yahoo's chief information officer.

item.title: Hong Kong police clear a major protest site.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Student leaders Joshua Wong and Lester Shum were among the more than 100 pro-democracy activists who were arrested as bailiffs and police cleared a protest camp in the city’s Mong Kok neighborhood. Activists vowed to return to the area soon, or find new sites.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Joshua Wong escaped Civic Party member Ken Tsang's fate, as police took him away in broad daylight. https://twitter.com/joannachiu/status/537445808908419072

Photo of #OccupyHK student leader Joshua Wong getting arrested in Mong Kok, from @Scholarismhk facebook page #UMHK pic.twitter.com/FbTBmjBYdO

— Joanna Chiu 赵淇欣 (@joannachiu) November 26, 2014

item.title: More protests in Missouri and across the United States.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: At least 44 people were arrested in Ferguson after rioters broke city hall windows and overturned a police car, in a second night of occasionally violent protests. Protests against the fatal police shooting of Michael Brown also took place in some 170 cities nationwide, including major demonstrations that shut down highways and bridges in New York City.

item.title: The presidentially-pardoned turkey is always white.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It’s not racism—it’s the influence of the industrial turkey lobby.

item.title: Kids will eat well without being asked.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Tactics include quieter cafeterias and having teachers eat with students.

item.title: Is Twitter shopping for Shots?
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The social networking service has talked with the owners of the Justin Bieber-backed selfie sharing app Shots, CNBC reports. Yesterday Twitter’s CFO accidentally tweeted details of a potential acquisition.

item.title: Europe is “elderly and haggard.”
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The pope says the continent needs a new sense of purpose (paywall).

item.title: Regulators open a new front against HSBC.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US justice department is investigating whether a trader at the bank leaked confidential client information to a hedge fund, according to the Wall Street Journal (paywall). HSBC, which was hit with a $618 million fine for manipulating foreign-exchange rates earlier this month, allegedly flagged news of a big currency deal it was arranging for one of its clients.

item.title: Samsung offloads its chemicals and defense units.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The sprawling South Korean company will sell its stakes in Samsung General Chemicals and Samsung Techwin for 1.9 trillion won ($1.7 billion) (paywall) to rival conglomerate Hanwha. Samsung has been simplifying its holdings as heir apparent Lee Jae-yong consolidates control.

item.title: Ebola workers in Sierra Leone dumped bodies in front of a hospital.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: They were protesting because they didn’t receive hazard pay for the past seven weeks.

item.title: Kim Dotcom says he's broke.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Authorities have "managed to drain my resources and dehydrate me," the infamous founder of the file-sharing website Megaupload said. Dotcom, who is fighting extradition to the US on charges of copyright infringement, says he has spent $10 million on legal costs since his arrest in New Zealand in 2012. His new company, Mega, is valued at $210 million.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Afternoon before the bail hearing: In the pool with the kids :-) pic.twitter.com/4W4nzoHPZG

— Kim Dotcom (@KimDotcom) November 26, 2014

I guess I'm going back to court soon to get some of my assets unfrozen for legal fees and living expenses. To be continued...

— Kim Dotcom (@KimDotcom) November 26, 2014

item.title: HSBC and Goldman Sachs are accused of metal price fixing.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The two companies, along with BASF and Standard Bank, have been sued by a US jeweler called Modern Settings for "front running"—sharing information about a client's intent to purchase goods, in this case platinum and palladium, to make a profit. Modern Settings says this has been going on since 2007.

item.title: The EU unveils yet another plan to kick-start its economy.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A €315 billion ($394 billion) investment fund will draw €16 billion from the EU's budget, €5 billion from the European Investment Bank, and then the rest—as if by magic—will be conjured from as-yet unidentified investors. The fund will target investments in much-needed infrastructure improvements: transportation, internet, and energy.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Europe investment plan - where the money comes from http://t.co/2rpVZdAWPJ @ReutersGraphics #Juncker #junckerplan pic.twitter.com/pstgse1Eka

— ReutersBreakingviews (@Breakingviews) November 26, 2014

item.title: China drafts its first domestic violence law.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Spousal abuse is being defined for the first time—critical in a country where state media reports that 40% of women in a relationship have been abused. If parliament passes the legislation, police will have to respond to domestic abuse complaints, and courts will have to issue restraining orders within two days of an incident.

item.title: Germany is creating a quota for women in company boardrooms.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Starting in 2016, a minimum of 30% of the country's biggest companies' supervisory boards need to be female. Similar legislation has already been passed in Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, and several other countries. "This law is an important step for equality because it will initiate cultural change in the workplace," said German chancellor Angela Merkel.

item.title: Europe wants the right to be forgotten to apply globally.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Because right now, when you submit a request to have a link scrubbed from Google's European search engine, the American company complies, but not for search engines outside the continent. An EU working group wants this to change—it's addressed in a set of guidelines the group will publish this week.

item.title: A top NATO general issues a warning about that Russian militarism.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: At an event in Kyiv, US Air Force General Philip Breedlove pointed out the strategic importance of Crimea, saying that Russian military assets on the peninsula would have an affect on "almost the entire Black Sea." Breedlove also said that Russian troops were helping train separatists.

item.title: GoPro has its eye on drones.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The company is planning to launch multi-rotor helicopters priced between $500 and $1,000 that feature its high-definition cameras, according to the Wall Street Journal (paywall). It's no surprise the company wants to go vertical: Drones are shaping up to be a hot seller this holiday season, and many top models are designed to hold GoPro cameras.

item.title: Gun sales expected to sky rocket for Black Friday.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The National Instant Criminal Background Check System—run by America's FBI—says it screens roughly 40 people looking to buy a gun every minute. But later this week, when people splurge on cheap televisions and other heavily discounted goods, that number goes up to nearly two checks every second or 120 a minute.

item.title: The uranium market has been giving investors some glowing returns
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: A step closer to an Ebola vaccine.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: For the first time a human trial showed a vaccine made by GlaxoSmithKline is safe and will likely be effective in fighting the virus. The vaccine could be available in West Africa in about six months, and other vaccines are being tested in Mali, Switzerland, and the UK.

item.title: More clashes at the Hong Kong protests.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Student demonstrators threatened to target government buildings (paywall) if police continued to force them from protest camps with pepper spray and batons. Pro-democracy activists also tried to occupy smaller streets in the city’s Kowloon district after a major thoroughfare was cleared yesterday.

item.title: Thailand’s elections may be delayed.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The military junta’s finance minister Sommai Phasee said general elections now may not take place until 2016, a year later than previously stated. Martial law will come to an end eventually, Sommai said, but is required at the moment “to deal with security.”

item.title: Microsoft pre-announces an acquisition.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The company prematurely published an incomplete blog post that suggests it is on the verge of acquiring Accompli, a mobile email start-up. The gaffe comes just days after a Twitter executive made a similar blunder.

item.title: Giving thanks makes you healthier.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: You’ll sleep better, exercise more, and feel more optimistic about life.

item.title: Don’t blame tryptophan for your Thanksgiving nap.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Turkey only contains a small quantity of the sleep-inducing amino acid.

item.title: Beijingers may only get to drive every other day.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The pollution-choked city has been test-driving a system to ban cars with license plates ending in odd or even numbers on alternate days, which helped produce rare blue-sky days during the recent APEC summit. Authorities are now looking into making the alternate-day ban permanent.

item.title: Australian cricketer Phillip Hughes dies from an in-game injury.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The batsman was struck on the head on Tuesday, and never regained consciousness. The ball hit Hughes at the base of the skull, an area not well-enough protected by his helmet, sparking conversations about the need to develop better safety gear for the sport.

item.title: Scotland is set to get more power.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The Scottish Parliament should be fully able to set its own bands of income tax and keep all the money raised, according to a commission set up by the UK to strengthen devolution in the country in the aftermath of Scotland voting against independence. Income tax bands and their distribution are currently set by Westminster. The vote should also be given to 16- and 17-year-olds, the commission said.

item.title: The Saudis kibosh oil production cuts.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: OPEC members Iran and Venezuela wanted to pump less oil in order to reverse a steep decline in prices, but Saudi Arabia and the wealthy Gulf states—who are able to ride out the weak prices—blocked the move. “It was a great decision,” said Saudi Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi, as oil prices fell even further.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: US-traded oil, the benchmark used to price shale oil, plunged below another threshold, falling more than $5 a barrel to $67.75.

item.title: A suicide attack on a British diplomatic convoy in Kabul kills six.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: The Taliban claimed responsibility for the car bombing ahead of next week's Afghanistan summit in London. A British security guard and an Afghan staffer from the UK embassy were among those killed, and another 34 people were injured, including many civilians.

item.title: Give thanks you're not eating Thanksgiving dinner on the International Space Station.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: US astronauts Butch Wilmore and Terry Virts will be celebrating the American holiday with such gastronomic horrors as irradiated turkey, thermostabilized yams, and freeze-dried mash potatoes. Despite the grub, Wilmore gave thanks in a video.

item.title: Ukraine's prime minister gets his marching orders.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: Lawmakers backed Arseniy Yatsenyuk to stay on as Ukraine’s prime minister, clearing the way for continued talks with the International Monetary Fund as the country grapples with a deep recession and the conflict in its east.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: “Our country is at war. People are in trouble,” Yatsenyuk told legislators. “It depends on us whether we can stop the external aggression from Russia.”

item.title: When it comes to buying a Christmas tree, timing matters.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

item.title: Mexico’s president vows to reform the police.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Enrique Pena Nieto said all local police forces would come under federal control, in response to the disappearance of 43 students, which were allegedly killed by police forces working with gang members. The reforms also grant Congress the power to dissolve local governments infiltrated by drugs cartels.

item.title: Kim Jong-un's sister gets a top government post.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Her name is Kim Yo-jong, she's 27, and she's now deputy director of the ruling Workers Party. Her responsibilities aren't clear, but in the bizarro world of North Korea, it's a big deal that she recently accompanied her brother on a tour of a cartoon film studio.

item.title: Iran's leader says he's not opposed to more nuclear talks.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei said in a speech that he does not "disagree" with continued negotiations. But he warned Tehran would not be bullied into a deal.

item.title: After 19 years of trying, the World Trade Organization delivers a world trade deal.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: The 160-member body agreed to overhaul global customs procedures. Mundane as that sounds, some economists say it could result in $1 trillion in new economic activity and 21 million new jobs.

item.title: David Cameron tests the EU’s limits.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: The UK prime minister wants to make EU migrants ineligible for welfare and housing benefits for their first four years in the UK. The proposed legislation, introduced as the anti-immigration UK Independence Party attracts more popular support, may threaten the UK’s position within the EU.

item.title: Ferguson protestors try to disrupt Thanksgiving.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: At least seven demonstrators were detained in New York City after they knocked down barriers near the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade and tried to obstruct the parade route. Between 50 and 100 protestors gathered peacefully early in the day to protest police brutality in both Ferguson and New York.

item.title: A Nigerian bomb attack kills at least 40.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: No group has taken responsibility for targeting a village bus station near the city of Mubi, but the area has been regularly singled out by Islamist extremist group Boko Haram. The Nigerian army and the militants have been battling for control of the area for several weeks.

item.title: The Netherlands takes 122 tons (111 tonnes) of gold out of the US.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Dutch central bank said the transfer of the precious metal worth about 4 billion euros ($5 billion) may have a “positive confidence effect with the public.”

item.title: The word “apron” used to be “napron.”
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: People misheard “an apron,” and the new name stuck.

item.title: Thanksgiving dinner in space took 18 months to prepare.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The turkey was irradiated, and the yams were thermostabilized.

item.title: Now is the time to buy your Christmas tree.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Timing matters.

item.title: We need to diversify away from wheat, rice, and corn.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: We can eat around 10,000 crops but rely on those three alone for 60% of our food.

item.title: Rémy Cointreau loses out on China’s crackdown.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The cognac maker reported a 23% decline in operating profit (paywall) for the half-year to September, from €133 million a year earlier. A corruption crackdown and slowing economic growth has hurt gift-giving in China, which accounts for about half of company sales.

item.title: A cold shower for Club Med.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The upmarket French vacation group, currently the target of a bidding war between Chinese and Italian suitors, posted a loss of €9 million ($11.2 million) for the second consecutive year, despite a rise in the number of holidaymakers at its all-inclusive resorts.

item.title: Legoland is coming to South Korea.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The London-listed entertainments company Merlin will be responsible for the development of the park (paywall), which is scheduled to open in 2017 in one the top Asian markets for the world’s biggest toymaker.

item.title: Nearly half the world can now visit India without queuing at an embassy.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: British retailers embrace Black Friday—and the predictable chaos ensued.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: The lure of cheap TVs is strong on both sides of the pond. In the UK, Reuters reports, police arrested three at Tesco stores and helped control crowds of shoppers in Cardiff, Glasgow, London, and Manchester. Nearly two-thirds of British merchants planned to offer promotions the day after America's Thanksgiving.

item.title: The president of HSBC Argentina denies having a Swiss account with the bank.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: But Argentina's tax agency said he did, and that it was just one of thousands of undeclared Swiss accounts that helped HSBC's Argentine customers evade taxes. The agency filed its accusations with an Argentine court; the bank said it has complied with regulations and rejected relationships with would-be tax evaders.

item.title: For the world's highly skilled workers, the US isn't the lure it once was.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz

item.title: The pope makes his first visit to a predominantly Muslim nation.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: Speaking from the presidential palace in Ankara, Pope Francis praised Turkey for accepting 1.6 million refugees from Syrian territories overrun by the ISIS, and said other countries have a "moral obligation" to help the Turkish government assist them. At Istanbul’s Blue Mosque, he stood in silent prayer alongside a senior Islamic cleric.

item.title: Ebola has killed more than 7,000.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: Worldwide, 16,000 people have been infected, the World Health Organization reports. The infection rate is still soaring in Sierra Leone, though it is stabilizing in Liberia and Guinea. Meanwhile, Mali just declared itself Ebola-free with the announcement that the last known patient there has been cured.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A 15-minute test for Ebola developed by scientists in Senegal will be used in trials over the next few weeks at an Ebola treatment center in Guinea. Aside from being speedy, the new test is portable and, unlike the traditional diagnosis method, does not require a cold environment. On the vaccine front, initial human testing of one possible candidate looks promising, in that the drug appears to be safe and provokes a strong immune reaction in test subjects.

item.title: Target's Thanksgiving Day online sales rise 40% from last year.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: It was the US retailer’s biggest online sales day ever, with growth in mobile traffic particularly pronounced. Business also was brisk at the chain's brick-and-mortar locations; in the first hour the stores were open yesterday, they sold 1,800 television sets and 2,000 video games per minute.

item.title: A gunman sets fire to the Mexican consulate in Austin, Texas.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: The blaze was extinguished and the 50-year-old gunman died, though not before firing more than 100 rounds at the consulate, a nearby federal courthouse, and Austin's police headquarters, among other downtown buildings. No one else was hurt in the early morning incident. Investigators have not yet determined a motive.

item.title: Ray Rice can play football again—if he can find a team to sign him.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: The NFL star, suspended indefinitely after a video surfaced showing him punching out his then-fiancée (now wife) at a casino in Atlantic City, New Jersey, won his appeal and is eligible to play again, according to his lawyer. Rice was released by the Baltimore Ravens in September.

item.title: Hosni Mubarak's murder charges are dropped.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: A judge dismissed a case against the former Egyptian president, who had been charged in the deaths of hundreds of protesters during the street protests that deposed him in 2011. In protests following the verdict, one person was killed, nine were injured, and more than 40 were arrested. Police dispersed the crowd with tear gas and water cannons.

item.title: Nicolas Sarkozy is back in the game.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The former French president was elected head of the opposition UMP, trouncing his rivals, Bruno le Marie and Hervé Marito, with 64.5% of the vote. His comeback comes 10 years after he first won the same position, from where he went on to become France's president. But Le Monde said that his advisors wanted at least 70% of the vote (link in French).

item.title: James Watson is selling his Nobel Prize.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Watson is auctioning the medal (paywall) he won in 1962 for discovering the double-helix structure of DNA because he is short of money. "No-one really wants to admit I exist," he said, following comments he made in 2007 that black people were inherently less intelligent than white people. The reserve price for the medal is $2.5 million.

item.title: Taiwan's premier resigns after heavy losses in local elections.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: Premier Jiang Yi-huah made the announcement after Taiwanese voted overwhelmingly against the Kuomintang (KMT) party in the over 11,000 contested local elections, showing widespread dissatisfaction with the ruling party's economic management and emphasis on closer ties with China. The KMT lost the mayoral race in Taipei City for the first time in 16 years.

item.title: India's super-rich population is exploding.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: China's too. Japan's, not so much.

item.title: The death toll in Friday's attack on a Nigerian mosque passes 100.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: No one has claimed responsibility for the gun and bomb attack on the city of Kano's Central Mosque, but officials say it fits the pattern of Boko Haram, the Sunni Islamist group that has killed more than 2,000 this year. The militants gained international notoriety after kidnapping more than 200 schoolgirls earlier this year.

item.title: Everything is better in Lego.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: Just 14 hours after the trailer for J.J. Abrams' new Star Wars movie appeared online, a superfan had uploaded this all-Lego shot-for-shot remake.

item.title: Suicide bombings kill 30 in Kobani.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: Four Islamic State suicide bombers detonated bombs across the town at the border of Syria and Turkey. One of the attacks, involving a bomb-loaded armored vehicle, was at a border crossing, prompting accusations that the attack was launched from Turkish soil. Turkey denied charges that the vehicle had crossed from its side.

item.title: A teenager missing for four years is found behind a "false wall."
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: The 13-year-old boy was found in his father's suburban Atlanta home on Friday, after he had contacted his sister online using a smartphone, police reported. He was reunited with his mother, who had told authorities where he was. The boy's father and stepmother were arrested, along with three juveniles.

item.title: Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson resigns.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: The officer who shot and killed the black teenager Michael Brown this August cited safety concerns for other officers and the community as the reason, telling the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, "I’m not willing to let someone else get hurt because of me.” Monday's announcement that a Missouri grand jury would not indict Wilson set off nationwide protests.

item.title: Switzerland decided against changes to its banking regime.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The country voted against forcing the country’s central bank to more than double its gold reserves, ending a 152-year-old tax break for rich foreigners, and capping immigration.

item.title: There's a drone next to the window seat.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz

item.title: Future space missions may be powered by poop.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Researchers at the University of Florida have found a way to turn human waste into biogas that can fuel space shuttle missions, potentially producing 290 liters of methane for each crew member every day over the course of a week. Currently, the poop is stored and burnt up as the space shuttles reenter the atmosphere.

item.title: China creates a bank deposit insurance system.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The People’s Bank of China introduced draft rules on an insurance system for bank deposits of as much as 500,000 yuan ($81,367). No start date came with the announcement but state media have suggested the new system—which removes the implicit government guarantee behind all deposits—could begin in early 2015.

item.title: Bird flu spreads in the Netherlands.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Dutch authorities discovered the disease at a poultry farm and are killing all of its 28,000 birds—near a farm where they encountered a highly-infectious new variant of the disease, H5N8, two weeks ago, resulting in the slaughter of 150,000 birds. In 2003, a bird flu outbreak led to the cull of 30 million birds.

item.title: Hong Kong's pro-democracy protests escalate.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Police and demonstrators clashed in front of Hong Kong’s main government office on Sunday night and into Monday, marking a newly violent stage of the pro-democracy protests that have entered their third month. Things are about to get more chaotic in coming days—a judge just issued an injunction to clear the main protest site.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: At least 40 people were arrested at the main protest site in Admiralty. “We feel that the government feels no pressure if this movement simply drags on like this,” Scholarism leader Oscar Lai told the New York Times (paywall). “This escalation shows that Hong Kong people can’t wait anymore.” [caption id="attachment_303984" align="aligncenter" width="640"] [/caption] [caption id="attachment_303985" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] [/caption] [caption id="attachment_303986" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] [/caption]

item.title: Hackers leak unreleased movies from Sony.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Attacks on the company’s computer networks resulted in at least five pre-release movies being pirated online.The hackers’ identities and motives are unknown, but the government of North Korea—which was angered by a forthcoming North Korean-themed comedy from Sony—is among the suspects.

item.title: Samsung didn't fire its mobile phone boss after all.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Mobile business head J.K. Shin retained his top spot despite speculation he could be replaced, after a precipitous decline in profits at Samsung's smartphone division. A source told ZDNet that Samsung heir apparent Jay Y. Lee's decision showed "deference toward his father and the current restructuring drive."

item.title: Uber is banned in Thailand.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The on-demand car service’s vehicles and drivers are improperly registered, do not comply with regulated rates, and discriminate against customers without credit cards, according to a Thai transportation regulator. Drivers for Uber, which has been operating in Bangkok and Phuket for about a year, will face heavy fines if they continue to operate.

item.title: DNA can survive in space.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Scientists found out by putting some on the outside of a rocket, but its survival may could mean our probes on Mars are spreading human DNA there.

item.title: Vladimir Putin visits Turkey.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Russian president will discuss trade and energy with Turkey’s Recep Tayyip Erdogan, but the leaders are unlikely to find common ground on two contentious issues: Russia’s backing of Syrian president Bashar al-Asaad, and Putin’s annexation of Crimea.

item.title: The Philae landing was a boost for Aerosmith.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The asteroid probe spurred people to revisit the Armageddon soundtrack.

item.title: Coffee tastes different depending on mug color.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A blue mug may accentuate the brew’s bitterness.

item.title: A merit badge for online cookie sales?
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Girl Scouts of the USA announced it will let troops sell its famous cookies online for the first time, via personalized websites and mobile apps, in order to teach e-commerce and entrepreneurial skills. The group also hopes that online sales will add to an estimated $800 million annual business.

item.title: A thriftier Cyber Monday?
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: US shoppers spent $50.9 billion over the Thanksgiving weekend, 11% less than last year. Consumers could be saving their holiday shopping funds for Cyber Monday—or just tightening their purse strings.

item.title: The US and Turkey are talking about a strategy against ISIL.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That's according to officials from both countries who spoke to The Wall Street Journal. The sources said that Turkey would let American forces use its air bases, and that there's talk of a potential "protected zone" (paywall) on the border of Syria that would be off access to Assad's regime.

item.title: Egyptian terror group says it killed an American.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The personal documents of William Henderson, 58, were posted to an ISIL online forum late last night, with the ISIL-linked Ansar Beit al-Maqdis claiming it was responsible for his death in August. Henderson's original cause of death was listed as a carjacking.

item.title: Rio de Janeiro erects a 280-foot floating Christmas tree.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The structure, claimed to be the world's tallest floating Christmas tree, is in the Rodrigo de Freitas Lagoon. It weighs over 540 tons, and it features over three million lights. Nearly 200,000 tourists saw it light up.

item.title: New Zealand says Kim Dotcom has been on his best behavior.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: This after the US requested that the Megaupload founder be remanded because he allegedly posed a flight risk. Dotcom did have the conditions of his bail tightened, however: he's no longer allowed to travel by helicopter and must check-in with the police twice a week.

item.title: Japan's credit rating is taken down a notch.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The ratings agency Moody's is unimpressed by prime minister Shinzō Abe's decision to delay a sales-tax increase, scheduled for Oct. 2015. The country's new AA3 rating puts it on par with the Czech Republic. This is despite the Nikkei hitting a seven-year high.

item.title: 15,000 robots are helping Amazon this Cyber Monday.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The $775 million Bezos spent on Kiva Systems back in 2012 faces its biggest test today. On Cyber Monday last year, Amazon customers ordered 36.8 million items—roughly 426 every second. That record will likely be broken today, with the 320-lb robots helping packages get out the door.

item.title: The "12 days of Christmas" will cost you $27,673.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Those piping pipers, swimming swans, French hens, and all the other items in the nine verses from the 200-year-old song will set you back even more if you decide to buy them on the internet: $42,959. That's according to the PNC Wealth Management Christmas Index, which has been publishing its tongue-in-cheek figures for 31 years now.

item.title: We're at "the beginning of the end" of the AIDS pandemic.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The number of people who were infected with the HIV virus last year was—for the first time—lower than the number of people who began taking drugs to keep the disease at bay. The United Nations says we can beat AIDS by the year 2030.

item.title: Captain Kirk and Iron Man are lifting off on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Not the actors that play the fictional characters, but their action figures. They'll also be joined by a Tyrannosaurus Rex onboard NASA's first test-flight of the Orion spacecraft. If all goes to plan, Orion will be sending astronauts to Mars at some point in 2021, assuming we figure out the logistics.

item.title: Google's next version of Glass will have Intel inside.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Wall Street Journal says the search giant's futuristic eyewear—on sale since April 2013—will finally get a version 2.0 update next year. There's still no word on whether the $1,500 price-tag will be trimmed.

item.title: Hong Kong Democracy Protest
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Police officers beat up protesters as they try to disperse them outside government headquarters in Hong Kong Monday, Dec. 1, 2014. Pro-democracy protesters clashed with police as they tried to surround Hong Kong government headquarters late Sunday, stepping up their movement for genuine democratic reforms after camping out on the city's streets for more than two months. (AP Photo/Vincent Yu)

item.title: APTOPIX Hong Kong Democracy Protest
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Police officers throw a pro-democracy protester on the main road outside government headquarters in Hong Kong Sunday, Nov. 30, 2014. Hundreds of pro-democracy protesters faced off with Hong Kong police late Sunday, stepping up their movement for genuine democratic reforms after being camped out on the city's streets for more than two months. (AP Photo/Kin Cheung)

Pro-democracy protesters clashed with police as they tried to surround Hong Kong government headquarters late Sunday, stepping up their movement for genuine democratic reforms after camping out on the city's streets for more than two months. (AP Photo/Vincent Yu)

item.title: Tim Cook has created as much value as Steve Jobs.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Testting links here testing.

item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: text text text text

item.title: Wanda Group is in talks to buy into Lions Gate.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Chinese property conglomerate’s chairman, Wang Jianlin, told Bloomberg he is interested in acquiring control of the Hunger Games movie studio but would also accept a minority stake. Wanda already owns AMC, the second-largest US cinema chain.

item.title: Vladimir Putin drops a controversial gas pipeline.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Russian president announced Gazprom would no longer seek approval to build a pipeline that would have taken its gas directly to central and southern Europe, after opposition from the EU. Speaking during a visit to Turkey, Putin said Gazprom would instead consider a “gas hub” on the border of Turkey and Greece.

item.title: New evidence that North Korea hacked Sony.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The malware tools that were used to penetrate Sony’s corporate network were similar to those used against South Korean TV stations and ATMs in an attack last year, according to the Wall Street Journal (paywall). The FBI also warned companies about destructive malware that could render data on hard drives inaccessible.

item.title: HIV is becoming “milder.”
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The evolving virus is taking longer to cause AIDS in humans, and is being “watered down” as it adapts to human immune systems, a study from the University of Oxford has found. A new report also found that fewer people were diagnosed with HIV than were signed up for treatment in 2013, marking a turning point in combating the epidemic.

item.title: SpaceX is hiring a farmer.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Not for a space station or Mars, but for McGregor, Texas; the company has vast land plots there that it might as well put to good use.

item.title: A new class of synthentic drugs is on the horizon.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: UK scientists have created artificially engineered enzymes.

item.title: Occupy Hong Kong announces its surrender.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The group's three co-founders said they would give themselves up to police on Wednesday, and urged protesters from other democracy groups to retreat from demonstrations in the wake of recent violence. Separately, three student leaders are on a hunger strike to force talks with the government, and a faction of more extreme activists vowed violent attacks on government buildings.

item.title: Israel moved toward early elections.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu failed to mend a rift with finance minister Yair Lapid, signaling the likely dissolution of Israel’s ruling coalition. Lapid and other centrist coalition members have criticized the prime minister’s push for more Jewish settlements and his failure to advance a peace process with the Palestinians.

item.title: Lebanon detains the wife and child of ISIL’s leader.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The family of Abu Bakr Al-Baghdadi was detained near the Syrian border 10 days ago, a source told AFP. Lebanon has taken a tough stance against the Islamic State, cracking down on sympathizers and tightening its border controls.

item.title: Apple goes to court over monopoly allegations…for the iPod.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Plaintiffs in a US federal lawsuit say the company violated antitrust rules in 2006 by only enabling iTunes customers to hear their music on iPods, rather than rival music devices. Apple could face a legal bill of more than $1 billion if it loses.

item.title: Stephen Hawking wants to be a Bond villain.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: “I think the wheelchair and the computer voice would fit the part,” the theoretical physicist told Wired.

item.title: You don't need to prove you're gay to gain asylum in the EU.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That's what the EU's top court just decreed, after three men were denied refuge in the Netherlands because they couldn't provide evidence of their sexual orientation. Those seeking asylum in EU member states still have to prove, however, that they're in danger in their home country.

item.title: Russia says it's going to enter a recession next year.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Instead of experiencing 1.2% annual GDP growth—like it originally predicted—Russia's economic development ministry now predicts the economy will contract 0.8%. Crucially, disposable incomes, which were expected to rise slightly, are now forecast to shrink by 2.8%. It's not helping that in this past year alone, the Russian ruble has lost 40% of its value.

item.title: A new ceasefire in Ukraine—or at least part of it.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: International observers say that starting Friday, forces fighting in the Luhansk region will honor a new ceasefire. In neighboring Donetsk, however, the situation remains hostile, with fresh attacks taking place within the past few days.

item.title: Barack Obama chooses a new defense secretary.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The US president has picked Ashton Carter, previously the Pentagon's chief arms buyer and an assistant secretary of defense, to replace the outgoing Chuck Hagel, sources told Bloomberg. Carter's appointment would require the approval of the Republican-led senate.

item.title: China's internet companies will be fined for not removing adult content.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Tencent, Baidu, and nine other internet firms will reportedly be fined an unknown amount for providing access to online pornography, violent content, and gambling. The move comes as part of a larger cultural crackdown by Beijing, including proposed bans on puns, racy TV shows, and unconventional architecture.

item.title: Kalashnikov rebrands itself.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The company wants its name to be as well known as Apple's, says Sergei Chemezov, head of the Russian company that owns a controlling stake in the weapons maker. The 20 million ruble ($375,000) rebranding effort kicked off with a flashy press event Tuesday in Moscow.

item.title: Egypt sentences 185 Muslim Brotherhood supporters to death.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A court found the men guilty of killing 12 police officers in an attack on a Cairo police station last year. The ruling is the latest of several mass trials of the group's supporters since Mohammed Morsi's brief rule ended last year.

item.title: RadioShack seems very close to shorting out.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Uber hitches a ride with Carlos Slim.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The ride sharing service signed a deal with Slim's America Movil to promote the app and offer Uber drivers money off their phone bills.

item.title: Iran allegedly conducts air strikes within Iraq.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Pentagon said that Iranian air force jets attacked Islamic State positions in eastern Iraq, where the US is conducting its own air strikes against the extremist Islamist group. A senior Iranian official denied the Pentagon's allegation, according to Reuters.

item.title: Most US executions come from just 2% of its counties.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Stay away from Duval, Florida, where one in 14,000 among the county's population of 850,000 has been sentenced to death.

item.title: “Gangnam Style” broke YouTube.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: PSY’s music video has been viewed more than 2.1 billion times, which required the video streaming site to introduce a system upgrade.

item.title: Hong Kong's pro-democracy protest leaders try—and fail—to surrender.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: The three co-founders of Occupy Central with Peace and Love, Hong Kong's veteran pro-democracy group and a key organizer of the Umbrella Movement, turned themselves in to police today, admitting they had "taken part in an unauthorized assembly." But rather than arrest Benny Tai, Chan Kin-man and Reverend Chu Yiu-ming, police told them to fill out a form indicating their offense, and then released them.

item.title: Sweden’s government may collapse after only two months in power.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Prime minister Stefan Löfven threatened to resign after his budget failed to win legislative approval. The right-wing Sweden Democrats have vowed to block any budget that supports a rise in immigration.

item.title: We must colonize other planets to protect the human race.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: So says Stephen Hawking (paywall).

item.title: Where in the US teachers get the most rewarding pay packets.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Britain pays off all its WWI debt.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Chancellor George Osborne said the UK will repay the remaining £1.9 billion ($3 billion) of debt from a 3.5% War Loan—issued in 1932, which converted 4% loans issued by Winston Churchill in 1927, which in turn refinanced National War Bonds issued to the public in 1917—in March 2015. The Great War started in 1914 and ended in 1918.

item.title: The American couple cleared of killing their daughter in Qatar go home.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Matthew and Grace Huang were arrested and charged with the murder of their 8-year-old adopted daughter from Ghana in January of 2013. The US state department intervened on their behalf, and they were eventually cleared in court. Today they're returning to Los Angeles.

item.title: Israel is dissolving its parliament.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Lawmakers voted 84-0 to dissolve the Knesset, an initial step toward holding elections two years early. Another vote next week could seal the deal. The move comes after prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu's ruling coalition collapsed as he fired two of his cabinet ministers, saying their criticism made it "impossible to lead a state."

item.title: Britain says its economy will do better than expected today, but worse tomorrow.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In the treasury's annual "Autumn Statement," chancellor George Osborne said 2014 GDP growth will come in at 3.0% instead of 2.7%, and 2015 will see 2.4% growth instead of 2.3%. However, this spurt will result in somewhat slower growth in later years, with forecasts trimmed to between 2% and 2.5%. The chancellor reckons he can balance the budget in 2018—the deficit is expected to come in at £91.3 billion ($143 billion) this year.

item.title: Lufthansa pilots are going on strike again.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Europe's largest airline announced that it will cancel nearly half its long-haul flights for the second time this week, as the pilots' union announced its 10th strike of the year—this one between 2am and 10:59pm GMT on Thursday. The pilots object to the airline's plan to phase out an early-retirement option.

item.title: Employer discrimination around the world, mapped.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

item.title: A Ukrainian nuclear reactor accident poses "no threat."
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That's what the country's energy minister said when he announced a short circuit at the 1,000-megawatt Zaporizhzhya facility, Europe's largest power plant. The issue is with a generator, not the reactors, he said, and rolling blackouts throughout the country are expected to end by Friday. Still, the news spooked European markets.

item.title: Honda announces a nationwide US recall.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Honda has already recalled 3.5 million cars with Takata air bags, but now it is expanding the program to all 50 states, despite a parts shortage (paywall). Takata itself was told by the US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to issue a nationwide recall by Dec. 2—but it refused to do so.

item.title: Sweden will hold a snap election next March.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Prime minister Stefan Löfven announced the news after his cabinet's budget proposal was rejected. The elections, due to be held on March 22, will "let voters make a choice in the face of this new political landscape," said Löfven.

item.title: Never let a good mind go to waste.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Approximately 100 brains—including that of the sniper who scaled a clock tower in 1966 and killed 16 people—are missing from the University of Texas. The school used to have twice that many, but didn't have enough room, so it put a few in the closet, from where they were snatched.

item.title: No indictment in the police-chokehold death of Eric Garner.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: This may sound familiar: A grand jury has declined to indict police officer Daniel Pantaleo, who was filmed holding the Staten Island man in a chokehold moments before his death in August, despite pleas from Garner that he couldn't breath. Pantaleo may still face civil or federal charges. Protests cropped up all around New York this evening.

item.title: No indictment over the death of Eric Garner.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A grand jury decided the white police officer who caused the death of an unarmed black man in New York by putting him in a chokehold should face no criminal charges, following a familiar pattern for how the US legal system handles cops accused of excessive force. Protests sprung up around the city, including at Rockefeller Center’s Christmas tree lighting ceremony.

item.title: Fighting in Chechnya.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Three police have been shot dead at a checkpoint and militants have taken over buildings in the north of Grozny, the Chechen capital. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov said the situation was calm and denied the city was under military control.

item.title: Honda puts some distance between it and Takata.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The automaker turned to Swedish parts maker Autoliv and Japan’s Daicel to supply parts for the cars it is recalling because of safety issues related to airbags made by Japan’s Takata. Honda announced a nationwide recall of cars fitted with Takata airbags; US regulators asked Takata to do the same, but the company has refused.

item.title: The ultimate test drive.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: NASA will trial the Orion spacecraft, the ship that is meant to eventually carry humans to Mars. Today’s test will send the ship up 3,600 miles, and when it returns to Earth, it’ll reach speeds of 20,000 miles an hour—the speed NASA expects ships will hit as they’re coming home from deep space.

item.title: Giraffes are going extinct.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Their numbers have fallen almost by half over the last 15 years. The "silent" extinction is being driven by poaching—including the belief that consuming giraffes cures HIV—and habitat loss caused by expanding human settlements, according to wildlife experts.

item.title: The World Trade Center subway station may cost more than the World Trade Center.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Its estimated to cost $4 billion.

item.title: Apple TV was no match for Google's Chromecast.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: The European Central Bank revs up.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: “Super” Mario Draghi is expected to drop hints about the ECB buying government bonds to kickstart the moribund euro zone economy. The euro traded at a two-year low against the dollar ahead of the ECB’s policy meeting, where it decided to leave benchmark rates at historic lows.

item.title: The ultimate test drive.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: NASA will trial its new Orion spacecraft, which is meant to eventually carry humans to Mars. Today’s test will send the ship up 3,600 miles; on reentry it will reach speeds of 20,000 miles an hour.

item.title: Vladimir Putin strikes a defiant tone.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: In the Russian president’s annual address to parliament, he justified the annexation of Crimea, condemned Western sanctions, and attacked “speculators” for pushing down the value of the ruble. “We know who these people are, and we have the means to rein them in,” Putin said.

item.title: Europe’s budget airlines soar.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Ireland’s Ryanair raised its profit outlook for the second time in a month after passenger volume rose 22% in November. Rival carrier Easyjet reported a more modest increase in passengers (paywall); both stocks were up sharply in morning trading.

item.title: Softbank invests in southeast Asia’s version of Uber.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Japanese tech company’s $250 million investment in GrabTaxi, which operates in six countries including Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand, will give the ride-share firm more resources as it tries to fend off the fast-expanding Uber. GrabTaxi said it will grow in a “an ethical and moral way.”

item.title: Best Buy admits defeat in China.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The big-box electronics retailer said it is selling its struggling 184-store Chinese business, Five Star, to Chinese real estate firm Zhejiang Jiayuan Group, in order to “focus even more on our US business.” Terms were not disclosed.

item.title: Divorce Italian-style now features WhatsApp.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Facebook messaging app is cited in half of all Italian divorce cases. Attorneys say it doesn’t cause infidelity—it just provides proof.

item.title: Flying this Christmas? Pack light and bring a book.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: US and UK counterterrorism officials are considering a ban on carry-on bags due to fears that Al Qaeda may be planning to bomb Europe-bound flights over the holidays. NPR reports that a complete ban on electronic devices in the cabin is also being discussed.

item.title: Russia's currency is going haywire.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: Google is making kid-friendly versions of its services.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The search giant's homepage, YouTube, and Chrome will be reportedly reinvented for children aged 13 and under, according to Pavni Diwanji, vice president of Google engineering. She says: "We expect this to be controversial, but the simple truth is kids already have the technology in schools and at home."

item.title: The next James Bond film is called "Spectre."
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: And it will hit UK theaters in Oct. 2015. The 24th Bond film will be directed by Sam Mendes, star Daniel Craig (again), and include Guardians of the Galaxy actor Dave Bautista in the cast. "Spectre" isn't just British-speak for "specter": It stands for Special Executive for Counter-intelligence, Terrorism, Revenge and Extortion, originally referenced in the 1960s films.

item.title: Apple GPU supplier unveils Raspberry Pi competitor.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Imagination Technologies may not be a household name, but it's crucial to playing graphically intensive games on iPhones and iPads. The British firm has unveiled a $65 computer called the CI20 that starts shipping in January. Raspberry has a four million unit head start, however.

item.title: NASA's Orion space launch was postponed.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The US civilian space program said a valve issue is to blame. The next attempt may be at 07:05 ET on Friday, pending weather conditions. The launch is an early step in NASA's goal to send humans to Mars.

item.title: Amazon is getting into the food takeout game.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: One catch: You have to live in Seattle.
