The online retailer is launching a takeout and delivery service that allows residents in its hometown to order meals to their homes from more than 100 restaurants, payable through their Amazon account. Amazon hasn't said if the service will launch elsewhere.

item.title: Starbucks launches "Mobile Order & Pay" in one US city.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Say you're walking to your favorite coffee house, wouldn't it be convenient if you could tap a few buttons and have your latte waiting for you as soon as you stepped inside? That's now possible—at least in Portland, Oregon. And it's a feature that'll come to more locations in 2015.

item.title: The ECB says no stimulus this year.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The central bank may consider expanding its bond-buying program to boost the euro zone's moribund economy next year, but has decided to hold fire for now. Meanwhile, the bank's growth forecasts were revised downwards: 0.8% this year, 1.0% next year, and 1.5% in 2016—down from 0.9%, 1.6%, and 1.9%, respectively.

item.title: Microsoft sells the Nook back to Barnes & Noble.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Two and a half years ago, the software giant forked over $300 million for a stake in Barnes & Noble's e-book division. But it just sold that stake back to B&N for $62 million and 2.7 million B&N shares. It probably didn't help that the book seller recently launched an Android powered Samsung tablet.

item.title: New York City mayor Bill de Blasio promises to change the NYPD.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: During an interview on local radio, the mayor vowed to make changes to prevent another incident like Eric Garner's, a day after a grand jury chose not to indict the officer who apparently put Garner, an unarmed 43-year-old black man, in a headlock before he died for allegedly selling untaxed cigarettes. "There's a lot of pain that we're all feeling right now," de Blasio said (paywall).

item.title: Why college education in the US is a bum deal.
item.dc:creator: qzroya

item.title: Uber is now valued at $40 billion.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The New York Times’ DealBook reported today—and Uber itself confirmed—that "a major round of venture financing" underway would value the fast-growing ride-sharing service at roughly $40 billion. Six months ago, the service was valued at roughly $18 billion. (Fortune reported today on new Delaware filings showing Uber is selling $1.8 billion in new shares in the company.)

item.title: Cleveland's cops habitually use excessive force.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: US Attorney General Eric Holder said a Justice Department civil rights investigation found that the Cleveland police force showed a pattern of "unreasonable and unnecessary use of force," one week after a surveillance video was released showing the fatal police shooting of a 12-year-old African-American child who was holding a pellet gun.

item.title: Uber raises new funds, and its own valuation.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The on-demand car service confirmed reports that it has raised $1.2 billion in new funding, which implies a $40 billion valuation that is more than double what it was six months ago. Uber is also in talks to sell an additional $1 billion in convertible debt, according to Reuters, giving it a significant amount of leeway when it comes to considering a future IPO.

item.title: The US grapples with police violence.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A second night of protests over the chokehold death of Eric Garner took place across the United States. Meanwhile, a federal report found that the Cleveland police force has a history of using excessive force, days after police shot and killed a 12-year-old boy, and the Los Angeles police department found fault with yet another shooting death of an unarmed man last year.

item.title: Starbucks is boozing it up.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Some 3,000 of the coffee chain's US stores will serve beer and wine as part of an expanded evening menu, aimed at reversing slowing sales. The company said at its biennial investor meeting that it plans to double US food sales to more than $4 billion within the next five years.

item.title: China's stock market is having a manic week.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Despite a slowing economy and an underwhelming plan to link  Hong Kong and mainland stock exchanges, the Shanghai stock market has risen nearly 10% for no apparent reason. Analysts say that bull-market enthusiasm "has become self-reinforcing."

item.title: Google is aiming at the youngsters.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The search giant's homepage, along with YouTube and the Chrome browser, will be reinvented for children aged 13 and under, according to Pavni Diwanji, vice president of Google engineering. "We expect this to be controversial, but the simple truth is kids already have the technology in schools and at home," she told USA Today.

item.title: Chimpanzee rights are denied.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A New York court ruled that animal rights activists could not file a lawsuit seeking the freedom of a chimp named Tommy. The judges noted that chimps "cannot bear any legal duties, submit to societal responsibilities or be held legally accountable for their actions,” and thus are not entitled to the same rights as humans.

item.title: Pomegranates could save Afghanistan's economy.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Assuming the logistical issues are ironed out.

item.title: Bats' brains have 3D compasses.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Specialized cells could explain why they fly so deftly.

item.title: The US grapples with police violence.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A second night of protests over the chokehold death of Eric Garner took place across the United States. Meanwhile, a federal report found that the Cleveland police force has a history of using excessive force, days after police shot and killed a 12-year-old boy, and the Los Angeles police department found fault with yet another shooting death of an unarmed man last year.

item.title: Starbucks is boozing it up.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Some 3,000 of the coffee chain's US stores will serve beer and wine as part of an expanded evening menu, aimed at reversing slowing sales. The company said at its biennial investor meeting that it plans to double US food sales to more than $4 billion within the next five years.

item.title: China's stock market is having a manic week.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Despite a slowing economy and an underwhelming plan to link Hong Kong and mainland exchanges, the Shanghai stock market has risen nearly 10% for no apparent reason. Analysts say that bull-market enthusiasm "has become self-reinforcing."

item.title: The NYPD may have problems, but diversity isn't one of them
item.dc:creator: jasonqz

item.title: Ukraine's government seeks a new ceasefire.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: President Petro Poroshenko said in a statement that Kyiv's forces would withdraw heavy weapons from the country's restive eastern regions if pro-Russian separatists also observed a "day of silence" on Dec. 9. Previous ceasefire pledges have been quickly broken, with more than 4,300 killed in fighting so far.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Ukraine also revealed new numbers on its dangerously low level of foreign-currency reserves, enough to cover just over a month of imports. Its buffers have dwindled as it spent money to defend the value of its currency and repaid hefty gas debts owed to Russia's Gazprom.

item.title: German factories are revving up.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Orders rose more strongly than expected in October, easing concerns about the health of Europe's economic engine. Speaking of German engines, Mercedes-Benz reported a 13% jump in sales in November, confirming that the carmaker is on track to set a new annual sales record this year.

item.title: Britain will loan
item.dc:creator: jasonqz

item.title: Orion blasts off.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The test flight of NASA's new Orion rocket, designed to eventually send humans to Mars, launched as scheduled from Florida, after technical glitches yesterday scuttled the launch yesterday. Watch live video from the rocket here.

item.title: Britain loans a Greek architectural treasure to Russia.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: One of the Elgin Marbles, removed from the Parthenon in the 19th century, was shipped from the British Museum in London to St Petersburg's Hermitage Museum. It is the first time one of the famous statues has been loaned out, stoking considerable controversy in the UK and, of course, in Greece.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The statue in question is of the river god Ilissos, originally placed in the left-hand corner of the Parthenon's west pediment, according to the British Museum:
The naked youth's languid form is well adapted to the raking angle of the pediment that framed him. He appears as if caught in the action of raising himself onto a rock. A piece of drapery hangs wet and clinging to his left arm.

item.title: The International Criminal Court drops Uhuru Kenyatta's charges.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The current president of Kenya was alleged to have committed crimes against humanity when 1,000 people were killed following the country's 2007 presidential election. "The evidence has not improved to such an extent that Mr. Kenyatta's alleged criminal responsibility can be proven beyond reasonable doubt," an ICC prosecutor said.

item.title: Colorado cop convicted of killing an elk.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Sam Carter shot and killed an elk in 2013, lied about it, and on Friday, he was found guilty of nine charges against him, including four felonies

item.title: The US jobs report is out—321,000 jobs were added in November.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That's significantly better than expectations; the unemployment rate is unchanged, however, at 5.8%. Also, October's numbers were revised to 243,000 jobs versus an original estimate of 214,000. This past year the US saw the fastest job growth in a decade and a half.

item.title: All new European cars to feature automated an emergency call system.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Starting in March 2018, if you drive a car fresh off the lot of a dealership in the European Union, it'll come standard with the ability to automatically call a police and ambulance should you get into an accident. This was supposed to have happened in 2012, but privacy concerns pushed it back.

item.title: The Maldives needs a water delivery.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A fire at a water treatment plant cut off drinking water to the 100,000 or so people who live in Male, the country's capital, forcing the government to declare a state of emergency. India is in the process of airlifting fresh water to the country, and bottled water is being distributed.

item.title: New Jersey governor Chris Christie didn't purposefully jam traffic.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: "Investigators found no conclusive evidence whether Christie was aware or not" of plans to shut down lanes of the George Washington Bridge for several days last September, allegedly to punish a local mayor who refused to help Christie get reelected. The scandal had marred Christie's viability as a US presidential candidate.

item.title: It took 20 years, but King Felipe's painting is finally done.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Antonio Lopez has literally spent decades painting a life-size portrait of the royal Spanish family. He finally unveiled his work at the Royal Palace in Madrid. The president of Spain's National Heritage commissioned the piece; Lopez says he went to the Royal Palace every day to paint for five hours.

item.title: Obama officially names his pick for US defense secretary.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Ashton Carter, previously the Pentagon's chief arms buyer and an assistant secretary of defense, is the US president's choice to replace the outgoing Chuck Hagel. Carter's appointment would require the approval of the Republican-led senate.

item.title: France to pay $60 million in reparations to Holocaust survivors.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: An estimated 76,000 Jews were transported on France's state-owned railway lines. The CEO of the train company, SNCF, acknowledged this back in 2010 when he announced his "profound sorrow and regret" for the company's involvement. French parliament still needs to sign off on the reparations—and they likely will.

item.title: James Watson's Nobel Prize sells for $4.8 million.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The man who discovered the structure of DNA sold the medal because he says the science community ostracized him after remarks made in 2007 on intelligence and race. Watson, the first living Nobel winner to sell his prize, says he'll donate some of the proceeds to charities that encourage scientific research.

item.title: ruble-vs-dollar-intraday-high-and-low-relative-to-opening-value-high-low_chartbuilder
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: The Orion test flight was a success.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: At 11:29 EST, the spacecraft that perhaps someday might be used to transport humans to Mars splashed down. Orion went up 100,000 ft. during a maiden voyage lasting four hours and 20 minutes.

item.title: More than 100,000 people evacuate the Philippines coastline.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Tropical cyclone Ruby—which has just been upgraded to super typhoon status—is less than 200 miles off land. The Red Cross says it has moved 20,000 families, and expects "a lot more are to come." The United Nations warns that as many 32 million people will be affected by the storm.

item.title: Sanctions have sent Russians' grocery bills soaring.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz

item.title: Time for Italy to get its credit card cut up?
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Standard & Poors downgraded the country's sovereign debt rating to BBB-, one notch above junk. The ratings agency said it expects Italy's sickly economy to grow by only 0.2% next year and then average 0.5% annual growth for the next few years after that.

item.title: China overtaking the US shouldn't keep you up at night.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It actually didn't, despite what you've been hearing. What should keep you awake and rocking in your chair, however, is the fact that China has been racking up trillions of dollars of debt that it will likely never repay. Gwynn Guilford says this will lead to China's inevitable slowdown.

item.title: Uruguay takes six from Guantanamo Bay.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Four Syrians, one Tunisian and one Palestinian have become the first to be transferred to a South American country from the American prison camp in Cuba. The transfer means 137 are still held in Guantanamo Bay—68 of them are considered low-level threats.

item.title: North Korea denies film hack.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The country praised the hacking of computer systems at Sony Pictures as a "righteous deed" but denied any role in the attack. Sony has made a comedy starring James Franco about assassinating Kim Jong-Un. North Korea said Sony was "abetting a terrorist act" making such a film.

item.title: Financial crisis? That's so 2008.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Morgan Stanley is to take a $1.2 billion quarterly charge (paywall) to pay its best bankers and traders earning more than $350,000 their bonuses upfront. The moves ends a trend of deferring bonuses in the aftermath of the crisis and subsequent bailouts—when the Federal Reserve kindly lent Morgan Stanley $107 billion.

item.title: Bird flu spreads in Canada.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: A fifth poultry farm in British Columbia has been quarantined (paywall) after testing indicated the H5 strain of the deadly virus. Some 80,000 birds in the first four farms are being culled; this latest farm has 60,000 birds. The US and other nations have already banned any imports from the province.

item.title: A raid in Yemen ends tragically.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The US led a raid on a site in southern Yemen that it said killed nine al-Qaeda fighters and eight civilians but resulted in two hostages—American photojournalist Luke Somers and South African teacher Pierre Korkie—being killed by their kidnappers. The US did not know that Korkie was being held with Somers.

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg hits back at Apple.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Apple seemed to take a shot at Google and Facebook for making money off private data earlier this year in its updated privacy statement. Now, the founder of Facebook responded in Time: "It's the most ridiculous concept. What, you think because you're paying Apple that you're somehow in alignment with them?" He also slammed the cost of Apple devices.

item.title: Iran braces for cheaper oil.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The country unveiled a draft budget for 2015 that is based on crude oil prices remaining around the current prices of $70 per barrel—oil has fallen 40% since June to five-year lows. President Hassan Rouhani said the fall in the price of oil will put "short-term pressure” on the government's budget.

item.title: Iran finally charges a US journalist—but with what?
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: The Washington Post's Jason Rezaian, arrested four months ago, has finally been charged by the theocratic regime in Tehran, but no details have been made available. US Secretary of State John Kerry who has been negotiating a nuclear deal with Iran, has expressed dismay.

item.title: Syria says Israeli jets bombed targets near Damascus.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: The Syrian army claims the targets were near the capital's main airport and a nearby town. No casualties have been reported; an Israeli army spokesman declined to comment.

item.title: Kim Il-sung had rice grains individually selected.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Dictators eat differently from you and me.

item.title: Your smartphone is more powerful than Orion's processors.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: NASA has a habit of using decade-old technology.

item.title: An ex-Apple exec is imprisoned for stealing iPhone secrets.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Paul Devine, Apple's global supply manager between 2005 and 2010, was convicted of selling inside information to iPhone suppliers. Devine was also ordered to repay Apple $4.5 million.

item.title: A UN climate group mulls an end to oil and gas by 2050.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Negotiators in Lima discussed phasing out the use of fossil fuels entirely, or restricting their use to countries with zero net emissions (paywall). Ministers are meeting ahead of a summit of world leaders next year in Paris.

item.title: Japan's recession is even worse than expected.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Third-quarter GDP shrank by an annualized 1.9%, compared with a preliminary finding of a 1.6% fall. Normally, such news would hurt prime minister Shinzo Abe, who is seeking reelection on the basis of his economic policies, but with the opposition in disarray Abe looks likely to remain in power until 2018.

item.title: An airplane has a near miss with a drone at Heathrow.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The UK’s Civil Aviation Authority confirmed an Airbus A320 came close to a helicopter-like drone as it was coming into land in July this year. The drone was thought to have been hovering at around 700 feet (213 meters) and disappeared after the encounter.

item.title: America's highest-paid private college president runs an obscure polytechnic
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: An Uber driver is arrested for rape in India.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Police said the suspect was arrested after a 27-year-old woman was sexually assaulted and beaten after booking an Uber ride on Friday night. Authorities said they would also take legal action against the controversial car service company for failing to run a background check on the driver.

item.title: North Korea suggests its sympathizers hacked Sony.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The country praised the theft and distribution of previously unreleased Sony Pictures movies as a “righteous deed,” and warned that hackers loyal to North Korea are to be found worldwide. Pyongyang denied having a direct role in the attack.

item.title: Russian prison guards are told to tell more jokes.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: “You can’t base relations on fear and submission alone,” says one researcher.

item.title: Prince William meets Barack Obama.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The second-in-line to the British throne will meet the US president at the White House before speaking at the World Bank on global wildlife trafficking. William’s wife Kate, the Duchess of Cambridge, is staying behind in New York.

item.title: Uber is banned in Delhi after an alleged rape.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: City authorities cracked down on the on-demand car service after one of its drivers was accused of raping a passenger on Friday. Uber CEO Travis Kalanick offered to work with the government to improve the company's background checks; the accused driver was previously arrested for rape.

item.title: Hong Kong protestors vow to stay on the streets.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A spokeswoman for the Hong Kong Federation of Students said the group was no longer considering plans to vacate the streets (paywall) they have occupied for more than two months. The government is expected to start final attempts to clear demonstration zones as early as Wednesday.

item.title: Singapore Airlines accidentally sold business class tickets at economy prices.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It will honor all customers who snapped up a bargain.

item.title: Canada and Britain close their Cairo embassies.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The US embassy remains open, but Canada's is shuttered, "due to unsettled security conditions." Likewise the British embassy, which has issued this polite warning to nationals: "Please do not come to the embassy building."

item.title: China's imports take a sharp tumble.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: November was rough according to the latest figures. Exports were up 4.7% year over year, but imports had their biggest drop since March—6.7%. "This means that pressure will rise on the government to do more to stimulate growth," said an analyst, knowing full well the country already lowered its base interest rate last month.

item.title: Sony's PlayStation network is hacked again.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The group "Lizard Squad" is taking credit for the latest outage to the Japanese company's gaming service, using Twitter to say: "PSN Login #offline #LizardSquad." This is the latest in a string of attacks on Sony: last month, hackers released the salary information of thousands of employees and Hollywood celebrities.

item.title: A window into the mind of Albert Einstein is online.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Princeton is hosting a vast collection of the iconic physicist's personal correspondence and notes on its website, for free. The collection is set to grow from the current 13 volumes to span 30 volumes in all.

item.title: Sierra Leone has lost its 10th doctor to Ebola.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Aiah Solomon Konoyeima passed away on Sunday. Ebola has an estimated fatality rate of 60%, but with 10 of 11 infected doctors dead, the virus is now being called the "caretaker's disease."

item.title: The US is set to unveil new rules on racial profiling.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In attorney general Eric Holder's own words: "Profiling by law enforcement is not only wrong, it is profoundly misguided and ineffective—because it wastes precious resources and undermines the public trust." Whether or not authorities follow his guidelines, especially once Loretta Lynch takes over, is another story altogether.

item.title: The UN is asking for $16.4 billion in humanitarian aid.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It's a new record for the organization: last year, it asked for $13 billion. Over half the money, $7.2 billion, will go helping Syrian refugees. According to the latest estimates, the country's civil war has displaced nearly 11 million people.

item.title: Godzilla is returning to Japan in 2016.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Toho studios—which holds the rights to the sea-monster franchise—feels like it can do a better job than the American pretenders. "The time has come for Japan to make a film that will not lose to Hollywood," said Taichi Ueda, the head of the project. Toho's last Godzilla flick, from 2004, tanked.

item.title: Greece takes a big gamble.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The government called for a presidential vote later this month that could trigger a general election. Syriza, a left-wing party that wants to scrap EU-mandated austerity measures, is leading in the polls. Greek stocks are plunging today on fears of a renewed financial crisis.

item.title: Typhoon Hagupit hangs over Peru.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Metaphorically, that is; the storm that just racked the Philippines will be the ghost at the banquet for the ministers from 190 countries meeting in Lima to finalize details on tackling climate change. The UN last week said estimates of the costs of adaptation over the next 35 years might be 2-3 times too low.

item.title: Most Americans say the internet is actually making them smarter
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: The US Senate publishes its controversial report on CIA torture.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The "brutal" interrogations often produced "fabricated" information, said the chair of the US Senate intelligence committee—Dianne Feinstein—presenting the report (pdf). Republicans have warned that the details in the report will spark "violence and deaths," and that Americans overseas should make sure they're safe.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Feinstein and her colleagues are spoke about the report on CIA interrogation methods (YouTube). The BBC, the Guardian, and the New York Times are all live-blogging their findings.

item.title: Portland sues Uber.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The city said the on-demand car service fails to comply with health and safety regulations. Uber talked with officials for several months before it launched the service on Friday without an agreement with the city; Portland is threatening fines of up to $5,000 for Uber drivers.

item.title: Hong Kong issues an eviction notice to the Umbrella Movement.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The High Court published a notice in the city’s newspaper saying that bailiffs and police will enforce an injunction to clear out the central pro-democracy protest site on Thursday. Protesters vowed to resist the decision, and the city’s strategy may have a glaring flaw.

item.title: New evidence that Mars was suitable for life.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: NASA’s Curiosity rover found clear signs that a 96-mile wide crater once contained large lakes, rivers, and deltas, bolstering the theory that Mars was capable of supporting microbial life billions of years ago.

item.title: Edward Glazer puts 3 million Manchester United shares up for sale.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The sell-off could earn $45 million for the son of late owner Malcom Glazer. Edward and his five siblings received an equal split comprising 90% of the club’s shares following their father’s death eight months ago.

item.title: Hackers demand Sony withdraw The Interview.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The “Guardians of Peace” group warned that the private data of two Sony executives would be made public if the company did not “stop immediately showing the movie of terrorism which can break the regional peace.” The film may actually get a boost from the recent publicity.

item.title: A TGI Fridays mistletoe drone ends badly.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The owner said a bloody accident wouldn’t have happened if the victim hadn’t flinched.

item.title: A Korean Air executive went nuts.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The daughter of the airline’s boss deplaned a flight attendant for improper macadamia protocol.

item.title: Some of the air leaves China's stock bubble.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Shanghai's benchmark stock index dropped 5.4%, the largest one-day fall in five years, as big Chinese bank and energy stocks plummeted. After the index climbed about 40% this year, highly-leveraged investors may be losing their nerve, especially as oil prices and emerging-market currencies continue to weaken.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_308851" align="alignleft" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Australia is the dirtiest industrialized country.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That's according to a report (pdf) published by Germanwatch and CAN Europe on the world's top 58 emitters of carbon dioxide. Denmark is the best, then Sweden, and then the UK. Why is Australia so dirty? The conservative government has reversed numerous climate policies, including the repeal of carbon taxes.

item.title: Cheap credit will keep Boeing busy next year.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The aircraft maker predicts aircraft financing will hit $124 billion in 2015 as companies place orders for more than 1,300 planes (paywall). This year, Boeing and Airbus together built over 1,200 planes. Boeing says China holds the most aircraft debt, then Germany and Japan, while the US holds just 9% of the market.

item.title: Abercrombie & Fitch lets its CEO go.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Effective immediately, Michael Jeffries is out as both CEO and as a board member of the clothing maker with a reputation of only hiring beautiful people to work at its retail stores. Jeffries' successor hasn't been named, but the board said it's begun looking at both internal and external candidates.

item.title: France just freed its final hostage.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It took three years, but Serge Lazarevic is coming home. He was captured in Mali in Nov. 2011 along with Philippe Verdon, who was executed last year. Lazarevic was one of at least 14 French nationals captured by Islamists in West Africa, but president François Hollande says there are now no more French hostages anywhere in the world. That, Barack Obama has peevishly said (paywall), is because France pays ransoms.

item.title: The EU's 2015 budget has been set at €141.2 billion.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It's slightly higher than 2014's budget of €139 billion ($172 billion), and assuming it gets approved without any complaints, lawmakers will sign off on the numbers within a week. The UK, which was supposed to put an extra €2.1 billion into the euro zone's coffers, got a 10-month extension on that bill.

item.title: Social media saves the day in Syria.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Earlier this month, the World Food Program stopped handing out food vouchers to Syrian refugees who fled to neighboring countries—it simply ran out of money. But after the organization started a social media campaign asking for 64 million people to give just $1, the response proved so overwhelming the vouchers were reinstated.

item.title: Spain becomes the latest country to ban Uber.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A rape allegation shut Uber down in India earlier this week. Now a judge in Spain has decided to axe the car-sharing service because it's "unfair competition" for local cab drivers. Over on the other side of the pond, the US city of Portland sued Uber less than a week after going live.

item.title: The US job market is accelerating.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: The end of an era at Bloomberg News.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Matthew Winkler, who was the news organization's founding editor, oversaw its growth to 2,400 journalists, and created its oddly strict style, the "Bloomberg Way," is stepping aside to become "editor-in-chief emeritus." John Micklethwait, the editor-in-chief of The Economist, will replace him.

item.title: Citigroup has some pretty expensive lawyers.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The company said it will swallow an uncomfortably large $3.5 billion charge in its fourth quarter, all but wiping out any profit. That sum includes a $2.7 billion bill for the legal case brought against Citigroup—and several other banks—alleging that they rigged interest rates and foreign-exchange markets.

item.title: The US averts a shutdown, for a few months at least.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: House and Senate leaders agreed to finance most of the government through September. But a provision to fund homeland security was only approved through February; Republicans want to use it as leverage to fight president Barack Obama's executive order on immigration.

item.title: JPMorgan Chase falls $22 billion short of proposed capital requirements.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: While discussing the new US rules aimed at increasing capital held by systemically important banks, the Federal Reserve accidentally let slip (paywall) that the bank was responsible for the entire shortfall, which it had previously said was shared between eight banks.

item.title: Yum Brands lowers its outlook on weak China sales.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The KFC and Pizza Hut owner cut its 2014 and 2015 earnings forecasts, as it struggled to win back customers in China—which accounts for more than half (paywall) of its sales—after a July food safety scandal.

item.title: A Harvard professor went to war over $4.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: He threatened a lawsuit over a takeout Chinese menu price discrepancy.

item.title: Hip-hop’s royal couple meet Will and Kate.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Beyonce and Jay Z entertained their fellow royals at a basketball game.

item.title: Even the UK police are playing the London real estate boom.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Scotland Yard flipped its headquarters for a 3x profit in just six years.

item.title: Most people (including men) in India would not be comfortable hiring an Uber car.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: New Luxembourg leaks implicate Disney and Koch Industries.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Documents revealing secret tax deals between 35 multinational companies and the Luxembourg government were released, describing efforts to cut their worldwide tax bills and adding to an earlier pile published last month.

item.title: Sony’s CEO had final cut approval for The Interview.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Kazuo Hirai personally cleared the violent finale to the Seth Rogen comedy about North Korean dictator Kim Jong-un, according to documents leaked by anonymous hackers who may be aligned with Kim’s regime.

item.title: TIME honors those on the front lines of the battle against Ebola.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The deadly virus has been called a "caretakers' disease" because it has claimed the lives of a hundreds of doctors and nurses. And yet the healthcare workers trying to contain Ebola soldier on, which is why they have been recognized as TIME's people of the year.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The head of the World Health Organization says the virus's spread is still "running ahead of us," and that the death toll has hit 6,331, with over 17,800 people infected.

item.title: Uber is sued by another two US cities.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles and San Francisco are skeptical of the way the car-hailing service screens its drivers, among other issues, so the cities are taking the company to court. Portland, Oregon did the same thing just yesterday. In related bad Uber news, yet another driver is facing a rape allegation, this time in Chicago.

item.title: HSBC has "let go" the head of its European foreign exchange division.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Stuart Scott was in charge of the bank's forex unit during a scandal over attempts to rig exchange rates, which resulted in regulators levying a $618 million fine. HSBC wasn't alone: Five other banks also were hit with penalties totaling $4.3 billion.

item.title: Catholic bishops are demanding an end to fossil fuel use.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Bishops from every continent have called upon the 1.2 billion Catholics worldwide to support renewable energy at a climate change conference in Lima, Peru. "As the church, we see and feel an obligation for us to protect creation and to challenge the misuse of nature," said the archbishop of Ayacucho.

item.title: HBO's chief technology officer resigns.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Otto Berkes is leaving the US premium-cable-television provider because, well, let's be honest: HBO Go, the company's service that lets customers consume its content over an internet connection, was never a home run. For its 2015 rollout of a standalone internet service, HBO has decided to license the technology that Major League Baseball developed in-house.

item.title: A Palestinian cabinet member dies after a scuffle with Israeli troops.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Witnesses said an Israeli officer roughly handled the 55-year-old Ziad Abu Ain, who collapsed and died after a demonstration in which Palestinian protesters were tear-gassed. Palestinian authority president Mahmoud Abbas said he'll wait for an autopsy to determine the cause of Abu Ain's death, which he called a "barbaric act."

item.title: Russia's prime minister urges people not to panic over the plunging ruble.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Dmitry Medvedev wants to make sure people don't move their savings out of the motherland. The currency has fallen by roughly 40% against the dollar this year following sanctions imposed over Moscow's annexation of Crimea from Ukraine. The collapse of oil prices—and with them a key source of Russia's revenue—hasn't helped the mood.

item.title: The Oscar Pistorius case isn't over yet.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A South African judge has granted state prosecutors' request to revisit the track star's conviction for negligent killing in the shooting death of his girlfriend. They are seeking a murder conviction, and have called his five-year sentence "shockingly light." Pistorius will face a panel of five new judges in an appeals court.

item.title: A chance to relive the early 1990s as a maniacal virtual city planner.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Sim City 2000—along with all the video game's game's expansion packs—are now available for free to anyone using a PC through Electronic Arts' online game distribution service, Origin. The 20-year-old game allows players to build meticulously detailed cities, and also offers various natural disasters to inflict upon them.

item.title: Brent crude falls below $65 a barrel.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: It's the lowest level in over five years, driven by signals from Saudi Arabia that it won't cut production and OPEC forecasts of falling demand. Two US shale producers scaled back their investment plans (paywall), but the promise of cheap fuel has sent airline stocks ever upwards.

item.title: Google News will close in Spain.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The search giant's move was forced by a new law that allows Spanish media to charge websites that aggregate their content, dubbed a "Google tax." The site will close in Spain on December 16 and Spanish publishers will be removed from global Google News search results.

item.title: McDonald's is trimming its menu.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The fast food chain said it would reduce the number of items on its US menus and use fewer ingredients in its food, after a year of slowing sales. The simplification is part of a plan to allow greater customization of meals, in an attempt to meet competition from chains such as Subway and Chipotle.

item.title: Elon Musk isn't worried about what cheap oil is doing to Tesla's share price.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Two female suicide bombers attack a Nigerian market.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Four people were killed in the bombing near a market in the northern part of the country. Boko Haram is suspected of organizing the attack.

item.title: A Chinese power plant is burning money.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Old and damaged bank notes are cleaner than coal.

item.title: Dressing like Santa is a human right.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: New York’s SantaCon is lawyering up to defend its annual pub crawl.

item.title: Xiaomi is banned from selling in India.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Sony Ericsson obtained an injunction against the Chinese smartphone maker from a high court in India, after it alleged that Xiaomi's handsets infringe on its patents. Xiaomi said it's yet to receive an official notice from Indian authorities.

item.title: Peter Thiel is disrupted.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Activists protesting the police killings of two unarmed black men took over a UC Berkeley venue where the PayPal founder was speaking. The demonstrators also shut down three metro stations, in the fifth night of occasionally violent protests.

item.title: Sony Pictures hacks the hackers.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The studio, suffering from a high-profile cyberattack, is trying to flood illicit download sites with erroneous data to limit access to its sensitive files. But the countermeasures are reportedly quite easy to evade.

item.title: Russia tries to salvage the ruble.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The central bank raised its benchmark rate from 9.5% to 10.5%—its fifth hike of the year—in an attempt to combat inflation and bolster the ruble’s value. The currency has fallen 40% against the dollar this year, going increasingly haywire as oil prices slide and Western sanctions bite.

item.title: eBay is considering firing 10% of its employees.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That's 3,000 people. An unnamed source told the The Wall Street Journal (paywall) that the bulk of cuts would be in the online retailer's marketplace division, which includes eBay.com and StubHub. As the company prepares to split from its PayPal payments unit, lowering its operating costs might attract more buyout firms.

item.title: Microsoft now accepts bitcoin.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The software company has announced that if you want to top-up your Microsoft account using the new digital currency, you can, and then spend it on video games, apps, music, and movies on Xbox consoles and Windows device."

item.title: US shoppers got busy in November.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The country's retail sales jumped 0.7% year-over-year last month, beating expectations of 0.4%. Economists credit cheap gas prices and healthy job growth, which has allowed Americans to spend more on holiday shopping. The average gallon of gas in the US now costs $2.62, down $1.00 from its April peak.

item.title: Scandinavia is suddenly looking shaky.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Norway's central bank unexpectedly cut interest rates to "prevent a severe downturn" thanks to plunging oil prices. In Denmark, the government slashed its growth outlook for this year and next, in response to weakness in its main export markets elsewhere in Europe. Finally, Sweden recorded yet another month of deflation.

item.title: Russia's rate hikes can't stem the ruble's decline.
item.dc:creator: qzroya

item.title: The biggest storm in five years is hitting Northern California.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Expected to be one of the windiest and rainiest in years, the storm prompted area residents to close schools, cancel classes and hoard provisions. The storm's intensity is ratcheting up thanks to moisture originating from Hawaii, also known as the "Pineapple Express."

item.title: China is reportedly pumping 400 billion yuan into its banks.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The roughly $65 billion cash injection to spur economic growth comes amid a three-day closed-door conference among top Chinese officials to set the country's yearly economic priorities.  Economists expect the debt-ridden country to lower its GDP target to 7% at an annual meeting in March.

item.title: Facebook doesn't want to see you drunk.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The social networking company already has access to all your photos. When it comes that with artificial intelligence, it's able to tell some interesting, including—one day—the ability to detect whether a photo you're about to share is unflattering. Earlier this year, Google spent $500 million to buy its own AI firm: DeepMind.

item.title: Wall Street is enamored with peer-to-peer lending.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Shares of LendingClub, the world's largest online loan marketplace, shot up 67% just a few hours after they began trading today. The firm, which has facilitated $6 billion in peer-to-peer loans, reported a slight loss for the first nine months of this year. But investors hope it can take over the market for risky loans traditional banks have shunned.

item.title: International Yoga Day is now a thing.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The United Nations has decreed that every year on June 21 the world should celebrate the activity that, according to Indian prime minister Narendra Modi, can help solve the world's problems. Yoga does, after all, make you healthier and less aggressive.

item.title: Dinosaurs needed to perish for today's birds to come about.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: According to the results of a four year study on avian genetics, it turns out that shortly after an astroid wipes out the creatures that inspire endless action movie remakes, there were roughly 15 million years of explosive evolution that gave rise to 95% of today's flying birds (paywall).

item.title: Banks get nabbed for conflicts in the Toys "R" Us IPO.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: America's financial industry regulator fined 10 financial firms (paywall) a total of $43.5 million for allowing their research analysts to woo Toys "R" Us as an IPO client in 2010 by offering favorable research coverage. The crackdown comes more than a decade after a notorious period of analyst bias at Wall Street investment banks.

item.title: After the Umbrella Movement, Hong Kong's media is more XX than ever
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: In its treaty with Britain when it regained control of Hong Kong, Beijing vowed to preserve freedom of speech, as enshrined in the region's mini-constitution, the Basic Law. But the last few years have been particularly grim ones for journalistic freedom—the Hong Kong Journalists Association called them the "darkest for press freedom for several decades” (pdf, p.2). The Umbrella Movement has only highlighted the divide between Hong Kong's largely pro-Beijing news coverage and a few pro-democracy media outlets—with surprising consequences. While Beijing's [caption id="attachment_311122" align="alignright" width="320"] The sad slide of Hong Kong's press freedoms.the only thing this has changed with the Umbrella Movement is that the erosions of Hong Kong's freedom of expression have grown much starker.[/caption] In the run-up to the protests, the Chinese government lectured Hong Kong's media on the need to cover anti-Occupy Central protests (often led by apparently pro-government toadies) LINK? . By the time the Umbrella Movement began, only the Apple Daily, a pro-democracy tabloid, could boast being fully free of self-censorship or more overt pro-Beijing editorial meddling. In the two months since, Jimmy Lai, a media tycoon and the tabloid's editor, was pelted with organs and his paper's delivery trucks blocked by reportedly pro-Beijing demonstrators. Yesterday, Lai announced that he was both under arrest and stepping down from his role as editor-in-chief. The South China Morning Post, once one of the most respected papers in Asia, has been accused of leaning increasingly Beijing-ward of late. But when the protests began, the newspaper started a live blog, and then put it outside the paper's paywall.   offered rigorous, balanced coverage as the Umbrella Movement unfolded—possibly because Wang Xiangwei, SCMP's editor and a former member of the Orwellian Chinese people's Political Consultative Conference, was on vacation, according to three current and former editors. The tone of the online reportage often contrasted sharply with the SCMP editorial page's anti-protest rhetoric. The protests helped the SCMP double and even occasionally triple its daily unique visitors while the protests were underway, according to an internal memo distributed to staff, but it also rattled Beijing. The SCMP's Chinese-language site, Nanzao.com, has been blocked in mainland China since the protests began, for reasons not entirely clear. Beijing certainly wanted to limit mainland access to information the protests, but also may have been punishing the paper for deviating from the party line that the protesters were unruly hooligans. (Demonstrators were in fact, for the most part, extremely polite.) Meanwhile, after the television station TVB edited out details from its report on an alleged police attack on a protester (paywall)— (and cementing the station's the nickname "CCTVB," a reference to Beijing's party mouthpiece, CCTV)—57 of its journalists risked their jobs by signing a letter of protest.   And scores of journalists were physically assaulted by police and anti-Occupy protesters. Now that the protest encampments are largely gone, the media landscape of Hong Kong seems even more tilted in Beijing's favor—with Wang and his pro-Beijing owners firmly in control at the SCMP, and the future of the Apple Daily uncertain with Jimmy Lai on the sidelines. Perhaps the lone bright spot for protesters is how the Umbrella Movement crystallized the exponential growth of social media, using channels that largely defy the ability of any corporate owners or even government censors to control what is reported. That includes citizen journalism on Twitter and Facebook, widespread use of messaging apps, including those like FireChat that don't even require an internet connection, and even professional journalists at pro-Beijing outlets reporting on the sly.

item.title: The US averts a government shutdown by a few scant hours.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The House passed a $1.1 trillion spending bill after president Barack Obama and vice president Joe Biden called lawmakers to ensure their support. Current government funding run out at 5am Friday GMT, and bipartisan support was required to secure new funds.

item.title: Hong Kong police release 247 protestors.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: All of the activists detained during Thursday’s demolition of the city’s main pro-democracy encampment have been released, but police reserved the right to prosecute them at a later date. Student leader Joshua Wong said his Scholarism group has no plans for further civil disobedience.

item.title: Jack Ma is the richest man in Asia.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The founder of Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba took the title from Li Ka-shing, a Hong Kong property tycoon, as Alibaba's stock climbed. Ma is worth $28.6 billion according to Bloomberg, and Alibaba has a market capitalization of $259 billion.

item.title: The CIA defends its use of torture.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Director John Brennan told reporters it was "unknowable" whether so-called enhanced interrogation techniques produced useful intelligence, and admitted that some officers used "abhorrent," unauthorized techniques. But the agency acted correctly to keep the US secure, Brennan said.

item.title: China buys one of Australia's biggest builders.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: State-owned construction firm CCCI will pay A$1.15 billion ($950 million) for John Holland (paywall), a major building and engineering company. The countries signed a free-trade agreement last month and Australia is planning a multibillion-dollar infrastructure building program.

item.title: Old school media love AwesomenessTV.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Magazine publisher Hearst bought a 25% stake (paywall) in the digital video network aimed at teenagers, suggesting a valuation of $325 million less than two years after DreamWorks Animation paid $33 million for the company. AwesomenessTV manages 90,000 channels on YouTube and boasts 114 million subscribers.

item.title: NFL players are taking untested stem cell treatments.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: They could end up growing body parts where they don’t belong.

item.title: China can’t quit big tobacco.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Its state-owned monopoly made 43% of all cigarettes produced last year—2.3 trillion to be exact.

item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded:
TOKYO—Democratic elections are not supposed to have pre-determined outcomes, yet Japan’s Sunday election is guaranteed to keep prime minister Shinzo Abe in power. But there is more at stake than a rubber-stamp victory for the creator of Abenomics: the results will impact Japan’s political and economic climate for years to come.

An election about…something?

Many in Japan do not know what they are supposed to be voting for. Abe’s government, seeking approval for its controversial economic policies, has insisted the election—which it is numerically assured of winning—is a referendum on the economy. Specifically, on his decision last month to scrap an October 2015 sales tax hike, after gross domestic product figures suggested the country had unexpectedly slipped into a recession due to weak consumer, business spending, and an earlier sales tax hike. His Liberal Democratic Party is campaigning under the rather grim slogan “to revive the economy, there is no other way.”

An Asahi newspaper poll found that 60% of voters disapprove of his decision to call the snap election. Even if that is the case, there is essentially no alternative to an Abe government. The opposition Democratic Party of Japan is fielding 198 candidates, compared with the LDP’s 352. There are 475 seats up for grabs. It is impossible for any other party to take a majority.

Japan is suffering from election fatigue

The country has had three national votes since the end of 2012. Voters are also being asked to cast ballots in local elections next year. The cluster of elections is especially a challenge to minor parties that rely on voter activism.

Timing is everything

“It is clear that his decision to call an election is based on the political calculation that he has a better chance for a victory now rather than later,” the Asahi wrote in an editorial.

The vote, however, may be the last for four years in Japan’s more powerful lower parliament, and it will give the prime minister some much-needed breathing space after a very difficult autumn. In September, a reshuffle brought five women to his cabinet, which was touted as evidence that his policies were helping to bring more women into the workplace. But two of the women quickly resigned because of separate financial scandals, and those who remained have been accused of being sympathetic to Japan’s far right. Abe is still trying to find a balance between a cabinet that is favorable to his conservative base but also satisfies those looking for a more open Japan.

The country is grappling with more than just Abenomics

The prime minister's plan for a new base in Okinawa Prefecture have been rejected by voters there. Other challenges facing the government include its quest to revive nuclear power, still contentious after the Fukushima disaster, but essential to reversing Japan's trade deficit. Abe's government also just passed a new national security law that punishes the leaking of state secrets with jail sentences of up to 10 years. Critics say it is overly broad and could be used to muzzle the press.

In short, Abe is sending Japan in a direction many disagree with; gaining more time with a convincing election win will give him more political capital.

And there's still the economy, stupid

The prime minister, however, insists this vote is about the economy. And if his previous term in office was defined by anything, it is the huge amount of money the governent is pumping into the economy by buying bonds and other financial instruments. Now comes the more difficult task of backing up the stimulus with lasting structural reforms that fundamentally change the way the Japanese economy operates.

“Apparently, Abe is starting to realize that his grand plan may not work,” economist Nouriel Roubini’s Edge team wrote in a recent report. One problem is that his government itself is divided; Teneo Intelligence’s Tobias Harris sees Abe’s coming problem as “resistance to his government’s initiatives from the bureaucracy, the LDP’s backbenches, and [its coalition partner] Komeito.”

If that resistance rises, Abe’s true test will comes in September, when his party votes for a leader. If it chooses someone else, Japan may see a new prime minister. But at least the public won't be dragged out to the polls again for that vote.

item.title: Baidu buys into Uber.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Chinese search giant will invest cash and assets worth up to $600 million in return for a minority stake in the on-demand car service, which is currently expanding in China. In addition to the financing, Uber will get some much-needed expertise from a local partner as it faces widespread regulatory challenges around the world.

item.title: This is why Saudi Arabia can afford a price war on oil.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Facebook is thinking about letting you not like things.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The social network's well-recognized "like" button—portrayed as a thumbs-up icon—doesn't have a counterbalanced "dislike" button, but that might change. CEO Mark Zuckerberg says he's contemplating adding the feature, but only if he figures out how to make sure no one uses it to be mean.

item.title: Chicago and New York want to clone Uber.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The two US cities figure hey, if people like using the car-sharing app because it's convenient, why not make apps themselves? The plan's already been approved in Chicago, but there's no timeline for the app's deployment. In New York, it's still just a proposal (paywall).

item.title: Google is pulling its engineers out of Russia.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: When the search giant opened a facility in Moscow in 2006, it was well before Putin started cracking down on internet companies. But the president's latest moves have pushed Mountain View, California-based Google to decide to leave—putting, according to The Information, more than 50 employees in a tricky situation (paywall).

item.title: Gucci's power couple say goodbye.
item.dc:creator: javinsqz
item.content:encoded: Chief executive officer Patrizio di Marco and creative director Frida Giannini will leave the brand—he at end of the year and she after February's autumn show. Marco Bizzarri, who oversees luxury couture and leather goods at Gucci's parent, Kering, will take over as CEO. Speculation about who will replace Giannini has already begun.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Gucci represents more than half of Kering's luxury revenues, and sales have recently lagged, hurt by a slowdown in Chinese spending as well as a general lack of excitement around the house's collections (which have recently leaned heavily on 1970s references).

item.title: Shots were fired at the Israeli embassy in Athens.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It's not yet known how many attackers there were, or who they represent, but reports say "dozens" of rounds have hit the building's wall. Police have recovered 54 bullet casings, which they say came from two different AK-47s. No injuries or deaths have been reported.

item.title: SoftBank is moving its Silicon Valley employees to Kansas.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Japanese telecommunications operator, who has been trying to buy T-Mobile USA for about a year now, has reportedly given up. Reuters says it's moving "the bulk" of it's employees to Kansas, home of Sprint—the US operator that SoftBank merged with in July of last year.

item.title: In southern Germany, buildings for asylum seekers were burned and painted with swastikas.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The incident, which occurred Thursday night in a small town near Nuremberg, saw three buildings damaged to the tune of 700,000 euros ($872,000). No one was injured or killed since the buildings weren't occupied, they were merely designated as homes for future refugees.

item.title: Forget being green, Europe wants its economy to grow.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A leaked document obtained by the BBC suggests that the EU is thinking about walking back legislation aimed at curbing air pollution and waste production—mainly because it would slow down some much-needed economic expansion.

item.title: Shanghai-Composite-Index-year-to-date-performance-rate_chartbuilder
item.dc:creator: jasonqz

item.title: B4bHmTwCUAADwZk
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Strikes are slowing the already unhurried pace of Italian life.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Trade unions across the country are furious with prime minister Matteo Renzi's job reforms, which make it easier for companies to fire people. Many government services that citizens depend on, such as public transportation, were shut down. That won't help the economic problems that Renzi says he's trying to solve.

item.title: A computer failure put London's airspace in restricted mode.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Earlier today, Eurocontrol said that all flights in and out of London will be grounded until 19:00 GMT. Heathrow, the biggest hub in Europe, tweeted that flights are experiencing delays. A power outage at the Swanwick air traffic control center in Hampshire, England, was blamed. The glitch has been fixed, but expect delays.

item.title: Vodafone is coming back to the US next year—kind of.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The British telecom operator—with operations in numerous countries—will resell access to T-Mobile USA's network in late 2015. The arrangement is known as an MVNO—Mobile Virtual Network Operator. Vodafone used to own a 45% stake in Verizon Wireless, America's largest mobile operator, but it sold it for $130 billion earlier this year.

item.title: Future proofing today better than the Egyptians did.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Picture, for a moment, what the Westerners who saw hieroglyphics thought to themselves after seeing the elaborate stone carvings for the first time. Grayson Clary at Aeon Magazine thinks tomorrow's explorers will look at our world in much the same way—he also wonders why we care about Egypt's past so much?

item.title: Climate change talks reach a deal.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Two days late, talks in Lima reached an agreement that, for the first time, commits even the fast-growing, heavy-polluting developing countries to cut emissions (pdf). But negotiators postponed the hardest talks to the major UN conference in Paris next year.

item.title: Uber also gets some Chinese money.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The WSJ reported that Baidu, the Chinese search engine, will announce an unknown amount of investment next week (paywall), which will help the taxi app grow in China. Uber recently said it had raised $1.2 billion to “make substantial investments, particularly in the Asia Pacific region,” valuing the firm at $40 billion.

item.title: London air traffic is almost back to normal.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: After a computer glitch the likes of "which has not been seen before," flights around Heathrow, the world's second-busiest airport, are nearly back to the usual levels, though 40 were still cancelled on Saturday. That said, Heathrow by some measures remains the world’s most fragile major airport.

item.title: A lot of Americans got married on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Saturday was Dec. 13th, 2014—or for people using the US date format of month/day/year: 12/13/14. That is the last sequential calendar date for at least 20 years, until 1/2/34. One chapel in Las Vegas planned to marry 120 couples.

item.title: Protests against police brutality across the US.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Demonstrations were held on Saturday in several large US cities over the killings by police of unarmed black men. A "Millions March" in New York attracted about 25,000-50,000, and an estimated 10,000 marched in Washington, DC.

item.title: Climate change negotiators reach a deal.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Two days late, environment ministers announced an agreement that, for the first time, would require all countries to cut greenhouse gas emissions—even fast-growing heavy-polluting developing economies. But negotiators postponed the most contentious issues until next year's UN conference in Paris, and said their agreement would not be sufficient to limit warming or protect poor countries from climate change.

item.title: Abe seeks a new mandate.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Japan is voting in a snap election called by prime minister Shinzo Abe, which polls suggest is likely to extend his huge majority (paywall) in the lower house of parliament. The world's third-largest economy is in recession—and Abenomics is still being touted as the cure.

item.title: Haiti's PM quits after protests.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Following sometime-violent demonstrations against delayed elections, Haitian prime minister Laurent Lamothe has resigned. Protestors want the president, Michel Martelly, to go as well. Martelly will be able to rule by decree once parliament's term expires in January.

item.title: The year's largest US private equity deal.
item.dc:creator: qzroya
item.content:encoded: Pet products retailer PetSmart agreed to be purchased by a consortium led by London-based private equity firm BC Partners for $8.7 billion, including debt. Activists had been pressuring the company to sell itself due to fierce competition from Amazon.com and other online retailers.

item.title: A hostage crisis in Sydney.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: At least one gunmen has taken as many as 40 people hostage in a Lindt chocolate shop in Australia's biggest city. Two hostages were forced to hold a black flag with Arabic script up to the window, though it does not look like the ISIL flag. Here's how to follow the situation in real time.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Stop calling this the flag in the Sydney Lindt hostage situation the #ISIS flag. It's clearly a different flag. pic.twitter.com/7141F7pzk6

— Gideon Lichfield (@glichfield) December 14, 2014

item.title: Shinzo Abe is handily re-elected as Japan's prime minister.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Abe's Liberal Democratic Party won 325 of 475 seats in an election that the LDP described as a mandate over Abe's economic reforms. The outcome was assured from the start; the opposition fielded only 198 candidates.

item.title: Sony Pictures tries to stop the presses.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The studio sent letters to Bloomberg and the New York Times requesting they stop reporting on the contents of the company's hacked computers. The script for the next James Bond film was among the documents leaked.

item.title: Hong Kong police dismantle the Umbrella Movement’s last outpost.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Authorities evicted pro-democracy protesters from their remaining protest site in Causeway Bay, removing tents and barricades and arresting over a dozen demonstrators. Protest groups are proposing a new round of civil disobedience now that their encampments are gone.

item.title: China has a new microwave-powered pain gun.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It’s supposed to be mounted on navy ships.

item.title: A ongoing hostage crisis in Sydney.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A gunman—Man Haron Monis—with a black Islamic flag has taken about 15 people hostage at a cafe in the city's business district. Five hostages have fled the scene, but police say the siege could continue through the night. Few details are known about the hostage-taker's demands, identity, or motivation.

item.title: More people are reporting US universities for not dealing with sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Uber's Sydney gaffe.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The company's surge pricing during a terror attack shows that there's an Uber for everything—except crisis communications.

item.title: Turkey arrests at least 24 media staffers.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Personnel from a newspaper and a TV station with close links to an opposition leader were detained for trying to “seize control of the state.” EU representatives warned the detentions “went against European values.”

item.title: China bans its own national anthem at weddings.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Only “certain dignified events” can feature it from now on.

item.title: A Texan snuck into North Korea last month.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Arturo Pierre Martinez, 29, made an appearance on the country's state-run news network on Sunday, where he went on a lengthy tirade about the United States, going so far as to call it a "Mafia enterprise" when describing its actions in Iraq. Martinez was not in North Korean custody and is seeking asylum in Venezuela.

item.title: An Al-Qaeda linked group seizes a Syrian military base.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The al-Nusra Front, as they're known, joined forces with another group known as Jund al-Aqsa, and have taken over Wadi al-Deif. It's being reported that 31 soldiers and 12 rebels were killed. The Syrian Observatory says the group used tanks and heavy weaponry that they captured from the Syrian Revolutionary Front, which is backed by the West.

item.title: France bans UberPop—but not Uber itself.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: UberPop—the company's cheapest tier of service, which allows anyone with a car to offer rides—will be illegal starting Jan. 1. The lack of proper licensing and insurance makes UberPop "a real danger" to consumers, according to an interior ministry spokesman (paywall).

item.title: Police capture three Belgians who took a person hostage.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It's not yet known why these men took barged into an apartment and captured someone, but two months ago a similar situation occurred and it was all about securing a ransom. The hostage is unharmed.

item.title: Oil hits a new five-year low—and Indonesia is among those feeling the pain.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The price of crude touched $60 a barrel early on Monday before bouncing back up to $63. This sent the rupiah, Indonesia's currency, plunging to levels that haven't been seen since the mid-90s Asian financial crisis. Russia is in a similar boat—it forecast a contracting economy for 2015 and the ruble is in free fall.

item.title: There are only five northern white rhinos left.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: An elderly male named Angalifu died at the San Diego Zoo on Sunday. There are no known northern white rhinos in the wild—largely because poachers kill rhinos for their horns, which are used as a party drug and a medicine in parts of Asia, despite being chemically pretty much the same as fingernail clippings.

item.title: Russian weapons sales are exploding.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Despite worldwide arms sales decreasing for three years in a row according to the the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, Russian arms companies boosted sales by 20% in 2013, mostly due to the country's military spending. Meanwhile, France is buying more arms, and Spain and Italy are cutting back.

item.title: The Korean Air nut rage scandal may lead to an arrest.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Cho Hyun-ah, the daughter of the CEO of Korean Air, may face criminal charges for her meltdown this month, after she verbally assaulted flight attendants because they served her nuts in a bag instead of on a plate and forced the plane to return to the gate. Cho reportedly told investigators that she had several glasses of wine beforehand.

item.title: Delhi is teaching its taxi drivers about sexual harassment.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Nearly half of New Delhi's roughly 100,000 auto-rickshaw drivers have completed a new two-hour course that teaches men how to respect women. The course—which started in Jan, long before the alleged Uber rape—is mandatory for taxi drivers and rickshaw drivers.

item.title: Sydney's hostage crisis ends in bloodshed.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: After more than 16 hours, police stormed a cafe where a self-proclaimed Muslim cleric named Man Haron Monis had taken 17 hostages. The Iranian-born hostage taker and two of the hostages were killed, and four people were wounded.

item.title: British Telecom is in talks to buy EE.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The UK's largest mobile operator, part-owned by Orange France and Deutsche Telekom, is in talks to be acquired by Britain's former telecom monopoly for £12.5 billion ($19.5 million). Combined, they would be a force to be reckoned with, though any deal is sure to raise concerns with competition regulators.

item.title: What does Putin, oil, and the ruble have in common?
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: China's economy is about to magically expand again.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

item.title: Denmark says it owns the North Pole.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: In an uncharacteristically belligerent move, it's challenging the US, Russia, Norway, and Canada for sole sovereignty of 895,541 square kilometers (556,463 square miles) of the North Pole—an area about 20 times the size of Denmark.

item.title: The US finally has a surgeon general.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Vivek Murthy was narrowly approved by the US Senate, in a hard-fought confirmation process that was opposed by the gun lobby and had left the post vacant since July, 2013. Murthy, who co-founded a group advocating gun safety, will serve a four-year term as the nation's top doctor and public health advocate.

item.title: The ruble continues its free-fall.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: In response to Monday night's emergency interest-rate hike, the Russian currency initially rallied but then had its biggest one-day fall in 16 years. Some say the only plausible next step is capital controls. That will put further pressure on an economy already suffering from Western sanctions and low oil prices.

item.title: Sony was warned about hacks a year ago.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Hollywood studio which had reams of sensitive information published online was told that hackers were mining data on a regular schedule late last year, according to Bloomberg. Contractors discovered the security breaches while patching up holes from a 2011 hack on Sony’s PlayStation network.

item.title: Rio’s Olympic waters are not fit for sporting events.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A superbug resistant to antibiotics and that can cause urinary and other infections is present in seawater where sailing and windsurfing events are planned for the 2016 Olympic Games. A lot of Rio de Janeiro’s sewage is dumped into waters nearby.

item.title: McDonald’s Japan is rationing french fries.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It will only sell small portions—though an unlimited number of them—due to a potato shortage caused by a labor dispute at US West Coast ports.

item.title: The Pakistani Taliban slaughters schoolchildren in Peshawar.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A handful of militants stormed a military-run school and killed at least 145 people, with over 100 of them being children (paywall). The Pakistani army says most of the 500 students that were in the building have been evacuated, but others are still being held hostage inside.

item.title: A UK bank fails a stress test.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Co-Operative Bank said it would sell £5.5 billion ($8.6 billion) of assets to meet capital requirements after it flunked the Bank of England’s first public stress test. RBS and Lloyds barely passed a test that simulated high unemployment, falling house prices, and an interest rate hike.

item.title: China's 2013 GDP figure will get only a small bump.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The country often reassesses its economic data, and many investors were expecting to see as much as a 10% upwards revision to last year's GDP later this week (Friday), but according to the head of the National Statistics Bureau, there will be only a 3% rise. In another sign of weak growth, December's PMI for manufacturing shrank for the first time in seven months.

item.title: The US collects some massive fines.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
