item.content:encoded: Bloomberg and Reuters both report that French engineering firm Alstom is about to pay $700 million to the US Justice Department to settle allegations of bribery in Indonesia, allowing Alstom's sale to GE to go ahead. Meanwhile, Sprint is reportedly due to settle for $105 million (paywall) for overcharging mobile subscribers.

item.title: Google's mobile payments bust is pushing Samsung to come up with its own
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The beauty of Android—Google's mobile operating system for phones and tablets—is that it comes with a host of the internet company's services pre-installed and ready to be used right out of the box. One of those, Google Wallet—a mobile payments product—has been completely shunned by the market, thanks to a mix of poor product design, marketing, and distribution. Less than two years after launching in late 2011, the head of the project, former PayPal veteran Osama Bedier, left to start a point-of-sale system company. With Android powering more than 83% of the smartphones that were shipped last quarter, Google's largest partner, Samsung, has reportedly decided that enough is enough. According to Recode, the South Korean electronics giant—which made nearly one out of every four smartphones sold last quarter—is in talks with a US startup called LoopPay to launch an Apple Pay competitor next year. Samsung isn't a stranger to mobile payments. It partnered with Visa in 2012 to launch a limited edition batch of Galaxy S3 smartphones that supported Visa's payWave technology. In 2013, Samsung expanded that partnership to 40 European countries and the Galaxy S4. This year, with wearables being on the tips of everyone's tongue, reports suggested Samsung would partner with PayPal to put mobile payments on its smartwatches. It's too early to know if the LoopPay deal will happen, let alone amount to anything. But US payments infrastructure is in for a shakeup next year with Apple launching its watch and US retailers switching to chip-based card systems. Samsung, to be sure, has an incentive to break away from Google for a service as important to its customers' daily life as payments. If Samsung can gain any meaningful traction with its service, it may create lock-in that prevents Galaxy owners from bailing for other Android phone makers. But Samsung has already tried this in other categories, such as media stores, with limited success. And if Google Wallet—which beat Apple Pay to market by almost three years—was already a huge hit, it might not have to bother.

item.title: There could be a third Bush in the White House.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Jeb Bush, the son of the 41st American president and brother of the 43rd, took to Facebook to announce that he's "decided to actively explore the possibility of running for President of the United States" in 2016. Will he face former first lady Hillary Clinton? She's yet to make a similar statement.

item.title: Apple wins a court case over old iPods.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A jury found Apple not guilty of anti-competitive practices in a class-action lawsuit over security features—now discontinued—that prevented iPod owners from loading music not bought on Apple's iTunes. The plaintiffs were seeking more than $1 billion in damages.

item.title: Mars may be home to some gassy organisms.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: NASA's Curiosity rover is detecting "belches" of methane gas being emitted on Mars, which scientists think may be escaping from stores trapped underground. On Earth, most methane is produced by living organisms, so it's a tantalizing sign of possible life on Mars—but it might just come from chemical reactions between water and rock.

item.title: American Apparel finally dumps Dov Charney.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The clothing company's founder was suspended back in June as CEO and chairman after a long and sordid saga of sexual harassment allegations, but stayed on as a consultant; now he's out for good. Paula Schneider will replace him in early January and maintain the brand's "sweatshop-free, Made in USA manufacturing philosophy."

item.title: Carnage in Yemen as well as Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The final death toll in the attack on a school by Pakistani Taliban reached 141, including 132 children. Meanwhile, Yemen saw 25 people—including 15 children—perish in a twin car-bombing at a checkpoint in the country's central Bayda province.

item.title: Markets deliver an eloquent statement on Russia's rate hike
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

item.title: Sony's hackers threaten a terrorist attack over "The Interview"
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Someone purporting to represent the Guardians of Peace, the group that stole a massive trove of documents from Sony Pictures and has been leaking them online, warned people to stay away from Sony's as-yet-unreleased North Korea comedy, saying, "Remember the 11th of September 2001." Sony said US theater owners could chose to pull "The Interview" if they are worried about the threat.

item.title: Shopping season for oil companies.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Spain's Repsol agreed to buy Canadian oil producer Talisman for $8.3 billion, after low oil prices brought down Talisman's value. If prices stay low for a time, expect to see more such deals.

item.title: Apple halts online sales in Russia.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Extreme fluctuations in the ruble have forced the iPhone manufacturer to close its primary sales channel. Last month, Apple raised the Russian price of an iPhone 6 by 25%.

item.title: Haiti protests turned violent.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Police fired tear gas after demonstrators calling for the resignation of president Michel Martelly burned tires and threw stones at police in Port-au-Prince. Martelly has repeatedly delayed elections since 2011.

item.title: Bad Santa robbed a San Francisco bank.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: And he got away with it, thanks to thousands of Santas in town for a pub crawl.

item.title: Threats prompt a theater chain to drop “The Interview.”
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Carmike Cineamas, the fourth-largest US chain, won’t screen Sony’s controversial North Korea comedy, according to Bloomberg. The move comes after Guardians of Peace, the group that leaked a massive trove of Sony documents, threatened audiences, warning, “Remember the 11th of September 2001.”

item.title: Alaska may lose its AAA credit rating.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Low oil prices could squeeze the state government’s tax revenues (paywall), Moody’s said. Last year about half of the state’s income came from the oil industry.

item.title: Grief in Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Mass funerals begin for the 132 children and nine adults massacred in the Pakistani Taliban’s attack on a school. Prime minister Nawaz Sharif has approved a decision to reinstate the death penalty and vowed to eliminate terrorism in his country. “No difference will be made between good and bad Taliban," he said.

item.title: Russia mounts a ruble defense.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The finance ministry said it started selling some of its $7 billion in foreign-currency holdings, giving the ruble a pop in early trading. But the biggest effect will come from the central bank, which has more than $400 billion in cash, gold, and other holdings it can swap into rubles if necessary.

item.title: Sony cancels its New York premier for "The Interview."
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The decision came after Guardians of Peace, the group that leaked a massive trove of Sony documents, invoked September 11th in a threat to audiences of the North Korea-themed comedy. Carmike Cineamas, the fourth-largest US chain, won’t screen the film, according to Bloomberg.

item.title: SpiceJet grounds its flights.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: India’s fourth-biggest airline by market share cancelled flights after being cut off by its fuel suppliers. The move came a day after SpiceJet won a government-backed reprieve to give it more time to repay its debts.

item.title: A non-profit group wants to compost your dead body.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: One human ought to be enough to fertilize a tree.

item.title: The Sydney gunman was on a security watch list.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It turns out Man Haron Monis was on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation watch list in 2008 and 2009, but for unknown reasons he was taken off. The Iranian-born self-styled cleric took 17 people hostage in a cafe earlier this week, and was later killed—along with two of his hostages—after a 16-hour siege.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Also in the aftermath of the siege, an 82-year-old former professional tennis player recounted his escape from the madman.

item.title: Cuba and the US are restoring diplomatic relations.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The process is likely to move fast: loosened travel and economic restrictions were are already in place—including a rule allowing travelers to bring in Cuban cigars and whiskey—and there could be a US embassy in Havana within months. But Republicans have threatened to block the appointment of a US ambassador to Cuba, and vowed to to maintain the 51-year-old US trade embargo.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Yesterday, in a prisoner swap, Cuba released a contractor accused of spying for America, 65-year-old Alan Gross, as well as an unidentified US intelligence source, while the US released three Cuban intelligence agents.

AP sources: US, Cuba seek to normalize diplomatic relations as part of prisoner release deal: http://t.co/09qRc8DIP0

— The Associated Press (@AP) December 17, 2014

BREAKING: Obama: US ending `outdated approach' to Cuba, beginning to normalize relations.

— The Associated Press (@AP) December 17, 2014

Castro: We've agreed to restore diplomatic relations.

— Gideon Lichfield (@glichfield) December 17, 2014

item.title: Pharmacists will face charges in 2012's deadly meningitis outbreak.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Contaminated steroids made in a Massachusetts compounding pharmacy killed 64 people across the US and infected over 700 others with fungal meningitis. Authorities arrested 14 people, including the co-owner of the company and a pharmacist who worked there.

item.title: These jeans are designed to make you feel secure.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The anti-virus software maker Norton is teaming up with the clothing retailer Betabrand to make hacker-proof blue jeans that block wireless radio signals—useful if you carry an RFID-enabled credit card or ID. They'll go on sale in February for about $150.

item.title: When hiring a private jet, it pays to shop around for a bargain.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: The European Parliament stands up for Palestine.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The body voted 498 to 88 to recognize "in principle" the idea of Palestinian statehood. The vote is symbolic, but adds to a recent swell of international pressure in favor of the Palestinians, who are also pushing for the UN to call on Israel to pull out of the West Bank by November 2016.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The move follows similar parliamentary resolutions in the UK, the Republic of Ireland, Spain and France; as well as Sweden officially recognizing Palestine as a state. Meanwhile, the European Union’s second-highest court removed the "terrorist organization" designation of the Palestinian group Hamas (paywall).

item.title: A mass grave has been found in Eastern Syria.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: More than 230 bodies were discovered by members of a tribe who were finally allowed to return home after battles with the Islamic State militant group in Deir al-Zour province this past summer, said the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The UN says it received reports of massacre back in August.

item.title: The Dalai Lama says perhaps he should be the last person to hold that title.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Once he dies, the spiritual leader says it may not be worth continuing the centuries-old tradition, since "There is no guarantee that some stupid Dalai Lama won't come next, who will disgrace himself or herself. That would be very sad." But ultimately, he said, the decision will be up to the Tibetan people.

item.title: A US judge overturns a black teenager's murder conviction, 70 years after his execution.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In 1944, 14-year-old George Stinney Jr. was executed in South Carolina after an all-white jury convicted him in the killing two white girls. In her ruling, judge Carmen Tevis Mullen said Stinney's one-day trail violated his constitutional rights, and the ruling was an attempt to "correct injustice where possible."

item.title: New York state bans fracking.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Shale gas and oil extracted by hydraulic fracturing has fueled a US energy boom, driving down oil prices worldwide. Critics, including New York's health commissioner, say that fracking contaminates water, air, and soil, and Gov. Andrew Cuomo's administration concluded that the economic benefits are outweighed by the risks.

item.title: Colombia's rebels announce a unilateral ceasefire.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The left-wing FARC made a big concession to the Colombian government, which has rejected a bilateral ceasefire during two years of peace talks. The indefinite ceasefire, which takes effect on Dec. 30, could hasten the conclusion of a five-decade war that has killed more than 220,000 people.

item.title: Sony Pictures cancels "The Interview."
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The studio pulled the North Korea-themed comedy’s planned release following terrorist threats against theaters and a devastating hacker attack that leaked reams of sensitive company data. Anonymous US officials told US news outlets that North Korea directly ordered the hacks, but some say the evidence is thin.

item.title: Sony Pictures cancels The Interview.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The studio pulled the North Korea-themed comedy’s planned release following terrorist threats against theaters and a devastating hacker attack that leaked reams of sensitive company data. Anonymous US officials told US news outlets that North Korea directly ordered the hacks, but some say the evidence is thin.

item.title: Uber promises better driver screening.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The on-demand car service said that it would build a custom driver screening tool to help protect its customers, as an Uber driver in Boston was charged with rape and kidnapping after he allegedly assaulted a female passenger earlier this month.

item.title: Macau has a serious Baccarat addiction.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Putin’s state-of-the-nation.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Russian president delivered his annual press conference to 1,200 journalists. Over the course of three-plus hours, he touted Russia’s diversified economy, championed innovation, and called for an end to using the law for political means.

item.title: Samsung’s de facto holding company has a mega-successful IPO.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Cheil Industries more than doubled its market capitalization as it raised 1.52 trillion won ($1.38 billion). The IPO will help the family of ailing CEO Lee Kun-hee consolidate control of Samsung’s sprawling empire as the company prepares for a generational power transfer.

item.title: A suspected Boko Haram attack kills 33 people.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Dozens were also abducted in the raid by militants in northeast Nigeria. Separately, a Nigerian court sentenced 54 soldiers to death for mutiny and cowardice, for allegedly refusing to fight the extremist group.

item.title: Cuba is owed back rent for Gitmo.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It has refused to accept US payments, but normalized relations may change that.

item.title: Thinking reduces confidence.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: We become less sure of our choices the longer we consider our options.

item.title: Amazon can now get toilet paper to you within an hour.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: If you live in parts of Manhattan and are a Prime member, the online retailer has launched a new service called "Prime Now," accessible via a new phone app (Android and iOS), which delivers "tens of thousands" of items to your doorstep in one hour for $8, or for free in two hours. For non-Manhattanites, Amazon says the service is "coming soon to a city near you."

item.title: Cosmetics maker Avon fined $135 million for bribes in China.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The US Securities and Exchange Commission slapped the world's largest direct seller of beauty products on the wrist for delving out $8 million in payments and gifts to Chinese officials between 2004 and 2008. Some of the money was paid out to "avoid fines or negative news articles that could have impacted Avon's clean corporate image."

item.title: Minecraft is getting a makeover.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Telltale Games—a gaming studio that has released titles based on hit television franchises such as Game of Thrones and The Walking Dead—has announced that sometime in 2015, it will launch an episodic game called Minecraft: Story Mode. It isn't an add-on for the popular title; it's a story-driven version of the do-it-yourself game, which Microsoft bought for $2.5 billion in September.

item.title: Marc Benioff and Eduardo Saverin just funded a fake mayo company.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Food startup Hampton Creek Foods, whose goal is to replace egg products in food with plant-based alternatives, just scored $90 million in funding at a reported $500 million valuation. Backers include Marc Benioff, CEO of Salesforce, and Facebook cofounder Eduardo Saverin. Last month, Unilever sued Hampton Creek for its "Just Mayo" product, which Unilever argues can't be called mayonnaise if it doesn't use eggs.

item.title: The price of oil resumed its decline.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Oil prices rallied briefly Thursday after Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, characterized the price slump as "temporary," and said that crude demand would rise as the global economy improved. But the months-long slide resumed following glum commentary from OPEC leaders and Russia's Vladimir Putin, who said low oil prices could last as long as two years. The US benchmark for oil prices fell to below $56 a barrel; the global Brent benchmark lost nearly a dollar before landing at $60.26 (paywall).

item.title: Bitcoin’s collapse is worse than the ruble’s
item.dc:creator: qzroya

item.title: The US says three top ISIL leaders have been killed in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: General Martin Dempsey, the Pentagon's top uniformed officer, told The Wall Street Journal (paywall) in an interview that the deaths of these "high-value targets" took place in recent weeks, in a push by coalition forces ahead of an offensive planned for 2015.

item.title: The Fed gave banks more time to comply with the Volcker Rule.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Banks holding onto billions of dollars in private equity investments will get to hold onto them a little longer, the US Federal Reserve has said. Banks will now have until July 2017 to comply with the Volcker Rule, part of the Dodd-Frank Act reforms meant to curb risk-taking after the financial crisis. The extension was granted after banks warned that divesting quickly might have "potential disruptive effects" on markets.

item.title: No more swimsuit competition for Miss World.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The organizers of the event—which first took place in 1951—want Miss World to be "more of an ambassador, not a beauty queen," which means no more strutting around stage in skimpy bathing attire. There will still be a "beachwear" segment in the competition, however, with the requisite critiques of contestants' fashion.

item.title: A major tuna merger.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Thai Union, the world’s largest producer of tinned tuna agreed to buy Bumble Foods, the US’s biggest tuna and sardine company for $1.51 billion. Thai Union has plans to expand its North American portfolio, and anticipates raising Bumblebee’s revenue by 25%.

item.title: American Apparel receives a buyout offer.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Irving Place Capital first expressed interest a few weeks ago, and has since raised its offer to $1.30 to 1.40 per share (paywall). Share prices jumped 45% on the news to $1.

item.title: Unilever drops a lawsuit over eggless mayo.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: One of the world’s largest food companies previously sued Hampton Creek over its “Just Mayo,” an alternative to mayonnaise made from plants instead of eggs (paywall). Also on Thursday, three-year-old Hampton Creek received a further $90 million in backing, bringing its valuation to $500 million.

item.title: China adds $305 billion to last year’s GDP.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Beijing increased the estimated size of the national economy in 2013 by 3.4% to 58.8 trillion yuan ($9.5 trillion). The gain came mostly from an adjustment in the value of the services sector, but the GDP figure may be significantly lower if measured by non-Chinese standards.

item.title: Japan maintains its stimulus.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The central bank will add 80 trillion yen ($672 billion) to the monetary base annually, in line with expectations. Falling oil prices are a real headache for the bank, as they risk lowering inflation, just as the BOJ is trying to stoke it.

item.title: Nobody has blue eyes.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Their eyes are made up of particles which only reflect blue light.

item.title: Brits are getting greener.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The average person in the UK uses 10% less electricity than they did five years ago.

item.title: Kurdish forces report a major win against ISIL.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Security forces in northern Iraq said they have broken the siege of Mount Sinjar, in which Islamic State fighters had trapped thousands of Yazidis since August. Eight thousand peshmerga were supported by air strikes in a two day assault.

item.title: Uber agrees to temporarily leave Portland.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The on-demand car service will withdraw from the Oregon city for three months while Portland alters its private car regulations. Uber said it would work with the government after launching two weeks ago despite objections from city officials.

item.title: It's been a great year for hedge funds—in India.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Bumble Bee Tuna will be acquired for $1.51 billion.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Thai Union Frozen Products calls the deal "the largest acquisition in the history of our company and one of the most exciting external growth propositions." Its CEO says with the purchase, revenue will rise by 25% (paywall); the fate of San Diego, California-based Bumble Bee's 1,300 employees is unknown.

item.title: BlackBerry is throwing off cash once more.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Canadian smartphone maker generated $43 million in cash flow in its fiscal third quarter, its first quarter of positive cash flow in nearly two years. More importantly, this happened one quarter earlier than CEO John Chen promised. Unit sales fell to 2 million from 2.1 million in the previous quarter.

item.title: Hackers likely broke into Sony's systems ages ago.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That's the conclusion of a Japanese security software maker that ran simulations of the attack. It says the malware that infected Sony's computers started gathering usernames and passwords likely months before the virus was triggered. The firm, Trend Micro, declined to say how it obtained the malware, according to Bloomberg.

item.title: Turkey releases some of the journalists it arrested.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Eight in total, including the editor in chief of Zaman, a daily paper with a circulation of more than 900,000, were being held because the government thought they were somehow going to overthrow them. Four other people working in media, including the head of Samanyolu TV, are still in custody.

item.title: NASA sends a wrench to space via email.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Thanks to a 3D printer installed on the International Space Station last month by NASA astronaut Barry "Butch" Wilmore, the US space agency was able to design a socket wrench on the ground and then have Wilmore build the wrench in space. Beats waiting around for the next supply flight.

item.title: Russia sends a warning to the US about additional sanctions.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: If further obstacles and restrictions are placed on the Eastern superpower, foreign minister Sergei Lavrov says the relationship between his country and the United States would be damaged "for a long time". A new US law that was recently passed allows US president Obama to increase sanctions—but even he says he'd rather not.

item.title: Sony's hackers say they'll stop releasing data.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Because the company decided to cancel The Interview, a comedy about two Americans sent to North Korea to kill its leader, the hackers who have been leaking emails and private data say they're done—for now. "We will assure the security of your data unless you make additional trouble," they said.

item.title: Most people sitting in boardrooms don't know what's going on.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A 2013 McKinsey survey of 772 directors has only 34% of directors feeling like the boards they're sitting on know just what exactly the company is doing. Directors of companies in emerging markets, however, are more likely to not only know about the industry they're in, but offer actual long-term strategies.

item.title: Obama doesn't mince his words on the Sony scandal.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: During the US president's end-of-year press conference, Obama said he wished Sony "would've asked me first" about whether or not to cancel The Interview, a comedy that involves the assassination of North Korea's leader. He even went so far as to say the company "made a mistake."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Sony Pictures CEO Lynton issued a rebuttal: "We have not caved, we have not given in, and we have not backed down. We have every desire for the public to see this movie."

item.title: Canada will soon be competing with its neighbor for Havana's beaches.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Staples was hacked—as many as 1.16 million cards are affected.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The office-supplies chain says 115 point-of-sales systems were infected with malware between July and September. Details on which stores were impacted haven't come out yet, but the breach appears to have been relatively contained next to the ones that struck Target (40 million cards affected) and Home Depot (56 million cards).

item.title: Currency trader arrested in rigging probe.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: A former foreign-exchange trader at the Royal Bank of Scotland has been arrested (paywall) by the UK’s Serious Fraud Office, the first arrest in the world as part of a global criminal probe by the US, UK, and Switzerland into rigging of the currency markets. Six banks, including RBS, paid $4.3 billion settle

item.title: Currency trader is arrested in rigging probe.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: A former foreign-exchange trader at the Royal Bank of Scotland has been arrested (paywall) by the UK’s Serious Fraud Office, the first arrest in the world as part of a global criminal probe by the US, UK, and Switzerland into rigging of the currency markets. Six banks, including RBS, have already paid $4.3 billion settle forex rigging allegations.

item.title: Pay your bills, or we take the cat.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Tax collectors in Russia have come up with an incredibly effective new tactic: threatening to seize debtors' cats. The Siberian region of Tomsk, for example, placed four pedigree Scottish Fold kittens "under arrest."

item.title: The US weighs its options over North Korea.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: President Barack Obama said the hacking of Sony Pictures is not “an act of war,” but that the US may still put North Korea on its terrorism watch list. Pyongyang called for the US to take part in a joint investigation or suffer “grave consequences.” Meanwhile, Sony is reportedly exploring how to stream the The Interview.

item.title: Four Afghans held at Guantanamo are released.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: The men were sent home to Kabul overnight on a US military plane, bringing the number of prisoners at the US military facility in Cuba—which the Obama administration advocates closing—down to 132. It marked the first return of Guantanamo Bay prisoners to Afghanistan since 2009.

item.title: The US government is seeking hefty fines against BP.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: The feds are asking for $18 billion in a non-jury trial to determine BP's financial penalty for the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. That penalty—which would be a record under the Clean Water Act—would handily eclipse the $3.5 billion that BP has set aside to cover its liabilities.

item.title: Students at US universities are surprisingly old-school.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz

item.title: A key Taliban commander is killed in Peshawar.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: A day after killing 32 militants in Pakistan's Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, Pakistani security forces said they killed the commander and at least four other militants in the province's capital of Peshawar, where scores of schoolchildren were murdered by Taliban gunman earlier this week.

item.title: Xiaomi closes in on new funding at an eye-popping valuation.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: A $1 billion funding round that could close as soon as Monday would value the Chinese smartphone maker at $45 billion (paywall)—more than four times what it was worth 16 months ago, according to the Wall Street Journal. The new funding round's lead investor is the All-Stars Investment fund, run by former Morgan Stanley analyst Richard Ji.

item.title: New York City police say they're under siege.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The NYPD directed police to travel in groups (paywall) after a gunman killed two officers in Brooklyn on Saturday, and senior police officials said mayor Bill de Blasio—who campaigned on promises to reform the police department—had “blood on his hands.” Ismaaiyl Brinsley, a Brooklyn native with a lengthy rap sheet, had vowed on Instagram to kill police in retaliation for the death of unarmed black men in New York and Missouri.

item.title: The old guard claims victory in Tunisia.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Beji Caid Essebsi, the 88-year-old leader of the secular Nidaa Tounes party, won Sunday's presidential election according to officials, though incumbent Moncef Marzouki has still refused to concede defeat. Essebsi is seen as a return to the ancien régime, whose economic mismanagement set off the Arab Spring in 2011.

item.title: Facebook angers Russian activists.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: At Moscow’s behest, the social network blocked access to a page calling for a protest march on Jan. 15 (The page is still online, but people in Russia can’t see it). Other pages quickly popped up to replace it.

item.title: OPEC blames everyone else.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Oil ministers from the UAE, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia (paywall) blamed "non-OPEC" oil producers—Russia and the US are the biggest—for the collapse in oil prices. "If they want to cut production they are welcome: We are not going to cut, certainly Saudi Arabia is not going to cut," said the Saudi oil minister; prices rose 1.2% after his comments.

item.title: "Allahu Akbar" attacks in France.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A man shouted “God is Great” in Arabic as he ran down pedestrians in the city of Dijon, injuring 11 people. French media reported the man was”apparently imbalanced” and had spent time in a psychiatric hospital. A man shouting the same phrase was shot dead by French police on Saturday after he attacked them with a knife.

item.title: Sony weighs its options for "The Interview."
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The studio is reportedly exploring how to stream the controversial film, but denied reports that it has decided to use its in-house Crackle online service.

item.title: Nerds really are taking their revenge.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The creator of Minecraft outbid Beyoncé and Jay Z to buy a $70 million mansion.

item.title: The dark net is darker than ever.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Silk Road was tame compared to the illicit online marketplaces that replaced it.

item.title: China is building a military base near the Senkaku/Diaoyu islands.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The base on China’s Nanji islands includes several landing strips and will contain several more in the future, according to Japan’s Kyodo newswire, which cited unidentified Chinese sources. The new base puts China’s military 100 km (62 miles) closer to the contested area than Japan’s armed forces.

item.title: Spain charges a princess with tax fraud.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Cristina de Borbon, sister of the king, is the first member of the Spanish royal family to ever face criminal charges. Her husband is accused of embezzling millions of euros through his non-profit foundation.

item.title: Suddenly, Google is surrounded by pessimism
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: China offers struggling Russia an economic lifeline.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: With the Russian economy and the ruble under strain, Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi told reporters Beijing is willing to engage in a currency swap with Moscow. This would allow Russia to strengthen its currency without straining its foreign-exchange reserves, and ensure greater use of the Chinese currency in bilateral trade.

item.title: Forced religious conversions cause a stir in India's parliament.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The opposition said Prime Minister Narendra Modi has done nothing as Hindu-nationalists groups allied with his political party conduct forced conversions into Hinduism in several parts of the country. The leader of the largest Hindu group said conversions of "those who have lost their way" will continue.

item.title: China is unenthusiastic about punishing North Korea for hacking.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In a phone conversation with US secretary of state John Kerry, Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi said Beijing will deal with Pyongyang and its alleged involvement in the Sony hacking only when it has more facts. And even then, it'll follow "international laws and norms, and Chinese laws."

item.title: Uber faces bans in Taiwan and China.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In Taiwan, where Uber has permission to operate "information services," not transport passengers, the minister of transportation the company must "obtains the proper licence." In China, the city of Chongqing—population 29 million—says Uber's business model is "classified as illegal behavior."

item.title: Report says Elon Musk's Hyperloop plan could work.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A start-up called Hyperloop Transportation Technologies has published a 76-page report on the Tesla CEO's plan to build a transport system capable of traveling at 800 miles an hour between Los Angeles and San Francisco. The report estimates the project would take 10 years and $16 billion to build.

item.title: Humanity's next home: A balloon colony above Venus.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: NASA says that while Venus is uninhabitable due to high temperatures and a dense atmosphere, the planet comes with a silver lining: roughly 30 miles above its surface, conditions are similar to those on Earth.

item.title: A selfie too far earns a Chinese surgical team the sack.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: After a successful seven-hour operation, a team of doctors and nurses at the Fengcheng Hospital in Xian congratulated themselves by posting a group photograph. Their bosses, declaring this disrespectful, fired them all.

item.title: Pakistan plans to execute 500 terrorists.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Having only recently brought back the death penalty, Pakistan will impose it on roughly 500 convicted militants in the coming weeks. This appears to be a reaction to last week's Peshawar massacre, in which 133 children were killed.

item.title: The Pope says the Vatican suffers from "spiritual Alzheimer's."
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In a hard-hitting Christmas speech to the church's cardinals, bishops, and priests, Pope Francis called on the Vatican bureaucracy to cure itself of such ills as "existential schizophrenia," "social exhibitionism," and a lust for power.

item.title: South Korea's nuclear power company is hacked.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Korea Hydro and Nuclear Power says its 23 reactors are fine, and that it is "100 percent impossible" for hackers to penetrate the nuclear control system since its "totally independent and closed." But the company says "non-critical" information was stolen. It's yet to announce who was responsible for the breach.

item.title: Belgium's prime minister suffers a French-fry attack.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Charles Michel had an order of pommes frites hurled at him—along with a generous squirt of mayonnaise—by protestors disgruntled with the government's austerity plans. Earlier this month, a national strike by several unions paralyzed the country's transportation infrastructure.

item.title: China to send peace-keeping troops to South Sudan.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: State-run media outlets say 180 troops will join UN forces in the country next month, with another 520 to follow in March. The news comes immediately after China National Petroleum signed a deal with South Sudan to increase oil production.

item.title: Welcome to the new normal for existing US homes sales.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: BMW launches a national US recall for Takata airbags.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The luxury carmaker will replace airbags in 140,000 vehicles across the United States. Takata itself has so far refused requests to implement a nationwide recall, despite reports of at least five deaths caused by its airbags deploying improperly.

item.title: North Korea’s internet mysteriously goes down.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The 10-hour outage came after US president Barack Obama promised a “proportional response” to the North Korea-supported cyberhack of Sony Pictures. Other explanations—such as cybervigilantes acting against North Korea, or Kim Jong-un’s regime taking down its own internet to prevent an attack—are also possible.

item.title: Hong Kong property tycoon Thomas Kwok is jailed.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The 63-year-old former co-chairman of Sun Hung Kai Properties was sentenced to five years in jail and was ordered to pay HK$500,000 ($64,000) for paying bribes to Rafael Hui, the city’s former number-two leader. Hui was jailed for seven and a half years and ordered to pay HK$11.2 million.

item.title: TripAdvisor is fined for “misleading” reviews.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The travel website was ordered to pay €500,000 ($613,000) by Italy’s competition watchdog for failing to make sure its reviews are “authentic and genuine.” The company was given 90 days to respond.

item.title: There is a Christmas catalogue for Scientologists.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It includes a $5,000 e-meter with “accuracy guaranteed for eternity.”

item.title: Kentucky spotted its first puma since the US Civil War.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A wildlife official promptly killed it.

item.title: China raids an Uber office.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Police stormed a driver training session in the central Chinese city of Chongqing last Wednesday, the same day the on-demand car service was announcing a tie-up with search giant Baidu. Authorities in Chongqing warned that illegal cab services would face charges, but did not mention Uber specifically.

item.title: North Korea’s internet comes back.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The 10-hour outage came after US president Barack Obama promised a “proportional response” to the North Korea-supported cyberhack of Sony Pictures. Other explanations—such as cybervigilantes acting against North Korea, or Kim Jong-un’s regime taking down its own internet to prevent an attack—are also possible.

item.title: Dalian Wanda falls after its IPO.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Shares of the Chinese commercial property giant dropped by as much as 8.8%, before closing down 2.6% over concerns about the company’s valuation and debt levels. The decline means that chairman Wang Jianlin will remain China’s second-wealthiest man behind Alibaba founder Jack Ma.

item.title: It's far from over yet for brick-and-mortar stores.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Narendra Modi is winning over India’s Muslims.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The prime minister’s predominantly Hindu Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has already won 25 seats in elections in Jammu and Kashmir, India’s only Muslim-majority state. The BJP is expected to win more than 30 seats in total, the most that it has ever won there, and enough to give Modi more clout in talks with Pakistan.

item.title: Greece fails to elect itself a president—again.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: No-one was expecting lawmakers to come to a decision during the second round of voting anyway. The government's candidate, Stavros Dimas, did secure 168 votes, however—eight more than last time. He'll need 180 votes during the third and final round of voting later this month or a snap general election will be held, probably ousting the government.

item.title: Ukraine takes a step towards NATO membership.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Parliament voted on Tuesday—303 to eight—to end the country's "non-aligned" status, which means it can now join military alliances. One day earlier, Russian prime minister Dmitry Medvedev said on Facebook: "An application for NATO membership will turn Ukraine into a potential military opponent for Russia."

item.title: A German anti-Muslim group holds its biggest ever march.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: An estimated 17,500 members of "Patriotic Europeans Against Islamisation of the West," or Pegida, sang Christmas carols in front of Dresden's Semperoper concert hall. Some 4,500 counter-demonstrators hit the pavement with the message "Dresden Nazi-free". Pegida's rapid growth—it began only last October—has stunned the German mainstream; Germany's leading Jewish organization has condemned it too.

item.title: Al-Jazeera goes dark in Egypt.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The channel, which made a name for itself with its reporting of the Arab Spring in 2011, has decided to shutter its Egyptian station, Mubashr Misr, until it can "[obtain] the necessary permits in co-ordination with the Egyptian authorities." Al-Jazeera's clear support for Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood earned it the enmity of the generals who ousted the Brotherhood in 2013.

item.title: The US economy grew 5.0% in the third quarter.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The original estimate, given in October, was 3.5%. That got bumped up to 3.9% last month. Many economists expected to see it revised upward once more to 4.3% today, but nope—America's GDP grew the most it has in over a decade.

item.title: Nicaragua breaks ground on its Panama Canal rival.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Its been over 200 years in the making, but thanks to Chinese capital, the construction of this $50 billion waterway to connect the Atlantic and Pacific oceans has begun. "Nicaragua expects to move 5% of the world's commerce that moves by sea," said the country's vice president, adding the canal will double Nicaragua's GDP.

item.title: Apple's online store returns to Russia.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The electronics maker took the store down last week due to the ruble's rapid depreciation, but now it's back—with prices that are 35% higher for those interested in buying the company's popular iPhone. This is on top of the 25% increase the Russian iPhone received in November.

item.title: Coca-Cola is going on a diet in 2015.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The soda maker warned—back in October—that it's going to need to shave $3 billion off its spending by 2019, but now The Wall Street Journal is translating that (paywall) into actual jobs: 1,000 to 2,000 layoffs "in the coming weeks," the biggest cut in 15 years. America's decreasing desire for pop is to blame; so is Mexico's soda tax.

item.title: "The Interview" is indeed hitting theaters this Christmas.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Multiple independent cinemas have tweeted out that the film studio has given them the green light—The Alamo Drafthouse in the US state of Texas is already taking orders. Sony's CEO even issued a statement saying "we have never given up" on releasing the film, despite earlier reports saying it has.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In related news, or not: North Korea's internet connection, which went completely offline yesterday, is back up. US officials denied that the outage was America's retaliation against North Korea for the hack that North Korea denies perpetrating against Sony.

item.title: The US may ease its ban on gay men giving blood.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Food and Drug Administration will recommend allowing men to donate blood if they haven't had sex with another man for at least 12 months. That would put the US in line with European countries and could increase blood supplies by 2% to 4% (paywall). Gay groups decried it as little different, in practice, from the previous lifetime ban.

item.title: Startups clearly invest in their engineers.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: The Dow breaks past 18,000.
item.dc:creator: mbackmanqz
item.content:encoded: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed another 1,000 ticks higher, just under six months after hitting 17,000. The S&P 500 also set a record. Neither index had a particularly exciting day, but it was enough to get the job done.

item.title: The US’s GDP revision boosts nearly everything.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The price of oil rose to a near-two week high after the US announced its economy grew at an annualized 5% in the third quarter. The dollar and stocks in Asia also jumped on the news.

item.title: “The Interview” will get its Christmas release.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Sony Pictures will release the North Korea-themed comedy on Christmas Day after all, with at least one US theater chain confirming it will screen the film. That’s an about-face from the studio’s earlier stance following a major hack and threats of violence.

item.title: Australian police arrest a man on terrorism charges.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Police in Sydney said the man was in possession of documents naming potential government targets.

item.title: UPS and FedEx reach their delivery limit.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The freight companies have held some retailers to volume limits (paywall) after a last-minute surge in online shopping threatened to overwhelm air express deliveries. Last year millions of packages missed their Christmas deadline when last-minute online shoppers overloaded shippers.

item.title: Standard & Poor’s threatens Russia with junk status.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The ratings agency put the country on a watch list, saying there is “at least a 50% chance” that Russia’s sovereign credit rating will be lowered to junk within 90 days. That would mean Russia was no longer classified as investment grade for the first time in a decade.

item.title: Ireland defends Microsoft in a cloud computing test.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Irish government moved to protect the American IT giant (paywall) after a search warrant was issued in the US for data stored on its servers in Ireland. The tussle could have far-reaching implications for privacy and cloud computing.

item.title: Alibaba has over 7,000 people spotting fakes.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It spent over $160 million in the past two years weeding out copycat goods.

item.title: Electricity can cure arthritis.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Scientists made a pacemaker-like implant that works better than traditional medicine.

item.title: Police kill another black teenager near Ferguson.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Antonio Martin, 18, was shot dead at a gas station in Berkeley, Missouri—adjacent to Ferguson, where 18-year-old Michael Brown was shot dead in August. The St. Louis county police, who cover both towns, say he pointed a handgun at an officer. Local officials say a surveillance video supports this claim.

item.title: South Korea indicts Uber’s CEO.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The city of Seoul also indicted the company’s local subsidiary after it said the on-demand car service violated a public transport law. Earlier this week the company faced legal issues in Taiwan, and in China police raided one of its offices.

item.title: European truck makers “operated a 14-year cartel.”
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The biggest truck-making companies in Europe collaborated to hold up the progress of emissions-reducing technology, according leaked documents seen by the Financial Times (paywall). The six truck makers named in the report have a near-100% market share in Europe.

item.title: Takata's president and COO is stepping down.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Stefan Stocker says he is stepping down to director for "personal reasons," but the shift comes on the heels of the airbag problems that lead to a recall of 24 million cars by 12 different auto-makers (paywall). Shigehisa Takada, the company’s chairman and chief executive officer and its founders' grandson, will take over Stocker's previous roles.

item.title: A record number of French people are unemployed.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Official figures show 3,488,300 people are without work—the highest number ever documented. President François Hollande said if he doesn't manage to fix this problem, he's not going to run for re-election in 2017. Next month, parliament will debate controversial labor reforms which include allowing businesses to open up shop on Sundays (paywall).

item.title: Claims of widespread Russian athletics doping will be tested.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Earlier this month, a German documentary reported that 99% of Russian athletes are taking some kind of performance-enhancing drugs, and that Russian athletics authorities are covering it up. The World Anti-Doping Agency has now traveled to Moscow to collect and test around 3,000​ samples from athletes, says the country's sports minister.

item.title: South Korea wants China's help to catch a hacker.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Earlier this week, South Korea's nuclear power network was hacked, though authorities say it did not undermine the actual reactors. The country says the attack originated from the Chinese city of Shenyang, near the North Korean border, and that "there is a strong possibility that Pyongyang was behind the attack."

item.title: A Japanese artist faces obscenity charges for her vagina-themed art.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Megumi Igarashi is an international censorship cause célèbre after her works—including a kayak based on the shape of her vagina and her sharing of the data to 3D-print her genitals—led to her arrests in July and then again earlier this month. The artist, who goes by "Rokudenashi-ko," pleaded not guilty.

item.title: Jordanian pilot's father begs ISIL for his release.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The father of a pilot from Jordan, who became the first foreign soldier from the US-led coalition airstrikes to be captured by Islamic State fighters pleaded publicly for his release. Earlier this week, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said at least 1,171 terrorists have been killed by the airstrikes.

item.title: A van carrying $68 million crashed—can you guess what happened next?
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: After the accident, which took place at lunchtime on a busy highway in Hong Kong, people swarmed the road and made off with millions in banknotes. Roughly $4.5 million was stolen, with one witness saying a "regular looking Hong Kong lady" walked away with at least 10 bricks of cash. Local police want people to return the money.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Christmas comes early! Scramble for cash after banknotes are spilled across busy road http://t.co/oGEQhXRczH pic.twitter.com/3lNjaQRsff

— SCMP News (@SCMP_News) December 24, 2014

item.title: You'll be able to watch "The Interview" from your couch today.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The controversial film about a mission to assassinate North Korea's leader comes out in select theaters tomorrow, but Sony has decided stream the film on its own website from 10am PST today for $6 as a rental or $15 as a purchase. It'll also be live on several other services.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
ICYMI: "The Interview" available to rent online. Statement from #Sony pic.twitter.com/tdtkGcnMK0

— WFMY News 2 (@WFMY) December 24, 2014

item.title: The US denies Roman Polanski's request to reconsider his case.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A court in California ruled that the film director—who pleaded guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old during a photo shoot in Los Angeles in 1977—should return to the US state if he wants the court to consider dismissing the case. Polanski also tried unsuccessfully to have the case dropped in 2008.

item.title: Here's what to call your bro when you're in the southwestern US.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

item.title: Militants attack an African Union base in Mogadishu.
item.dc:creator: javinsqz
item.content:encoded: Somali Islamic militant group al-Shabaab said they were targeting a Christmas party when they attacked the African Union's base in Mogadishu, where gunfire and explosions were heard on Thursday. The building abuts the airport and also houses the UN headquarters in Somalia. The AU mission in Somalia says nine were killed.

item.title: Putin cancels holidays.
item.dc:creator: javinsqz
item.content:encoded: Following the ruble's catastrophic collapse, the Russian president told his government ministers not to take off the standard break for the New Year and Orthodox Christmas during the first 12 days of January. "We cannot afford this long holiday, at least this year," Putin said in a televised government session. "You know what I mean."

item.title: Relative calm in St. Louis, Missouri.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The city had a mostly calm night after clashes between protesters and police earlier this week. Protesters rebuilt a memorial to 18-year-old Michael Brown, who was shot in Ferguson in August, after a car drove through it.

item.title: Asia marks the 10-year anniversary of a deadly tsunami.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: A decade ago today, an earthquake beneath the Indian Ocean triggered a massive wave that killed 226,000 people in a dozen countries. They were remembered in prayer services and memorials in Thailand, Indonesia, Sri Lanka and elsewhere. The region is better prepared now to deal with natural disasters, the United Nations said.

item.title: Seven New Yorkers arrested over cop threats.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: The NYPD has arrested seven individuals for threatening to kill cops on social media, in phone calls to precincts or, in one case, in an overhead private conversation. Three of the arrests were made because of comments users made on Facebook.

item.title: XBox and Playstation disruption continues.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: The two game platforms' networks are still down for millions of users, after a cyber-attack by a group called Lizard Squad on Christmas Day. A counter-hacking group known as Finest Squad had scored some successes this month against Lizard Squad—but evidently not enough.

item.title: Philadelphia cab companies sue to block Uber.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: More than 40 cab companies in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, filed a complaint against the online taxi-booking company in a federal court on Dec. 24, calling it a "criminal enterprise" and comparing it to bootlegging. The companies want Uber banned from the city.

item.title: The UN is pulling back further in Darfur.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Once the world's largest peacekeeping operation, the UN force has already shrunk and is to shrink further (paywall) as the agency tacitly admits defeat in the face of attack from both government and rebel forces. A former spokesperson for the mission has accused the UN of "whitewashing" its own failures.

item.title: Japan Post could become the world's biggest-ever IPO.
item.dc:creator: javinsqz
item.content:encoded: The state-owned postal service—which also runs Japan's biggest bank—has announced plans to list its postal service, insurance, and bank units (paywall) in an IPO late next year. Executives didn't say how much of the holding company would be sold, but government officials have estimated the share offering could raise $40 billion (paywall).

item.title: How you could have made billions investing—with perfect hindsight
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

item.title: Peace talks on Ukraine break down.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Belarus, which hosted a strained first round of talks between Ukraine's government and pro-Russian separatists on Wednesday, said a second round set for today has been canceled. Ukraine's decision earlier this week to end its "non-aligned" status and move towards joining NATO infuriated Russia, which is also a party to the talks.

item.title: Libya's largest oil port is on fire.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Smoke is billowing (paywall) from the Es Sidr terminal, as fighting rages between the government and militias attempting to seize control of the country's crude oil export income. The port, which can handle 400,000 barrels a day, has been closed since Dec. 13. Despite the fighting, oil prices continued their decline, underscoring the extent of the global oil glut.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This video from Russia Today shows the effect of a rocket that hit a storage tank on Thursday:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cWxq1yasY54

item.title: Expect a not-so-busy Black Friday.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: US retailers are forecast to sell $9.1 billion worth of goods, nearly a fifth less than two years ago, and—for the first time in a decade—less than on “Super Saturday,” the one before Christmas. Still, forecasts for the overall holiday shopping season are optimistic (paywall) as the economy rebounds.

item.title: The ruble slides again.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Despite assurances on Thursday from the finance minister that the ruble crisis was over, the Russian currency weakened again on Friday; it's down 39% this year. The central bank announced it was trebling a previously agreed rescue loan for a medium-sized lender, Trust Bank, thereby taking a sizeable chunk out of a planned bank rescue fund.

item.title: Tensions rise over New York police killings.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Thousands, including Vice President Joe Biden, attended Saturday's funeral for Rafael Ramos, one of the two policemen shot dead this week in apparent retaliation for the police killing of Eric Garner. But some officers turned their backs on Mayor Bill de Blasio as he eulogized the slain officer, apparently in response to his past criticism of police tactics.

item.title: North Korea blames US for net breakdown.
item.dc:creator: tfernholz
item.content:encoded: Officials pointed the finger—and racial epithets—at the US after suffering major internet outages. The pariah state has denied responsibility for a security breach at Sony Pictures that ostensibly prompted American retaliation. As with that case, we may never know what went wrong. “I guess accidents can happen,” one US official said this week.

item.title: Indonesia suspends search for missing AirAsia plane.
item.dc:creator: tfernholz
item.content:encoded: Flight QZ 8501 lost contact with air traffic controllers at 7:24 local time, while flying from Surabaya, Indonesia to Singapore. The search will resume in the morning. The Airbus 320-200, was carrying 162 passengers and crew.

item.title: The US-led war in Afghanistan is officially over.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: For the US-led forces, known collectively as the International Security Assistance Force, a 13-year campaign has come to an end. But the Taliban insurgency continues, and 13,500 soldiers—mostly American—still remain, to train and guide Afghan forces.

item.title: The Syrian regime says it is willing to meet opposition groups at Moscow peace talks.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Russia says the "informal" talks will take place next month, with the goal of ending the four-year civil war that has killed more than 200,000. Many opposition groups have already said they will not attend; ISIL is almost certain to reject any negotiations.

item.title: Soccer icon George Weah does to his political rival what he once did to Verona.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: The 1995 World Footballer of the Year won a seat in Liberia's senate, defeating the son of president Ellen Johnson Sirleaf by a landslide. Weah is best known internationally for one of the greatest goals ever scored.

item.title: The man who tried to kill one Pope wants to meet another.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Mehmet Ali Agca has placed flowers at the grave of John Paul II, 33 years after he shot the pontiff. The Vatican held out no hope for a meeting with Pope Francis.

item.title: The washing-machine war between LG and Samsung may have gone too far.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Prosecutors in Seoul have raided LG's headquarters and banned the CEO from leaving the country, as part of a probe into whether the company damaged washing machines of its rival Samsung at stores in Berlin. LG denies the charge, and has counter-sued Samsung employees.

item.title: Sony's PlayStation network has been restored—but for how long?
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: The company says it has resumed service after several days of disruptions by hackers calling themselves the "Lizard Squad." The same group hacked the PlayStation network earlier this year. Microsoft's XBox Live, which also went down on Christmas Day, was restored Dec 26.

item.title: The Norman Atlantic ferry has been evacuated, but the death toll is rising.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: The BBC reports "all the surviving passengers" have been taken off the Italian ferry, which caught fire on Sunday off the coast of the Greek island of Corfu. There were 478 people on the ship and the death toll stands at 10, but the Associated Press reports that only 414 people were rescued, leaving more than 40 people unaccounted for.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Italian Navy reports only the captain of #NormanAtlantic, Argiglio Giacomazzi, left aboard with four Naval officers.

— John Hooper (@john_hooper) December 29, 2014

item.title: The missing AirAsia plane is presumed to be "at the bottom of the sea."
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Flight QZ8501 disappeared en route to Singapore, but the plane most likely crashed into the Java Sea, according to the head of Indonesia's National Search and Rescue Agency; there have been unconfirmed reports of debris spotted in the search area. The search has been suspended for the night and will resume on Tuesday morning local time.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Packed outdoor press conf at Surabaya airport now. Officials say #AirAsia8501 likely at bottom of sea pic.twitter.com/EU9QvIkyrl

— Tom Phillips (@tomphillipsin) December 29, 2014
